PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Willis:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my great pleasure to rise today to speak on the budget and the measures associated with the budget. In so doing, I emphasise some issues which arise from the general direction which the government has taken in the budget and the white paper—especially the philosophical direction it has taken—and to contrast that with the direction the opposition parties, especially the Liberal Party in its revived form, have been attempting to take.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, the central thrust that comes out of the budget is the emphasis on social justice. There is no doubt that social justice is the key factor behind the white paper and the attempts through the white paper to do something for the long-term unemployed. In that context, there is also no doubt that the initiatives of the white paper, in trying to come to grips with the problems of the long-term unemployed, are some of the most revolutionary of those adopted in any Western country. As the green paper stated, rather than allow the marketplace to simply take a very long time in getting the long-term unemployed to find employment, even in the context of an economic recovery, the white paper has put in place a comprehensive program that attacks the problem by trying to ensure that every long-term unemployed person is looked after, especially on a case by case basis.

There will be a very significant attempt to ensure that these people are put into employment. Where there are difficulties in terms of the level of training, there will be a very significant attempt to put them into training, into labour market programs and, in certain cases, into education programs. For example, there will be an attempt to put people of migrant backgrounds who have insufficient English resources into English language programs. In other words, we will do everything to ensure that the long-term unemployed are given a sustained position in our society.

This concept of social justice for the long-term unemployed and giving everyone a guarantee to help them contrasts dramatically with the concept of social justice which the conservative parties have had. One might have thought that with the change of leadership in the Liberal Party we might have been able to look forward to some change in the areas of the attitude to the unemployed, the attitude to aged care, the attitude to health and the attitude to those who are the most disadvantaged in the community.

Instead, with the new face of the Liberal Party, notwithstanding the claims of the new leader that there would be a move to a more middle ground approach and to a party that was not ideologically driven, in the new shadow cabinet only two people come from the moderate wing of the party; the rest come from the dry ideological hard right. This is not something that I have stated; it was on the front page of the Australian when the new shadow cabinet was announced.

People wondered how this very dry shadow cabinet was going to suddenly transform itself into having a new philosophy and a new position from which it was going to put forward a middle ground, pragmatic and reasonable approach compared to the previous approach, given that the frontbench, especially the key shadow cabinet frontbench, was constituted by the hard dries of the Liberal Party.

We had the extraordinary situation that the moderate spokesman on certain key areas of responsibility with respect to social justice was shifted into the outer cabinet. In the key health area we have had the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) put forward as the health spokesman, which includes dealing with the key area of social justice. I suppose this is part of the new image of the Liberal Party.

Yesterday the honourable member for Mackellar presented her maiden speech. In the maiden speech she attempted to present the philosophy which she was going to pursue within this parliament. If one analyses that philosophy, the fundamental point that comes through is that it is unreconstructed New Right philosophy. In fact, it is more extreme than the most coherent spokesman of the New Right in other countries.

According to the honourable member for Mackellar, the situation in respect of the pursuit of the philosophy of the modern Liberal Party is to be nothing more than a return to a 19th century view of the political philosophy of the right; that is, total emphasis on individualism and total rejection of any participation by the state. That was the gist of her philosophy.

In her speech the honourable member tried to tell this House that the models to be pursued were Britain and New Zealand, two nations—not the only two, but the two she chose—which have pursued the Thatcher New Right philosophy. Newspapers reported last week that the British Prime Minister, Mr Major, made a shameful attack on homeless unemployed people, telling them that they should not be begging in the streets. The fact that people now have to beg in the streets of Britain—something that never happened for many years—is a testament to the failed policies of Thatcherism and the New Right. That is a fundamental point which the whole of the world has understood except, of course, the new federal opposition. It dares to pretend that it believes in social justice and then puts forward people who hold extreme right views as its major spokesmen in health and other key areas.

If we were to pursue the views put forward by the honourable member for Mackellar we would hold to the very simple minded idea that it is just a question of choosing between the individual and the state, between what the individual and the marketplace can deliver to the individual and what the state can do. This simple minded philosophy has been rejected even by the thinkers in the right. Everyone understands that in the modern world you cannot simply have the marketplace taking the dominant role, the total role, with respect to the individual and have the state taking a negligible role. That kind of approach was rejected even by the founder of the Liberal Party, the Hon. Robert Menzies.

Instead of going to the position set out by Menzies, which was a relatively modern position for the time, if we are to find anyone who propounds the sorts of views set out in the speech of the honourable member for Mackellar we have to go backwards into history, into the 19th century. This would not be a matter of concern if these were simply the views of one individual but with the new Liberal Party we now have a number of spokespersons who are supposed to deal with key social justice areas and social policy areas and whose credentials in terms of their personal philosophy are such that they are not moderate people. They are not people who are talking about the necessity of balancing the role of the state and the role of the marketplace to deliver the best situation for the rights of the individual. They are people who would totally get rid of any role for the state and the government and leave the individual to the ravages of the marketplace.

As we have seen in Britain and in other countries that have adopted this formula, such as the United States under President Reagan, an underclass has been created, a group of people who are permanently either unemployed or in severe poverty and who receive no reasonable assistance. That would be the consequence of adopting a philosophy such as that put forward by the honourable member for Mackellar.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an underclass here now.

—The honourable member interjects that we have an underclass here now. This is how much he knows about sociology. The reality is that Australia, through proposals put forward in the white paper and other measures adopted by this government, has been able to avoid that phenomenon. In fact, we are the only Anglo-Saxon country that has avoided that phenomenon because we have never adopted the absurd New Right philosophies of Thatcherism and Reaganism.

PARA.TAB: If we are to continue to have some measure of debate on social justice policy in this country, as was hoped when the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) took control, those members of the opposition frontbench who hold these extremist views ought to be shifted or they ought to be told to adopt a new philosophy and approach. An article in the Australian headed `Bishop in iron maiden speech' outlines the approach of the honourable member for Mackellar. Obviously, she is going to model herself on Margaret Thatcher. She should note that Margaret Thatcher's approach has been rejected even by the bulk of the Conservative Party in Britain. The problem is that the Conservative Party cannot find a new philosophy to replace it and is struggling to find some identity. But the reality is that the approach of Mrs Thatcher has been rejected even by the party which she led. It certainly has been rejected by most of the conservative parties around the world.

When the new Leader of the Opposition was elected, we hoped that we would see on the opposition front bench at least a balance between the moderates and the dries. We hoped that we would see the development of a new approach and a new philosophy which would allow for a genuine debate in this country about social policy issues in the areas of health, aged care, assistance to the disabled, assistance to the unemployed and ethnic affairs.

What has occurred in the area of ethnic affairs is an outrage. The President of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia was forced to issue a statement, following the announcement of the membership of the new opposition frontbench. Notwithstanding the Leader of the Opposition's assertion of his support for multiculturalism, the spokesperson for immigration and ethnic affairs has been shifted out of the shadow cabinet. He is now in the outer shadow ministry. Can you believe that? In the key area of multiculturalism and ethnic affairs, the opposition spokesperson, Senator Short, has been shifted out of the shadow cabinet.

How can anyone take seriously the claim that the opposition is really interested in presenting any new philosophy or position when its key spokespersons are ideologically of the New Right? The honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), who is now responsible for community services and aged care, has been shifted to the outer ministry. So those people who may have brought some new ideas and balance and provided greater comprehension of social policy have been shifted out of the shadow cabinet. We now have an extremely dry opposition frontbench which is once again putting forward the same old philosophy, if the speech by the honourable member for Mackellar is any guide.

In contrast to this, the government is moving forward with respect to the continuing development of its social philosophy. We are now increasingly defining social justice as not merely a set of programs but a coherent philosophy of social rights.

Rather than looking simply at what the individual might gain from society through the marketplace, this government is committed to a situation in which the most disadvantaged, the most unfortunate, are assisted through government programs and guaranteed that assistance as of right.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about jobs?

—I will conclude on the point of jobs. One of the most important rights that one can guarantee is, increasingly, the right to employment. We have had the recession and we are now coming out of it. The government has said that it is not going to allow a situation in which the long-term unemployed, those who find it difficult to participate in the work force because they have been the most tragic victims of the recession, stay unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Rather the government is going to have active programs to assist these people to become job ready—to get training, to gain the relevant level of education—and to get jobs. If the honourable member had bothered to look at the white paper he would know that jobs will be created through special wage subsidy incentives for employers who take on the long-term unemployed. There will be not only the creation of a large number of jobs through the wage subsidy scheme but also a special scheme specifically for the long-term unemployed, the people who have been most disadvantaged.

This is social justice in practice. This is an attempt to put forward a social right for the unemployed and to ensure that they are guaranteed improved prospects. There could be no further illustration of the philosophical difference between the government and the opposition than the guarantees which have been given by the government to the unemployed and the general attempt to embed in this society the general social democratic philosophy that people are entitled to a fair go and that the state, the government, has a very important role to ensure that they do get a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, I congratulate the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) and the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) on their maiden speeches. I know the honourable members for Mackellar and Warringah will have very great contributions to make in this place and I hope they enjoy their time here. I certainly extend to the honourable member for Bonython the sentiment that he has a very fulfilling time in this chamber though hopefully not an enduring one.

PARA.TAB: I would like to commence my discussion of the budget by reminding honourable members of some of the headlines that graced the front pages of Australia's newspapers on 11 May, the day after the budget was delivered. The screaming headlines included, `Betting on a boom', `Rubbery risk', `Vote for me and my budget', `A trust-me budget', `Labor punts on growth and a trusting public'. A Courier-Mail headline appropriately read `What budget? Mr Willis fudges the figures'.

Most people agree that this year the government has delivered an unnecessarily risky budget. The government is betting on a continuing economic recovery and massive business investment to solve the nation's problems—which, of course, emanate from 11 years of Labor rule. The government is playing a gambling game. Gamblers rarely come out on top and if they do, it is only temporary. The gap in this nation between the rich and the poor has widened during the 11 years of Labor. In fact, a lot of what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), said was utter nonsense. This is a government of the rich and not of the poor.

Australia no longer has a reputation as an equal, classless society. Today only 40 per cent of Australian households could be classed as middle income earners, while in the 1970s 65 per cent of households received an income of between $22,000 and $72,000 a year. This is a tragedy and sadly we have seen the development of an underclass in this country, and this trend is continuing to grow. We now see gaps opening up that did not exist before. In 16 years, the middle class of Australia has collapsed. Those affected make up, of course, Menzies' forgotten people. Fifteen per cent of Australian households had an annual income below $22,000 in 1976 but in 1992 that figure had increased to 38 per cent.

This is not the Australia our founding fathers envisaged. Who would have thought that in 1994, the International Year of the Family, an Australian couple would be better off financially and better able to provide for their children if they were divorced in this the year of the family? The Australian published a story the day after the budget about a family which was desperately looking for some relief in the budget. It was a story about a Melbourne middle-class couple with three children. Their son had had to move out of home to receive higher Austudy payments and rent assistance, and a daughter was planning to do the same. The parents, both unemployed, said that if they divorced or lived separately they would be better off financially under the existing social security system. The family received $525 in unemployment benefits per fortnight, and after paying $200 a week rent they were left with about only $60 a week.

There are many families throughout Australia in the same situation. They are living in hope that their elected representatives will help. Consequently, when the Treasurer (Mr Willis) brought down his budget this year, they were looking for a life raft. They were looking for some assistance; instead, what they got was more of the same. Quite frankly, it is time that this government either fixed the problem or stepped aside to allow others to fix it.

We still have around a million people out of work and possibly up to two million Australians unable to find sufficient work. We have hundreds of thousands of Australians involved in the no-win training schemes of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which serve only one purpose—to rort and fudge the jobless figures, to make it seem as though fewer Australians are out of work than in fact really are. These training schemes will fail and will continue to fail because there are no jobs to go to. People have come to me in my office and complained that they have been sent to four, five, six or seven training schemes; they have this ticket and that ticket but still no job. We have the best trained dole queues in the world, and that is a tragedy for unemployed Australians.

We had the government's white paper on unemployment, the so-called Working Nation package, which has basically disappeared without trace, and the government's white paper on employment. That does not create jobs; it just trains more people. We need $6.5 billion to pay for these programs. Where does the government expect to get the money? With its betting record, one would imagine it will go off to the casinos of this nation. In reality the government probably hopes to take it from business—big business and small business—by increasing taxes, by extending the fringe benefits tax, by seeking to enforce greater compliance with the tax system. I notice that it expects to raise $300 million from increased compliance measures. The government is bleeding business dry.

There is no doubt that this budget increases taxes on all Australians, and the government is increasing its outlays as well. What happened to the recommendations of the FitzGerald report? If the government refuses to save, why should the Australian people save? This government should be setting an example. Instead it spends more, takes more, sells the family silver and relies on gambling to pay its debts. What sort of example is that for the Australian people? What sort of example is that for young Australians?

This is an extravagant government, a government of want and waste. Australians have witnessed want and waste at the Lodge, fraud and waste in the Department of Social Security and in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. We have seen hundreds of millions of dollars squandered on bureaucratic consultancy fees. This government takes more from the people; it spends more, wants more, wastes more and ultimately owes more.

With this budget, the government will squander any benefits of economic recovery in a bid to shore up its short-term political prospects, its increasingly bleak political prospects. It has tried to make the country's economic position look better than it really is by exaggerating growth and business investment forecasts. This is an election budget. To quote from the editorial in the Advertiser on 11 May:

Short of actually producing How To Vote cards on the floor of the House of Representatives, it is difficult to see what more the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and his Treasurer, Mr Willis, could have done in the production of an election Budget.

Having proclaimed within the first minute or so of delivery "no new taxes and no increases in tax rates" (not entirely accurately), Mr Willis promptly found some megadollars to address recent headline concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The megadollars will come partly from the sale of family silver. The government's rubbery figures are partly based on unattainable sale prices for Commonwealth assets. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) said yesterday, the government is `selling off the family silver to pay the champagne bills'. He said, `You can sell the silver only once, but the champagne bills keep coming.' Unfortunately, the government appears to be drunk. The government does not really understand what is happening. It is time that the government started to think past the next election and to introduce policies that address the very real problems of this nation and its people.

PARA.TAB: Australia can return to its former status, it can provide its citizens with one of the best standards of living of all OECD countries, but it cannot do that if we continually flog off our assets and use the proceeds for recurrent expenditure rather than to reduce debt. This government has a moral responsibility to the Australian people to discontinue its slick, fast money tactics and bandaid solutions in its never ending shopping spree in pursuit of votes. This budget's projected $11.7 billion deficit was designed to soothe the financial markets which were displeased with the Working Nation package. But take away overambitious sales prices based on assets, repayments and other figure fudging exercises, and in reality we are more likely to have a budget deficit in the 1994-95 year of a figure approaching $18 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that from? Make it up, did you?

—No. Sound economists have pointed out that this government's deficit figure of $11.7 billion is nothing short of a fraud. At a time of economic recovery, the government should be saving, attempting to reduce our debt and planning for the future. The Australian business community has had to cut back over the past decade in order to survive and yet has maintained its level of service to the community; the government can and should be doing the same.

PARA.TAB: Instead, the government is moving very much in the wrong direction. The government has had very little favourable comment on its budget. The budget editorial in the West Australian said it all:

SPEECH.PARA: That trend defies conventional economic theory that governments should spend more in recessions to stimulate activity but cut back when the economy improves. . . The budget is based on expectations of 4.5 per cent real growth next year—at the upper limit of predictions by private economists and well ahead of growth among OECD nations. It also hinges on a mooted rush of business investment.

The 4.5 per cent growth figure is based on the assumption that private investment will increase by 14.5 per cent. As we all know, there was nothing in the budget to trigger new business investment—another gamble. The government is relying on business to start spending because there appears to be a favourable economic climate.

PARA.TAB: What if demand continues to rise and business does not spend? Then we are again faced with the danger of inflationary pressures. We might see an increase in investment in the future but not at the level the government forecasts. Many commentators from the business community have said that the government's growth forecasts are unduly overoptimistic. Most recently, Don Mercer from, I think, the ANZ Bank said that the government's figures were not figures that he would expect to see.

The Reserve Bank has now confirmed that interest rates are rising. Our industrial relations situation, particularly following the passage of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act, is unlikely to encourage investment or promote jobs. In fact, the Industrial Relations Act will cost jobs, and that is why the government is having to come into the parliament to seek amendments: it knows that the Industrial Relations Act is an unmitigated disaster. An Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry spokesman, Ian Spicer, confirmed, after the budget was announced, that investment would not occur to an adequate extent and jobs would not be created. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . business will be concerned about the credibility of the economic projections, especially as they relate to plant and equipment, based on extremely optimistic growth of over 24 percent. There are also questions about the underlying deficit which is well above $11.7 billion. Depending upon the degree, this will affect interest rates and work against investment.

It is no surprise that the figures are phoney. The government's record at fudging figures is impeccable—just look at unemployment: change the names of a few welfare payments, shuffle a few large groups of unemployed people into different Department of Social Security lines, call them trainees and, like magic, the unemployment rate drops overnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —No real jobs created at all.

—No real jobs are created, as the honourable member for Parkes quite accurately points out to the chamber. The budget does nothing to reduce unemployment. In fact, experts are suggesting that the gap which already exists in Australia between rich and poor will continue to widen.

PARA.TAB: Constituents in the Fisher electorate have not been fooled by the government's budget. Many have contacted me since 10 May to say that this budget offers them nothing. People are appalled that the government has effectively abandoned its second round of tax cuts. People are appalled at the $1.24 billion Aboriginal land fund which treats some Australians differently from others. Sunshine Coast residents are angry about the impact the departure tax hike will have on the region's international tourist industry. This government has no real understanding of the contribution the tourist industry makes to the economy and just how important tourism is for job growth not only on the Sunshine Coast but throughout Queensland and Australia. As well as the revamped departure tax, $17 billion in tax will be taken from the tourism industry this year. These tax increases will deliver a major blow to our international competitiveness as a tourist destination and will impact heavily on international tourist havens like the Sunshine Coast. Job seekers will be the losers on the Sunshine Coast as a result of these tax increases.

The Australian Council of Social Service has warned in a post-budget article in the Australian that Australia was likely to be a `deeply divided community' by the end of the decade. ACOSS President, Robert Fitzgerald, was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We still fear that by the end of the decade, Australia will be a deeply divided community between those who are able to access well paying and secure employment and those who will be low income earners and who are unable to generate wealth . . . and that division is not being addressed by the measures announced in the white paper or the budget in sufficient quantity to have an impact.

This government is the last of the big spenders and plans, hopes or is desperate to win a lottery to pay the bills. In summary, the budget was big on hope, big on spending and the government was betting on a boom. If Australians are being told to save, should their government not be setting the example? If business is being urged to invest in the future of Australia, should the government not invest in the future of Australians by creating real long-term jobs, not mickey mouse schemes, not short-term training schemes which do not provide long-term employment?

PARA.TAB: This government has been the government of the quick fix and has failed desperately. This government has denied its responsibility to the people of Australia and has failed, yet again, in this budget and in the government white paper. This government has once again sold out our children's future in pursuit of its short-term political aims. This government stands condemned by all Australians for its shonky budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Few budgets have been as well received as the budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 10 May. It was well received because it was a realistic budget which set the course for national growth in the economy. It has really been interesting to listen to opposition members struggling to find areas to criticise. I noticed one theme coming out: they are starting to say that our children or our children's children will be the ones who pay for this budget. It will be a very different society that our children or our children's children reside in. Those people in future generations will look back on this budget as a landmark.

PARA.TAB: I have been very interested to hear some of the opposition's very imaginative imagery. I sometimes wonder about the opposition. I know an opposition party is there to oppose and put an alternative point of view, and I would not argue with that. Why is the opposition not more supportive of this country when putting that alternative point of view? Why is it always talking the economy down in this country? Why is it always sending negative images of Australia and our economy abroad? I believe that an opposition has a role to play and has a duty to stop sending such false and negative images.

If this budget offered so little, why was it universally welcomed across Australia? Why did all the editorials support it? Why did the major groupings from all sides of the economy, from all sides of the nation, support this budget? I listened, as I always do, to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) when he told us how his phone had been ringing hot since the budget had come down. Every time a budget is handed down I have my staff in my electorate office on stand-by. We have a spreadsheet showing the various issues that people will ring up and comment on either for or against. At the end of the day my staff phone the results through to me so I can report them to my colleagues here. At 5 o'clock on the day after the budget, the spreadsheet was still virgin white. There was not a mark on it, because not one person in the electorate of Throsby rang up. I might say that they did not ring to congratulate me either, but they did not ring on one issue. Believe you me, the people of Throsby know how to use the telephone and they know their way to their local member's door.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are unhappy, they do.

—They most certainly do. Not one person rang up, which is good. I compared my notes with those of the electorates on either side of me, Cunningham and Gilmore, and all our sheets were virgin white. The people of the south coast, who know what unemployment is about and who know what welfare is about, were satisfied with the budget. If they were not dancing in the streets of sunny downtown Dapto, they most certainly were not wailing and gnashing their teeth.

PARA.TAB: Let us put all this nonsense aside that the members of the opposition continually bring up about this budget. I actually sympathise with them because they have to get up here each day and trot out a 20-minute speech. It is very difficult to give a 20-minute speech when there is nothing to criticise. So their old minds go into overdrive. I suppose a few notes are churned out by some of the shadow ministers and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) to give those opposite points to raise. They say, `Scare them. Scare the Australian people. Say their children will have to pay for it. Say it is not a real budget. Say the figures are shonky.' That is what they are saying, but no-one is picking that up. It is not happening because this is a good budget and has been very well received.

Let me put on the record that I was one of those members who had a few criticisms about the budget last year and raised them with the relevant ministers. May I modestly claim that, along with some of my colleagues, some of my views were taken account of and certain modifications were made. Let me also put it on the record that it was a difficult budget last year. We on the government side appreciated it was, but we appreciated also that difficult decisions had to be taken. I strongly believe that it was the hard decisions taken in last year's budget that helped to shape this one.

The hard decisions of last year were about maintaining the deficit reduction strategy. Those hard decisions of last year have produced a budget which will, as the Treasurer stated, maximise economic growth, reduce unemployment—I do not know where the opposition is getting its figures from that the budget will not reduce unemployment—promote social justice, which is something we do not hear too much about from those opposite, and reduce the budget deficit without any increase in taxes.

I suppose when we stand up in this place we always like to draw attention to successes, modest as they may be, in which we believe we have played a contributing part. In that way, modest as I always am in the chamber, I claim to have played a contributing part—no more than that—in three decisions taken within the budgetary context. The first one was to help right the wrongs done to merchant mariners who were exempt from the veterans' entitlement. Merchant mariners will now be entitled to the same benefits as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

This was a two-year campaign ably led by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). The honourable member deserves credit for his efforts. I had the honour to second the motion that he moved in 1992 when he introduced the bill. Let me put on the record that the opposition supported the bill. It was a bipartisan campaign. I remember that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) spoke very strongly on that matter in 1992.

Soon after the 1993 election, the honourable member for Shortland reintroduced that motion. Again, I had the honour to second it. Again, the honourable member for Dawson and the honourable member for Hinkler spoke to it. It was such an important issue, we more or less made the same speeches as we made in the preceding year. Although it did not affect a lot of people, a great injustice was being done to those people who had served in the merchant fleet. They had not been given their true recognition and had not been entitled to the same entitlements received by veterans.

I pay tribute to the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca), who took this issue on board and righted a wrong. Righting that wrong will not win this side or the other side any votes. It affected very few people, but a great injustice had been done to a group of citizens in Australia. Members on both sides of the chamber saw that, and that wrong has now been rectified.

The other issue that I believe I played some small role in was the reduction in the fuel levy excise. It would not often be said in speeches in this place, but I believe that the reduction in the fuel levy excise was an unintended consequence of the last budget. Let me be generous—I am in a particularly generous mood—and pay tribute to the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), who rose in this chamber and drew attention to the fuel levy excise in speech after speech. Although the honourable member for Hume and I sometimes disagree on transport matters, on that matter—as I said in each of my speeches—I agreed with him wholeheartedly.

I believe—and I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe), who is at the table, agrees with me—that the reforms undertaken in the Australian shipping industry, the lowering of crew levels, multiskilling, everything that has been achieved that we are so proud of, have made us world competitive. Despite what those opposite might say, we have a good record in Australian shipping. I believe that unintended consequence wiped out some of the gains that we made over 12 months. The charge has now been reduced by 2c, and that will save Australian shipping between $6 million and $8 million a year. That will continue.

The minister made that decision. It was the correct decision. I am not too proud to say that the wrong decision was made in the preceding budget. When we have perceived that a wrong has been done to Australian industry, we are big enough to correct it and say, `We got that one wrong. We admit it and we will put it right.' We do not stand and defend it and keep it there; we correct it. That decision has been a great boost to Australian shipping.

Another decision that does not involve my electorate but which affects it greatly is the one in the white paper, released in the lead-up to the budget, about commencing work on Badgerys Creek. As people know, I am the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. I chaired the committee that recommended that work proceed on Badgerys Creek, Sydney's second airport.

In their wisdom, the minister and the government of the day rejected the unanimous decision of the public works committee. It was one of the more foolish decisions of this parliament. When a committee of parliament comes down with a unanimous decision, some considerable thought, study and investigation have gone into it. I will not go on about ministers rejecting something like that out of hand, but I have private views about the issue which I have expressed to a few of my colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would like to hear them.
—I know that the honourable member would like to hear them, but he will not hear them from me today.

PARA.TAB: The government saw sense in proceeding with Badgerys Creek. I have reservations about selling off some of the airports in Australia, but I can see the logic of it. There would be no difficulty in selling off Tullamarine, Kingsford Smith, perhaps Coolangatta and a few airports that the government could profit from, but who would really want to buy—this is no disrespect to my Tasmanian friends—the Hobart or Launceston airports? At the moment, there is a cross-subsidy. I believe that it should stay. I worry about some of those smaller airports, such as Adelaide airport and a few other airports, all being sold off.

I also worry that one reason for the sale is the funding of Badgerys Creek. As someone who has totally supported Badgerys Creek, this worries me. The report of the public works committee said that the $56 million that the government had already put up should stay; there was no argument about that.

For once, let the private sector put its money where its mouth is. It is talking about Badgerys Creek, and I am talking about it. I believe that Badgerys Creek has a great future as an international freight airport. If we want to get into Asia, we have to have the infrastructure. I can see jets going out from that airport every day.

Last week, I was in Taiwan. The potential for trade between this country and Taiwan is something that we have not even tapped. One real problem with trade is that countries become the flavour of the month. We put all our efforts and energy into devoting everything to the new country that is suddenly the flavour of the month, forgetting our traditional markets and not trying to expand into new ones. We just let it roll. We are seeing this time and again in Asia.

I remember how a couple of years ago the People's Republic of China was the flavour of the month. We had ministers, vice ministers and deputy ministers coming through here at a rate of knots. At the time, I was the secretary to the trade and resources committee. I was being dined with Chinese officials three times a week. My parliamentary dining room bill was almost zilch because every night I was out with the minister being wined and dined with a delegation from the People's Republic of China. I do not know how much our trade improved; it was not all that much.

At the moment, Vietnam is the flavour of the month. We are putting a lot of effort into it. Trade missions are beating a path constantly to get into the Vietnamese market. But so is everyone else. The Americans have lifted the trade embargo. All the European countries are trying to get in there, and the Japanese are getting in there. When we adopt these countries and they become the flavour of the month, we tend to neglect our traditional areas or we focus on an area that is not so popular.

Taiwan is a classic example. We are ignoring it. I have spoken on India before. We totally ignore the Indian market. When we think of India, we think of 600 million people living in poverty. What we do not think about is that India has a middle class of between 60 million and 80 million people with a disposable income as great as Australia's. It is a major market for us—a major market that we neglect because we are on this kick about countries that are flavour of the month. Talk about putting all our eggs in the one basket; that is what we are constantly doing.That is one of the reasons that I strongly supported the establishment of Badgerys Creek.

I have always argued that Badgerys Creek will not replace Kingsford Smith airport. It could be a major freight export facility. It has the infrastructure. It is beside the freeway. There has already been an announcement that it will be linked to Kingsford Smith airport by another freeway. Provision has been made for a rail network. It could be the major freight airport of Australia. It is something that we have not had in this country. If we are going to be serious about it, we have to stop looking at our region narrowly.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is at the table. He knows that I supported the inland port concept at Parkes. We could have rail coming from various parts of Australia. We could have it as an inland port, shooting goods north, south, east or west. If we wanted to ship them out, they could go through Port Kembla, of course—there is nothing parochial about me—or to the international freight airport at Badgerys Creek.

Until we start thinking more widely in Australia about export potentials, about the resources we have in this country and about the infrastructure—that is, not only what we have but what we should have—and take a broader view of the whole concept, we will not achieve the goal that we constantly talk about achieving of breaking into Asia. We say our economic future is tied up with Asia. I have no argument with that at all. Our economic future is tied up with Asia. Geographically, we are part of Asia. It is time that we had the infrastructure in rail, road and air to take advantage of that. By the construction of an international freight airport at Badgerys Creek, we most certainly will achieve this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The budget that we are debating today and the Working Nation statement which preceded it bring to 26 the number of statements that the government has introduced on economic and employment issues since it came to power. That makes 26 magic pudding solutions, each one of which we were guaranteed would institute a new era of prosperity and wipe away all of our previous problems. They were all introduced with very grand rhetoric. A classic example is the words which the Treasurer (Mr Willis) used to introduce the budget speech. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget that I present tonight will:
maximise economic growth;
reduce unemployment;
promote social justice; and
reduce the budget deficit, without increasing taxes.

What a wonderful series of promises! What a remarkable formula this budget was going to provide for the future of Australia! If it were going to achieve those sorts of objectives, I am sure it would have been greeted with great enthusiasm by the Australian people. But, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said, his whiteboard is still empty; nobody bothered to ring to say what a wonderful budget it was. The budget has made no impact on the Australian people at all.

PARA.TAB: My experience in my own office has been very similar to that of the honourable member for Throsby. The budget has created very little interest and very little enthusiasm. True, there have been calls from veterans who are concerned about the future of their entitlements because of the reductions in veterans expenditure that are included in the budget, and there are concerns about a number of other issues, but basically the budget has made a very limited impact. I am afraid that that has been very much par for the course for all of these 26 government statements. Many of them have caused great concern in the community just because they have achieved so very little.

Let us think back over time to all of the separate labour programs that have been devised to solve our nation's unemployment difficulties. I am told that 45 separate labour programs have been invented by the Labor government. Honourable members have heard of things like jobtrain, jobsearch, jobstart, newstart, skillshare, skillscope, CEP, SEVS, CDEP, NIES, LEAP, REAP, the job compact, CEIS, Nettforce, JET—the list just goes on and on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any real jobs amongst them?

—Certainly one—inventing imaginative titles for all of these schemes. Great imagination is shown by the government in inventing new titles but, sadly, few of these schemes have achieved anything really worthwhile for the Australian people. I sometimes wonder whether they are designed to amuse the unemployed in the hope that some international recovery may sweep over the government's incompetence and build some growth into our national economy in spite of the government's policies. None of these programs will achieve those objectives.

PARA.TAB: When we have large numbers of unemployed it is important that they spend the time when they are not properly occupied in developing their skills, maintaining their spirits and developing strategies which may be helpful to them in the long term. So it is useful to have these sorts of programs. I am not critical of the job creation schemes on that score. What I am critical of is the flamboyant rhetoric that is usually associated with these schemes, rhetoric about what they are going to achieve in a worthwhile way for the Australian population, for the unemployed and for our national economy. In reality the grandiose rhetoric does not create jobs. The flamboyant claims do not create jobs. What we clearly need to do in this country is to develop the sorts of policies which create lasting productive work in the community and not just artificial jobs that last only as long as the taxpayers are prepared to keep paying the bill.

The unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed, have naturally become greatly discouraged after years of unemployment. No-one any longer believes the government when it comes out with yet another program that is going to solve the problems of the past. It is a bit like the boy who cried wolf. We have been promised so many times the magic pudding solution and yet it never occurs. I know that over the last month or two there have been some improved jobs statistics. They are welcome. However, it needs to be remembered that unemployment figures from now on are artificial because they do not accurately reflect the true number of people out of work. Those people who have been involved in training programs are no longer counted among the unemployed. Those who receive the new mature age allowance—the premature retirement scheme for the unemployed—are not counted as unemployed. Those involved in the artificial job creation schemes are not counted as unemployed. Those Aborigines working on the community development program are not counted as unemployed. Those who have been moved onto disability pensions and the like are not counted as unemployed. Those who have just given up looking are not counted as unemployed. Anyone who has worked for one hour in the previous week is not counted as unemployed.

So when we add all of those people to the official 900,000 or thereabouts unemployed, the true number of those in Australia seeking work, seeking more meaningful employment, is very much higher indeed. There is nothing in this budget that will offer any hope to those who are unemployed that there may be a better future ahead. There is nothing for their job prospects. I ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, what I am to say to the 11.8 per cent of the people of Wide Bay, my electorate, who are out of work—up to 22 per cent in some of the larger centres in the electorate. What hope is there for them in this budget? They do not want any more training programs and they do not want early retirement; they want real productive jobs so that they can contribute to the national economy, so that they can help build real wealth, and so are able not only to plan for their own future but also contribute to their community.

The centrepiece of this budget is the alleged 4.5 per cent growth that our economy is going to achieve over the next 12 months, a growth largely built on improved international activity. But central to this growth is a 14 1/2 per cent increase in business investment. Yet there are no measures in the budget to actually stimulate such business investment. There is nothing there to encourage business to go out and invest, to build this increase in the national economy around which the budget is based. Indeed, perhaps the only measure that has been around over recent times to stimulate investment, the investment allowance, will be axed from the end of this month. There will be no investment allowance, no incentive to invest whatsoever. The only thing that is in this budget for business is higher taxes. That is the typical Labor recipe for the future—more taxes, as though somehow or other the more revenue the government collects the better off the nation is. The typical ALP budget strategy is spend more, tax more.

But I notice that even the Labor government now is concerned about the philosophy behind its budget. The headline in this morning's Financial Review was, `Government gets jitters over economy'. If it has not got the jitters about the economy and about its own budget, it certainly ought to. Foreign debt is up. The government's answer to that will apparently be a new education program to try to persuade the Australian people that a debt of $244 billion somehow or other does not matter. Investment is down. In spite of the fact that this budget is built on increased investment, the first figures that come out after the budget show a decline in business investment. The trade figures remain woeful. Once again, the worst part of those figures is the failure for there to be any improvement in relation to imports of plant and equipment, which were supposed to be the centrepiece of our business growth.

Interest rates are set to rise. The government's response? The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is starting on a new bank bashing exercise, blaming the banks because the government has once again let the economy get out of control. The industrial relations legislation is so discouraging employers from even considering adding to their work force that any prospects of job growth are being killed off right at the beginning. This horrific type of legislation provides no incentive whatsoever for business to invest. Business investment of 14 1/2 per cent is totally unrealistic when the government's own policies seem to be designed to quell investment rather than to encourage it.

This budget is the biggest taxing budget in our national history. The Treasurer told us on budget night that there were no new taxes in this budget. That is not entirely true; there are new taxes on aviation, there are new taxes on businesses, there is a threatened new tax on the fishing industry and a range of other similar measures. But the government did not need to introduce new taxes in this budget given all the new taxes which were in last year's budget, many of which only take effect in this financial year. Many of them are indexed so there are guaranteed increases in the budget revenue.

This budget demonstrates very powerfully the effect of indexation and bracket creep. If governments do not actually reduce tax rates every year they collect more revenue just by relying on the natural growth in the community and inflation. So, in spite of a no new taxes budget, personal income tax receipts are up by 8 per cent, company tax is up 7 per cent, superannuation funds taxes are up 27 per cent, sales tax revenue is up 8 per cent, fuel excise is up another 13 per cent, and fringe benefits tax is up a whopping 131 per cent.

All of these massive rises in tax revenue will mean that for the first time in our national history a government will collect over $100 billion in tax revenue from the Australian people—$103.3 billion. All this has been achieved without any public new taxes. In reality, though, there is an enormous increase in the depth to which Labor's tax office will reach into every Australian's pocket to collect more revenue for the government's big spending programs. The government that gave us capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, bank debits tax, superannuation taxes, training guarantee levies, Medicare levies, resource rent taxes, HECS payments and a whole range of others will dig further into our pockets to collect even more revenue for its big spending programs.

In spite of the $100 billion that the government is collecting from taxpayers this year, there will still be an $11.7 billion budget deficit. That is an enormous future debt which will have to be carried by future generations of Australian taxpayers. The government would have had to increase taxes on every working Australian by $2,000 just to balance this year's budget—let alone doing anything about the debt that has been accumulated over previous years.

Perhaps the most frightening economic statistic coming out of this budget is that, by the end of this financial year, the Commonwealth government's own debt will be $96 billion. One of the biggest increases in this year's budget is a 36 per cent increase in the cost of servicing the government's own debt. This $96 billion has grown from $30 billion in just five years due to the government's big spending programs which will have to be paid for by future generations of Australian taxpayers.

For the first time in our national history we have had a decade of Labor government. In the past we have had short, intermittent periods of big spending and poor management by a Labor government. This country has now experienced 10 years of appalling economic management, and the legacy of that already is $96 billion worth of debt which future generations will have to repay. This federal government is going down exactly the same spending path as did Burke and Lawrence in Western Australia, Cain and Kirner in Victoria, Bannon in South Australia, Wran in New South Wales and, of course, Goss in Queensland. The government has big spending programs, but it concentrates that expenditure on social engineering, top-heavy bureaucracies and empty welfare. It does nothing to rebuild the national economy.

We still have a $2.4 billion target for asset sales. The government has never achieved its targets for asset sales in the past, and no-one really believes that it will do it this time. In this budget it is selling Qantas for the third time. It has never achieved its objective. We have just heard the honourable member for Throsby saying that he will lie down in front of the sale of airports. That again throws this particular part of the budget estimates into disarray.

The particularly alarming feature of the sale of government assets relates to where the money will actually go. I think it is reasonable to sell off many government assets. It is quite acceptable to put forward an argument that there is no reason why the government needs to be the owner of some of these assets. But when we sell off our assets to pay this year's unemployment benefits, we are clearly going downhill. When we sell off the back paddock to pay this year's bills, we are clearly destroying our revenue opportunities for the future and damaging the government's capacity to balance future budgets. If $2.4 billion were being spent on building new national infrastructure or developing a strategy to guarantee our national future, then I would be supporting it. But this $2.4 billion will be all gone at the end of the year. It will be used to pay this year's unemployment benefits. That is clearly a nonsense strategy.

One of the other very disappointing aspects of this particular budget is the government's response to regional development. The government led us to believe that its Kelty report was going to welcome a new era of commitment to regional issues, that the profile of these matters would be raised and that the government would make a real commitment to redressing some of the imbalance and unfairness that its policies currently direct towards regional Australia. The Kelty report was a glossy publication of four volumes. It really was little more than a multi-billion dollar wish list. It promised ports, airports, railways and a four-lane highway from Adelaide to Cairns. They are all wonderful projects. Many of them are thoroughly worthy of support.

What has the government provided towards this multibillion dollar wish list, this new turnaround in government attitudes towards regional Australia? It has provided a miserable $10 million, followed by $20 million in subsequent years. So these billions and billions of dollars worth of projects approved by the Kelty report will have to compete for a miserable $10 million. Is that not an extraordinary response compared with the $800 million that was made available for the better cities fantasy? In fact, $200 million of this year's budget is allocated to building better cities, but only $10 million is allocated to building a better regional Australia. That says something about the government's priorities when it comes to building a better country.

About $71 million is provided in the budget for urban and regional development, but $25 million of that will be spent in Canberra. Labor's definition of regional Australia seems to be that Canberra comes first and any money left over can go to the rest of the nation. It is quite clear that Labor's regional affairs policy is only empty rhetoric. There are glossy publications, but there is nothing really there to back up the empty words. Certainly regional Australia feels very depressed about the government's response to the crucial issues affecting their part of the country.

The government's promised commitment to expenditure in regional Australia is entirely wiped out by perhaps one of the most appalling aspects of the budget; that is, the enormous rise in fuel excise revenue. Under this budget, Labor will take more from regional Australia in the form of extra fuel excise than it will return by way of infrastructure or other contributions. That clearly indicates what the government thinks of regional Australia: it is a source of fuel excise revenue. The government is only interested in where it can get the taxes from. It is not interested in its contribution to the national economy and what it can do to help build a better Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has cut road funding too.

—That is right. Over $10 billion will be collected from the Australian people in the form of fuel excise and other fuel taxation. In return for that, Australia will get only $820 million by way of road funding. So regional Australia will get nothing by way of developing new infrastructure. The amount of money provided for roads will not be enough even to deal with the maintenance on the existing road infrastructure, let alone the provision of any new developments. This is a very great disappointment for rural and regional Australia. The budget offers nothing. Sadly, it offers nothing for all Australians. Labor could not run a general store, a travel agency or a petrol station—
—Or a sandwich shop.

—It had an industry minister who could not run a sandwich shop and has a Prime Minister who cannot run a pigsty. Yet these are the people who are entrusted with running our national economy. After 10 years, the government has delivered this nation almost $100 billion of Commonwealth debt. (Time expired)

—I want to make it clear that opposition representations about the budget—and these have also been reflected in statements by state members—have been very misleading to the Australian public. First of all, those opposite talk about $820 million being allocated by the federal government to roads with $10 billion being collected in the form of excises, registrations and licences around the country. Much more than $820 million of taxpayers' money is going to roads. Because of the premiers' agreement with the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, general revenue funds are now going to roads and being spent by the states. This sort of misleading remark does nothing to further the progress of government in Australia. It does not mention the benefits of the federal system that we now have. All sorts of misleading statements can be made.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the total expenditure on roads. For instance, road trauma in Australia is estimated to cost $6 billion a year. That is being paid by taxpayers all over Australia, by people who contribute to Medicare through their levies. The total expenditure on roads is approximately $4.7 billion. It is quite clear that what is being spent on roads is roughly what is being received from roads by all levels of government throughout Australia. So we should not be too misleading about the transfer of funds from one government to another and the effect of that. We cannot just say that only $820 million of taxpayers' money is being spent on roads.

I want to be more optimistic. I want to be optimistic about things that have been mentioned in the parliament today, like regional development. The exciting opportunities that are available for regional development are not lost on most honourable members that I have talked to and I believe should not be lost on honourable members on the other side of the House. It gives them great opportunities, it gives the nation great opportunities and it gives our local regions great opportunities. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) now has the housing and regional development portfolio. This portfolio has taken parts of the industry, primary industry and community services portfolios. Because of this combination in the one portfolio under the Deputy Prime Minister there are some great opportunities for regions in Australia.

The government has just appointed its own policy committee on housing and regional development and is about to appoint members to it. Under the program announced in the budget there are opportunities for strategies which give flexibility to be developed. Sunraysia will probably never be a Labor electorate. It was not so long ago that the Mallee electorate, for instance, was the safest coalition seat in Australia—something like your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, on the government side.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the members? A very good member.

—I am not commenting on the members. I lived there for a long time and they were pretty good members in Sunraysia over those years. I am commenting on the ability of the people in Sunraysia to get their act together. Going over the border to the seat of Riverina, I understand that is also included in the great regional development proposal that has come up in Sunraysia where land-holders, councils and industry have cooperated to increase farm size. The Mildura winery is increasing its production of its beautiful wine by 33 per cent a year.

PARA.TAB: We have consolidated farms and taken into account both sides of the border. This is the sort of flexibility that I have seen in my own region. I had a meeting with regional councils last week. They were talking about having the flexibility to deal with people across the Victorian border in Orbost and Bairnsdale local government areas and having the flexibility to deal with the ACT government on matters of common interest.

There will be great challenges in this region around the ACT. Queanbeyan and the ACT will come close to population saturation certainly by the end of the century. There will be a need to look at infrastructure, water, sewerage, education and health for people who live over the border. We will need to cooperate. In fact, I believe we will need not just a forum, which exists now, but an across border planning authority—a Canberra and south-east region planning authority. People are prepared to talk about that and cooperate with the government over the border.

There needs to be federal, state, local and territory cooperation so that we have the flexibility to develop a strategy for our region. That is what this money is for. If people take advantage of it, they are going to be ready just as Sunraysia and the Goulburn Valley—another National Party electorate—were. In two National Party electorates people, industry and local government had a proposal ready for government. When the appropriate time comes state, federal or local government can be ready to take up those proposals separately or in cooperation.

People can now see that it is worth thinking about where they want to go, what they want to do and the future—not just short term but longer term strategies. There is funding not only for strategy development but also for the provision of information. For instance, to speed up planning processes in local government they will be able to get information from the federal government. People will be working on speeding up those planning processes.

What is important here is the radical change from the attitude on regional development of previous years. Government is saying, `This needs to come from you. We're not going to do the work. You people are on the ground, you need to do the work to prepare a case for yourselves. Tell us what you ought to be doing in your own local area. It will be from the bottom up.' If honourable members on both sides of the House are prepared to work with local government and have those ideas ready for government to take up, there will be great benefits for their electorates.

There are some other matters within my own region which ought to be mentioned. I can see some great benefits from proposed government expenditure for the timber industry. The timber industry will now be able to be involved with an advisory group to tell government how it should be spending funds of up to $10 million in association with the restructuring of the south-east forest industries. Again we need to have across border links with what is happening in Victoria.

The discussions on the proposed south-east forest advisory group are close to completion. That group is going to include industry, government at all levels, unions, conservationists and community representation and will be advising on that expenditure. That is an important move that has taken place following federal and state cooperation in coming up with an agreement on the south-east forests.

In the fishing area there are some moves towards aquaculture. Production from fishing in Australia has been falling. It is important that we develop aquaculture: there are proposals being developed along the south-east coast of New South Wales and in other areas of Australia. Perry Smith, in the latest Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics report, has said that the key factor for the fishing industry is whether supplies from aquaculture can be increased from present levels. Production promotions have been falling. Mr Smith said that Australia is in a good strategic position to capitalise on the opportunities that will be presented over the next few years on both export and domestic markets. Overseas demand for seafood is expected to remain strong in the medium term and a lower dollar has helped.

The dairy industry is also showing progress with production of milk on the south coast and tablelands of New South Wales to April up 10.91 per cent for the financial year. Sales are also higher for those districts. The cooperation within the industry on the sale and distribution of flavoured milk and accountability of bulk fresh cream provision, particularly in Sydney, has assisted the industry. It is very good that, as a result of a new school milk campaign, 19,000 litres of a new brand of milk called Dynomite has been sold in the Wollongong test market.

I welcome the way in which Bega and other suppliers to the Canberra milk market have financially supported the Canberra Raiders rugby league team. I think the brand name Dynomite would look pretty good on the backs of the Canberra Raiders players' jerseys.

The cattle industry is probably as good as it has been in the last 10 years. The meat and livestock industry will benefit from the GATT round. I was pleased that the delegation to Europe, including the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair)—I will not go into the names of all the members, but he was the deputy leader of the delegation—was able to have useful talks on GATT and was able to, I believe, turn around the attitude of the European parliament on kangaroo imports. The parliament actually had a draft proposal to totally ban all kangaroo imports, whether they were meat or other kangaroo products, having been misinformed that the kangaroo was an endangered species. It is only five or six species which are endangered. We made it clear to its members that there are plenty of other species which are not endangered at all and for which there are culling programs.

Wool prospects are very good, with the market indicator at 615c a kilogram and 1050c for 19-micron wool. This is partly because the wool stockpile is no longer distorting or contributing to uncertainty. New arrangements have been put in place. Wool International has spent effort on forward selling. This has added depth to the market through a greater variety of selling mechanisms. As well as that, changes to the western European economy are feeding through; western Europe is buying more wool. Japan's buying is slow but it is also showing good prospects. There have also been some useful inquiries and purchasing from eastern Europe and China.

The seniors health card is going to take effect from 1 July. This is long overdue, particularly for the retirement areas of electorates around Australia. Lower income people who do not currently receive a pension will welcome the fact that they can now apply for a Commonwealth seniors health card. From 1 July this year health card holders will be able to get a range of benefits and services, including pharmaceutical prescriptions; hearing aids through Australian Hearing Services; and access to a new two-phase Commonwealth dental program, which has an emergency dental scheme and a general dental scheme as well.

The seniors health card will help many older people who have reached age pension age and who meet the pension income test but are not entitled to the pension because their assets are too high or because they have not lived in Australia long enough to meet the resident requirement for the pension. The card is also going to benefit people whose income would allow them to get a small age pension but who choose not to claim for personal reasons. People should contact the Department of Social Security in their area and apply for a Commonwealth seniors health card if they think that they may be eligible, and they have the knowledge that there will not be assets testing on this card.

I also welcome some changes which have taken place for unemployed people. I have previously said something about this matter. I welcome the job compact which is available for people aged 18 years or over who have been receiving allowances for more than 18 months. They are required to meet a reciprocal obligation to accept any reasonable job placement offer or lose entitlement to income support for a period. As well as that, there will be assistance for non job compact people who have not been unemployed for that long. There will be much better case management for individual unemployed people.

The combination of support which has been given to our regions, including the enormous amount of support which has been given to unemployed people—I know there remains a lot more to be done—and the prospects for industry that come not only from the economic recovery which has occurred but also from the general optimism out there in the electorates really means that the budget has deservedly been pretty well received.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I want to focus on foreign affairs matters, in particular the United Nations system for preserving global peace and security. In my speech on last year's appropriation bill I addressed the question of the reform of the United Nations system, with particular emphasis on its peacekeeping activities. Nine months later I very much regret to say that there has been little progress towards a more effective United Nations peacekeeping capability. In particular, the continuing tragedies in Bosnia and now Rwanda appear to mock UN efforts.

PARA.TAB: Goaded by the Bosnian Serb siege of the UN declared safe haven of Gorazde, in April the international community increased pressure on the factions in Bosnia to reach a negotiated solution. A contact group comprising the United States, Russia and the European Community nations was established to coordinate the international approach to peacekeeping and peace negotiations in former Yugoslavia. This symbolised the emergence of a new international consensus and resolve on the issue. Russian involvement had previously been instrumental in bringing about the lifting of the siege of Sarajevo.

At the same time, the United Nations Security Council agreed to the dispatch of a further 6,500 United Nations troops to former Yugoslavia, demonstrating the UN's continuing commitment to peacekeeping. The Security Council also agreed to broaden NATO's mandate to permit air strikes against Bosnian Serb forces and weapons threatening UN declared safe havens, demonstrating the UN's increased determination to use force against Bosnian Serb defiance of the United Nations. This marked a significant increase in the UN's willingness to use force against those who flout its directives.

Negotiations brokered by the United States aimed at establishing a federation between the Bosnian Muslims and Croats were crowned with success when on 11 May agreement was reached on the shape that the new federation would take. The Bosnian parliament is currently meeting to ratify the agreement. One could have reasonably hoped that this renewed concentration by the international community on the situation in Bosnia would have borne fruit. Unfortunately, as I speak, the prospects for peace in Bosnia are not noticeably closer than they were a month ago.

Last week the contact group met with representatives of the Muslim-Croat federation and the Bosnian Serbs in France. At issue was the proposed division of Bosnia-Herzegovina between the two sides, as well as a proposal for an extended cease-fire. But these talks produced no agreement. UN brokered talks on the same issues are set to resume in Geneva on 2 June. But Bosnian President Izetbegovic has already cast doubts over Muslim-Croat participation on the grounds that the Bosnian Serb army continues to maintain troops in the exclusion zone around Gorazde. Against this depressing background, there have been renewed threats by the French and the British, who provide the bulk of the UN peacekeeping force in Bosnia—UNPROFOR, as it is referred to—that they will withdraw their troops by the end of the year unless substantial progress has been made towards a settlement.

The coalition's policy on former Yugoslavia has three key elements: support for all UN action in support of a negotiated solution, and the provision by Australia of humanitarian relief; support for the UN arms embargo on the grounds that its lifting would endanger UN peacekeepers in Bosnia and jeopardise UN humanitarian relief activities; and agreement with the government's refusal to commit Australian military personnel to UNPROFOR. The coalition does appreciate the great difficulties—extreme difficulties—that the UN has been labouring under in former Yugoslavia and at present sees no viable alternative to the policy outlined above. On each and every point one could raise differing arguments, and there is a balance either side of it, but at the moment we hold to the policy the key elements of which I have just enunciated. But the fact that key players like France and Britain have come to the despairing conclusion that they may have to withdraw from UNPROFOR underlies the urgency of the need for the international community to find more effective ways of intervening in such conflicts.

The tragedy in Rwanda continues and the part the international community has played—not so much in trying to alleviate the suffering of refugees who have fled the country, but in attempting to protect internally displaced persons and to ensure the delivery of humanitarian assistance inside the country—has raised fresh questions about the capacity of the United Nations to react effectively to such crises. I have already stated elsewhere that the coalition supports the government's decision to provide $1.5 million in emergency relief assistance to Rwandan refugees. Indeed, I specifically called upon the government to provide such assistance. I have also called upon the government to keep the situation under review so that it can provide further assistance as required.

The government's reaction to the UN's request for contributions has ranged from the positive to the cautious. Initially, Senator Gareth Evans undertook to view the UN request `very sympathetically' but, on 24 May, Senator Ray said that government policy had changed. Senator Ray said that Australia would now only contribute, firstly, if the United Nations had a clear mission; secondly, if the UN had a clear timetable for any commitment; and, thirdly, if a political resolution process between the Rwandan government and the RPF were in place. Even then, Senator Ray said, Australian Defence Force personnel would be committed only if their security were to be `assured'.

I do not want to make too much of the contrast between Senator Evans's initial reaction and Senator Ray's more measured approach. But I will mention that, again in my speech on last year's appropriation bill, I pointed out that there was a contradiction between the activist approach to peacekeeping advocated by Senator Evans in his blue book, published last year, and Senator Ray's distinctly cautious view of such activism.

The coalition appreciates the need for caution. It absolutely appreciates such a caution—there are lives at stake—before committing Australian Defence Force personnel to situations where they might be at risk. I have already stated elsewhere that it would be premature for Australia to commit military personnel without knowing details of the structure, composition and command arrangements. Nevertheless, the coalition remains disposed in favour of Australia fulfilling its international responsibilities in Rwanda.
