Senator Ray has already commented on the reasons for the delay in the government coming to a decision on whether Australia should make a contribution and, if it did, what form the contribution should take. But, given the fact that there is widespread concern about the plight of the people of Rwanda to the extent that organisations such as Community Aid Abroad and Care Australia have advocated an Australian commitment to the United Nations force, I call upon the government to explain in detail the factors influencing its consideration of the issue. I assume it has a great deal to do with the UN itself not making up its mind, which is part of the problem I was touching on earlier; and I assume that it also has to do with the disagreement between the UN and the US as to what the UN Secretary-General had in mind when he met with the US President last week. But the parliament needs to be told and the people ought to be informed.

Bosnia and Rwanda, therefore, are examples of where the United Nations peacekeeping efforts have not met with success. I do not say this with any pleasure because I am a great supporter of the UN system—as a former Vice-President of the United Nations General Assembly, it gives me no pleasure to reflect on an organisation to which I am committed—but it needs significant improvement. Bosnia, Rwanda and Somalia all posed the UN challenges on questions such as national sovereignty and the organisation of international forces that it has been quite unable to meet to date.

The case of Cambodia, however, is one where the intervention of the United Nations was highly successful. But, regrettably, it also illustrates that even the best efforts of the UN cannot overcome intractable domestic political disputes. A year after United Nations supervised elections, the situation in Cambodia is failing to fulfil expectations of stability and prosperity generated by the election of the coalition CPP-Funcinpec government and the emergence of democracy.

To those who are aware of their history, particularly Khmer history, Cambodian history and recent history, it is a chilling fact that the Khmer Rouge in certain areas now has a presence further inside Cambodia than it has had at any stage since the Vietnamese invasion of 1979. The coalition has already publicly supported the government's decision to consider Cambodia's request for appropriate military assistance to help defend the new government against the Khmer Rouge. The coalition has also called on the government to provide adequate development assistance, including for de-mining, to Cambodia.

Another area of grave international concern beyond Cambodia and our own region is that of North Korea. Reports in recent days that North Korea has removed fuel from a reactor at Yongbyon, without international monitors being present, have again raised the possibility of United Nations sanctions being imposed upon Pyongyang. In such a delicate situation, the coalition calls on all parties concerned to resolve their differences through dialogue and negotiation. But, again, North Korea's brinkmanship has posed the United Nations a challenge to which that organisation has no ready answer.

The coalition believes that, with the threat of global nuclear war diminished—but not, it must be stressed, eliminated entirely—it is the potential proliferation of nuclear weapons that now poses the greatest nuclear threat to regional peace and stability. North Korea is strongly suspected of developing nuclear weapons and is developing ballistic missiles capable of delivering them onto targets in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and China. North Korea epitomises the dangers of nuclear proliferation.

Therefore, the coalition believes it to be of the utmost importance that international mechanisms to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons be strengthened. In this regard, the coalition supports the indefinite extension of the non-proliferation treaty, which is coming up for review in 1995; accelerating the work on a comprehensive test ban treaty; the missile technology control regime; and the work of the International Atomic Energy Agency. Building international support for these international treaties and organisations and ensuring compliance with them are our best hopes for containing nuclear proliferation.

The conflict in Bougainville, though outside the purview of the United Nations, also raises the question of the role the international community can play in ending conflicts. The key elements of the coalition's policy on Bougainville remain, firstly, concern over allegations of human rights abuses by the Papua New Guinea defence force and the Bougainville revolutionary army and, secondly, support for Papua New Guinea sovereignty and territorial integrity, including its right to conduct its internal affairs without external interference.

The coalition is concerned about allegations of human rights abuses on Bougainville by both the Papua New Guinea defence force and the BRA. The coalition has consistently called on the government to urge the Papua New Guinea government to observe internationally accepted human rights standards. The coalition does not accept, however, allegations that Australia has materially contributed to an ongoing `state of civil war' on Bougainville. It does not accept the view that Papua New Guinea defence force operations on Bougainville have only or even largely been made possible because of the provision of military equipment by Australia or Australian military assistance to the Papua New Guinea government.

The coalition has consistently called on all parties to the conflict on Bougainville to work towards a negotiated solution to that conflict and will support any initiative towards that end. The coalition welcomed Prime Minister Wingti's decision to invite an Australian parliamentary delegation to visit Bougainville and participated in it. Senator Calvert and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) from the coalition were in the delegation. I would have liked to attend, but I had to be elsewhere. The coalition also supported the government's recent decision to offer up to $10 million, matching a contribution by the Papua New Guinea government, to rehabilitation and reconstruction efforts on Bougainville.

I have noted Deputy Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan's 27 May proposal that a South Pacific peacekeeping force, drawn from Fiji, Tonga and Vanuatu, be deployed in Bougainville. Such a force could help establish a climate in which negotiations aimed at bringing about a political resolution to the dispute between the Papua New Guinea government and the BRA could achieve progress. I have seen reports that the Papua New Guinea government will ask the Australian government for funding and logistic support for the initiative. I also understand that, as yet, no formal request has been made. If it were to be made, the coalition would be likely to endorse Australia providing such assistance for a South Pacific peacekeeping force. Sir Julius's proposal is a welcome demonstration of Papua New Guinea's flexibility and resolve to reach a negotiated solution to the Bougainville crisis.

Returning now to the United Nations, I am concerned that its 50th anniversary is drawing closer but it seems increasingly unlikely we can achieve the full reform agenda by the time of the 50th birthday. Meanwhile, domestic concern is growing in Australia with respect to United Nations treaties. There has been a steady increase in the number of United Nations treaties entered into by Australia during the last 10 years of the Hawke and Keating Labor governments. Major industry groups, as an example, have expressed concerns that the government does not follow a sufficiently open approach to foreign treaty making—and I have considerable sympathy with those views.

There is a clear and a growing problem associated with the lack of accountability to parliament for treaties entered into by the executive. Indeed, not all treaties have even to be considered formally by cabinet. Additionally, the High Court's extended interpretation of the external affairs power under the constitution has enormously expanded the power of the Commonwealth government to override the states, thus compelling a change in the way the Commonwealth government enters into treaties; it compels the need for reform of the way in which it enters into treaties.

Furthermore, the fact is that UN treaties, being multilateral solutions to worldwide problems, do not necessarily reflect the full extent of Australia's particular interests in these problems. We have limited input into, and limited control over, the drafting of such treaties and, as Senator Gareth Evans admitted in Senate estimates hearings last week, we win some and we lose some. Recently, for example, on the Basel convention on hazardous waste Australia simply got rolled, to put it bluntly. Yet our accession to such treaties can seriously compromise Australia's legal independence.

The coalition has shown concern about potential intrusion into our legal system resulting from the so-called optional protocol of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which enables Australians to take complaints to the United Nations Human Rights Committee. Private industry concerns have also been expressed with respect to the Australian negotiating position on a number of international environmental issues. It is most disturbing that, despite the government's repeated claims that it consults extensively with the full range of non-government groups interested in these matters, what I repeatedly hear is that these consultation processes are neither sufficient nor effective, and when they ultimately prove ineffective, as they did on the Basel convention, the government blames industry.

The onus is in fact fully and squarely on the government, and only the government, to ensure that Australia's overall national interests are protected in such matters and that effective processes of consultation are in place. Under some pressure on this issue, Senator Gareth Evans has recently introduced some minor bureaucratic changes in the treaty making processes. He has agreed, for example, to table a short explanatory document setting out the objectives and describing the nature of the particular convention concerned at the time when the bill implementing any such convention is introduced into parliament. This is just not good enough. This is just not soon enough in the process. Public debate should take place as early as practicable, preferably before negotiating positions are finalised. At the very least, parliament, and indeed the general public, should be informed before the point of ratification, and the states must be fully involved in the negotiating process from the start. As a strong personal supporter of the UN system, as I have said, and with long experience in the area, I find the present situation most unsatisfactory, to put it mildly.

I very much welcome this week's announcement that the Prime Minister will hold a round table with industry and environment representatives on the United Nations climate change convention. The coalition is committed to achievement of sustainable development and committed, in particular, to the objectives of the climate change convention. But, in my view, cabinet needs urgently to reconsider Australia's position and to finetune its approach to defending our economic and trade competitiveness interests under the convention.

As consensus emerges among the OECD countries to implement additional policy response measures to climate change, the existing caveat to Australia's negotiating position will no longer prove sufficient to protect our specific national interests, which is why the issue of equitable burden sharing is so important and why it is perfectly ridiculous for Senator Gareth Evans to be so proud of his comment in Senate Estimates Committee A on 25 May that the government has `flagged' its `concern' on this issue. The government clearly needs to do very much more. Despite its expressed recognition of our fossil fuel dependency—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate today on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1994-95. I find it difficult to isolate the topics that I would like to talk about because in both the Working Nation white paper and the federal budget brought down a couple weeks ago by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) there are so many positive initiatives that this government has outlined for tackling unemployment and other important major social issues that it would be doing an injustice to try to cover all of them. In the few moments that I have in this House I would like to concentrate on a couple of key areas.

PARA.TAB: I would like to talk about some of the important employment initiatives that were contained in the white paper and that have been funded in the Commonwealth budget. Of particular interest to me are those initiatives that I know from personal experience have had great success in the past and that have been considerably expanded. One area that has been given a significant boost in the budget and in the Working Nation document is new work opportunities in the environment. That boost is given in a number of ways.

The government has determined that the environment sector will be a key target area for new work opportunities. There is a new initiative in this area called the regional environment employment program. It will support regional consortiums of community groups, landcare groups, government and business to provide work experience and training in strategic environmental management and restoration projects. We already have in place a program along this line called LEAP, the landcare and environment action program.

I have had the opportunity and the pleasure to see a number of very successful LEAP projects started and completed in my electorate of Moreton. Just a couple of weeks ago I participated in a number of LEAP projects which involved cleaning up and restoring waterways, creeks and parks. It also involved the replanting of major new Australian native trees to replace some of the weeds and overgrown areas along those parks in suburbs such as Corinda. There is a major program at Nosworthy Park, where a number of young people have been involved in restoring an important community asset and making it, again, a viable asset for the whole community to enjoy. That has also occurred at Mount Gravatt, Sunnybank and a number of other places in my electorate.

The important thing about LEAP is that it involves young people. It is targeted at employing 15- to 19-year-olds who have been long-term unemployed and who have had no opportunities to gain work experience. The LEAP program involves active on-site work in cleaning up our community and planting trees and it also incorporates training in horticulture through environmental management programs. So it is a combined education program and work experience program which lasts for six months. Every person I have met—and I have talked to over 40 people in my electorate—who has been involved in this program has found it to be a very successful and viable program. I am pleased that in the federal budget and in the Working Nation document there has been a significant boost to the number of programs that will be funded over the next four years under LEAP.

The regional environment employment program, which will incorporate programs such as LEAP, is very important because not only does it get people actively working in the community fulfilling meaningful jobs but it also benefits the community by improving and cleaning up important valuable community assets such as waterways, creeks, parks, et cetera.

The government has also funded research by the Australian Conservation Foundation for further green jobs opportunities in the areas of waste and water management, ecotourism and energy auditing. The government funded that last financial year and funding will be extended into this financial year.

A commitment has been made for the ACF to test the research by placing 100 unemployed people in green jobs to obtain work experience and training through the jobskills program. The jobskills program is also a very important program which has been involved in giving training and employment opportunities to young people as well as cleaning up our community. Again, there has been a very successful jobskills program in the Toohey forest, in the electorate of Moreton. There are so many initiatives in the Working Nation document that bring great credit to this government. I am pleased to give my strong support to those initiatives.

I am also pleased about the additional support that has been given to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander job seekers in this budget. I have the privilege of chairing the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and my colleague the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) is a member. In the period that I have been on that committee we have visited many Aboriginal communities which are involved with CDEPs, community development employment programs.

These programs involve the local community getting together to bring about community improvements in the local area. The community takes charge of the unemployed in the area, looks at the areas of need in the local community, trains people and gets the local unemployed people working in the community to improve the resources and the facilities that are available in that community. It is basically a work for the dole scheme, but it is a scheme that is run voluntarily and it works very successfully. It means that in those Aboriginal communities the community and all the members in it are working together to benefit both the individuals within that community and the community as a whole.

This has been a very successful program and one that all Aboriginal communities around Australia have wanted to be involved with. I am pleased that in the budget and in the white paper there are measures for the considerable expansion of CDEP programs plus an additional $108.7 million provided over four years to ATSIC to expand and enhance employment and enterprise programs. The government will also be expanding the TAP program, the training for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander program, by giving it a further $190 million over the next four years. This will allow an additional 25,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to gain work experience in the community.

There have been a number of very positive initiatives in this budget. I know a number of my colleagues have spent time in this House talking about the range of other initiatives, but I wanted to give credit to the government for emphasising the importance of both the environment and Aboriginal employment programs.

I will now talk about the important initiatives in the budget relating to health and the land acquisition fund. There have been a lot of statements made of late about how much or how little money the government is putting towards Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. Those opposite have engaged in a bit of a political campaign, trying to attack the government on the amount of money it is committing to Aboriginal health. They have dared to criticise this government for the fact that it is increasing the amount of money for Aboriginal health by almost $500 million over the next five years. I find it quite ludicrous that the opposition would have the gall to come into this place and criticise this substantial increase in commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I know that we need a larger amount than that, and as part of this government I will certainly continue to fight for more funds. The opposition gains no credibility at all by coming into this place and attacking our programs to expend money on Aboriginal health. One just has to remember what the opposition had in its policy when it went to the last election. I know very well what the opposition was going to do. We only need to read Fightback—I know the Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), could slip Fightback out of the Prime Minister's drawer if he wanted; I know it will be in there, easily able to be exposed to public scrutiny—to see that the opposition was going to cut $90 million a year off Aboriginal programs, including employment, housing, education and health programs. It was going to cut $90 million a year at least from directly targeted Aboriginal programs as well as targeting Aboriginal communities in its attacks on social welfare programs.

Compare that to what this government is doing. We are not going to cut by $90 million a year; we are boosting by $100 million a year programs just in Aboriginal health—let alone the moneys I outlined before that will be allocated to employment programs, CDEP and others. This is the big contrast that this community and the people of Australia need to recognise when listening to the politics that the opposition plays with regard to Aboriginal affairs in this country. Its rhetoric does not match its performance.

I am very pleased that in this budget there has been a $500 million boost to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. But I place on the public record once more this important point: the Commonwealth is not solely responsible for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health nor is ATSIC solely responsible. As chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs I have already tabled in this House two reports which commented on the need for much greater coordination between all Commonwealth and state agencies in the delivery of services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

That is demonstrated more in the health area than in any other area. A lot of money is being provided by the Commonwealth to state and territory governments to deliver health services to all Australians. But, unfortunately, it appears to the government that a lot of state and territory governments are not providing the appropriate emphasis to Aboriginal communities in the provision of health services, whether they be direct medical services or environmental health services such as water supply, decent housing and garbage collection.

I have been to many Aboriginal communities across the length and breadth of this country, and wherever I have gone I have found that the local government authority or the state government has not put in place the types of resources that are required for that community. There is an expectation that ATSIC will look after everything. ATSIC is only given complementary funding to top up particular areas of disadvantage and need. It is not there to deliver mainstream services in every area of government.

All other government departments at the state and federal level have the responsibility to deliver services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as well as all other Australians. We need to recognise that this $500 million boost to Aboriginal health should be a complement to the existing funding that is provided both to the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health and to the state and territory departments of health. We need to get them working more fully with Aboriginal and Islander communities to target those areas of great disadvantage and great need. We need a much better level of coordination across state and federal agencies to ensure that those agencies are all identifying the appropriate resources that are required and putting those resources in place in those communities.

Let us not think that this $500 million boost to health over the next five years for Aboriginal and Islander people is going to solve everything. It certainly is not. There is still a long way to go. We also need to make sure that every dollar spent is spent appropriately and targeted properly and that the moneys that are currently allocated to all government agencies are spent where they are supposed to be spent—that is, for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as well as other Australians.

It is of great disappointment to me that those opposite have chosen to oppose the land acquisition fund—an important initiative contained in the budget. It reflects badly on the current coalition. For many years in this place there has been a bipartisan position on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander welfare and programs.

The land acquisition fund is not the first example of the federal government being involved in establishing funds to purchase properties or land for Aboriginal people. In fact, in 1974 the Whitlam government's Aboriginal Land Fund Bill enabled the Aboriginal affairs department to purchase cattle properties or other areas of land, outside of reserve land that had already been set aside for Aboriginal people, so that Aboriginal people could be engaged in farming techniques or other forms of economic development for their communities. The 1974 bill flowed from a commitment of the McMahon Liberal-Country Party government to give Aboriginal people `the opportunity of access to specific areas of land to use and develop for economic and social purposes'. The former member for Gwydir, Ralph Hunt, in his contribution to the debate, said of the original government process:

Within the reserves of the Northern Territory—and there are 92,000 square miles of them—we have, I think, one-third of the Aboriginal people. The areas are encompassed by the boundaries of these reserves were arbitrarily drawn by white legislators. They took no account of the conflicting needs or rights of the Aboriginal clans at all. We always sensed that there would be some difficulty in trying to apply this land rights principle to Aborigines living off reserves. To overcome that problem it was resolved that we should set up a land fund to buy for Aborigines off reserves both in the Northern Territory and in the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1974 Aboriginal Land Fund Bill was supported by the coalition and the Labor government. It was a smaller version of what we are considering today. The land acquisition fund provided for in this budget is about providing for the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who have been totally dispossessed of their land an opportunity to recover some of that land and to be involved once more in the land that they find so important to their spiritual and cultural needs.

PARA.TAB: A central objective of the land fund is to encourage greater self-reliance for indigenous people and to remedy the past injustices that no-one in this place could disagree have occurred to them. The Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody highlighted this point very succinctly in describing the levels of disposession and disempowerment when it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Colonial takeover denied Aboriginal people the right to live by their own rules, to decide their own policies. They were denied to run their own economic and family life. They were also denied the right to own land, to earn secure living as farmers, as merchants, or in the labour market at their own discretion, to earn a family wage, to receive welfare benefits, to live where they pleased. Under various policies their private reproductive lives were under scrutiny by government and missionary officials. They could not necessarily marry the person they chose, fraternise with people of their choice, speak to people of a certain skin colour, live in a particular street or on a particular reserve. They could not decide how many people they shared their house with. They were not eligible for old age pensions, for workers' compensation, for maternity allowances or child endowment. Even when legislation on such matters changed in the 1940s and 1950s, it was often the manager of the mission or reserve rather than the individual who was paid this money. They could not run their own bank accounts. Anyone who objected could end up hundreds of kilometres away or imprisoned for an unknown time. After release, they could be again banished from their families. The law extended its arm into the bedroom and the post-natal ward. Children were taken from their mothers after birth, others were taken once they reached the age of three or four years. Many Aboriginal families were thus denied the right to nurture, to rear and educate, to love their own children, to see them grow up. They lost these children, and the children became lost themselves. Who were they? Often children had been taught to detest everything Aboriginal, and this could extend to themselves once they realised that their skin was not white.

This quote comes from the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I think it sums up the massive level of dispossession and injustice that Aboriginal people have suffered. I recognise that the government should address many areas dealing with Aboriginal needs, including health, education and housing.

PARA.TAB: People have to understand—this was significant in the Native Title Act and the Mabo decision of the High Court—that we cannot build a fairer and more decent society for Aboriginal people until we end the basic injustices that they have suffered over the 205 years of colonial European rule in this country. When we came here, we took the land off Aboriginals. Mabo recognised at long last that they were here; that they did exist; that they had possession of this land; and that we took it off them. Mabo ended the fiction that they did not exist.

To improve upon that, we now have to act to restore some of that dispossession and give Aboriginal people some semblance of rights in our community. That is why we need to address the land acquisition fund as well as health, housing and education issues. Unless we address their rights of ownership of land and that basic tenet of their social and cultural life, we cannot succeed in dealing with other important issues. I am delighted that the land acquisition fund has been supported and introduced in this budget. I urge the coalition to reassess its position and to think carefully. It should look back at its position of the last 30 or 40 years and at the fact that we have had that bipartisan support. I say to the coalition, `Please reassess your position.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly reply on the Aboriginal matters raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). The Australian Labor Party claims or wishes to have bipartisanship only when it is in trouble or when it has doubts about the veracity of its policies. It does not matter whether it is immigration, human rights or Aboriginal matters; the plea for bipartisanship comes only at the times when it has difficulties with its policies.

PARA.TAB: What does the honourable member think he is putting to the House? Does he think that a fund which is three or four times the size of the amount being spent on Aboriginal health and which provides land for people—land that will not sustain them; land on which they will need housing and further support—is more important than having Aboriginals alive, being educated and in jobs? Are you seriously putting the proposition that it is three or four times more important in human terms to give people land even though they may be dying? You look at the mortality rates.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you are knowledgeable in this area as well. The mortality rates and the incidence of blindness, sickness and trachoma amongst Aboriginals are higher than those in the Australian community, but you say that we will create a fund that provides land for a favoured few friends of the Labor Party. That is the way it will finish, you will see.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—I am sure that the real traditional owners in many instances will not gain land. The black bureaucrats and friends of the Labor Party will be the only ones that get it. You mark my words, Mr Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer (Mr Willis) claims that this budget will maximise economic growth, reduce unemployment, promote social justice and reduce the budget deficit without increasing taxes. What an incredible set of goals and objectives this budget sets out to achieve! Just in one document in one year the government expects to maximise economic growth, to reduce unemployment, to promote social justice and to reduce the budget deficit without increasing taxes.

In the short time that has passed since the budget was introduced—in that time we have had the response from the then Leader of the Opposition—there has been a significant slump of investment of over seven per cent. So the basis on which the budget was founded, a growth of 14.5 per cent in business investment, is starting to cause some concern in financial circles. People are worrying whether the budget will hang together. In terms of maximising economic growth at this point, there is a real question mark over whether the government's targets for growth will be met.

The reduction in unemployment is a government goal, but it seems to me that it is more an objective of fancy bookkeeping—training, education and work experience—than real jobs and real opportunities to participate in the workplace. In my view there does not appear to be a real growth in jobs, which is claimed by the government to be one of its objectives. The government claims it wants to reduce unemployment. It will actually reduce the number of people on unemployment lists and in statistics, but it will not reduce the number of unemployed.

This budget, it is claimed, promotes social justice. I have dealt with the Aboriginal matter. As I said, three or four times the amount being spent on health is being spent to provide land for Aboriginals. This is more than is spent on important matters such as giving them the right to survive and enjoy decent health. I cannot understand the government's priorities in this area. Surely nothing should be more important to the government, which claims to understand this issue, than providing for the wellbeing of people. I cannot see the social justice in not providing real jobs.

On the last goal, that of reducing the budget deficit without increasing taxes, Budget Paper No. 1 clearly shows an increase in revenue of 7.9 per cent. So the government is clearly increasing taxes. In the sales tax area alone, in one year there is a 43 per cent increase in sales tax. Inflation will go up by about 1.4 per cent—let us run it out to two per cent. The government's increase in revenue is four times the increase in inflation. There is no equity in this, and there is certainly an increase in taxation.

On those four goals one would have to say that there is doubt already about the maximisation of economic growth, and there is real doubt about whether the government is serious in reducing unemployment. There cannot be any other than a very biased, jaundiced point of view about whether social justice is being delivered by the budget. One would have to be a member of the politically correct and elite Labor Party to understand its thoughts on social justice. For example, the government thinks it is politically correct to smoke marijuana but not tobacco. That is the sort of thing Labor is promoting in this House. I cannot follow that logic, nor can I follow the logic of promoting social justice, as outlined in the budget, whether it be with jobs or with the Aboriginal people.

When looking at this budget to see whether it really measures up to the needs of the Australian people, I have taken two documents of advice submitted to the government. The first one, containing budget proposals, was put to the Australian government by the Salvation Army of Australia, and is entitled Budget Submission to Commonwealth Government 1994-95. Nobody could doubt the authenticity of the Salvation Army. The other submission put to the government that I will look at is entitled Towards a creative innovative manufacturing nation by the Metal Trades Industry Association, which represents the manufacturing industries of Australia.

I want to measure the government's effort against two important groups in our community: the one that will supply jobs and the one that looks after the needy and those requiring welfare—the real hurt cases in Australia. We will see whether the government measures up to the objectives that it has laid down. The Salvation Army submission impresses this upon the government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the focus of The Salvation Army in preparing this Submission is upon the long-term well-being of those in our society who are most disadvantaged and least able to advocate for themselves.

Every Australian would understand that the Salvation Army, along with other organisations, truly represents that group. I do not claim that it is unique or exclusive in that area. St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family and many other groups do similar work to the Salvation Army. They seek to assist those in the most vital need. The Salvation Army submission, which was put to the government just before the budget, requests the government to take note of these things. It also says:
. . . the revitalisation of our economy holds the potential for the gulf between the haves and have-nots to continue to widen, between those in employment, and those without a job.

One only has to look at the term of office of the Australian Labor Party to understand that that gulf has widened. The mates of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the few elite at the top have really benefited by the Labor Party. The bottom 10 per cent has gone backwards in their capacity to look after themselves and avoid poverty. So the haves and the have-nots have grown further apart. The Salvation Army is pleading with the government not to continue with the policies that have created that situation. The Salvation Army's presentation also states that, should the gap increase:

. . . significant numbers of Australians are likely to become trapped in poverty, creating an underclass which may have the dire personal and social consequences which have been witnessed overseas in parts of the United Kingdom and the United States of America.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you will agree that Perth is a pretty open and beautiful city. There has been an avoidance of ghetto or slum type degraded land development in the inner city areas of Perth. In giving evidence in Perth, the Salvation Army said it believes that a permanent underclass has been established in Australia. The Australian Labor Party has brought that about. It said that it has occurred over the last 10 years.

PARA.TAB: The Salvation Army has pleaded with the government, through the budget, to not allow that to continue and to reverse the trend of creating a permanent underclass. The government does not acknowledge that, and nothing in the budget or the white paper seeks to rectify those problems. The Salvation Army submission continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The Salvation Army is calling upon the Commonwealth Government and all members of the Australian Parliament—
everybody here—

to ensure that those Australians with whom The Salvation Army has day-to-day contact, who include the unemployed, the poor, the homeless, and those with psychiatric illness, have their needs addressed in tangible and effective responses.

Let us deal with the unemployed. The Salvation Army has said that employment is one of the most important things for giving people a sense of wellbeing and an opportunity to look after themselves. The vital part of its submission—the main text—states:

The Salvation Army is concerned about the impact of unemployment on all Australians who are without employment, and supports strong action on the part of government, in cooperation with business and the community, to create real jobs which will supply sustainable employment.

The government has not met that objective in its budget and has not tried to. It is not interested in long-term employment. It is not concerned about the ability to employ or whether there is sustenance for families to continue to exist. All the government is doing in its budget and the white paper is providing training opportunities, fudging the figures and giving people an opportunity to learn more. We need to have that in Australia, but what happens next? There is no impetus to lift some of the restraints currently on business to allow it to employ. The objectives set out by the Salvation Army are not being met, and that is a tragedy.

PARA.TAB: The poor are getting poorer. The Prime Minister fails to acknowledge that day after day. He comes here and parades with his Italian suits and French clocks without having any understanding of what is happening in Australia. How long has it been since he visited a soup kitchen? How long has it been since he went into his electorate, to Bankstown, and met some of its welfare cases? How long has it been since he visited the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul in Bankstown to find out what is happening in Australia? He is remote and does not care. A permanent underclass has been established. The homeless numbers continue to grow.

The Salvation Army claims that the Commonwealth had in this budget a unique opportunity to enhance the position of families in Australia. This is the International Year of the Family. I searched the budget speech via computer to find the word `family'. It is mentioned once, and it relates to the Family Court. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mrs McHugh), who is at the table, must be really proud of the government in relation to the breakdown of families.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—There is not one word of encouragement and support for families in the budget speech. Mr Deputy Speaker, read the budget papers. I invite honourable members, all members of the Australian community in the gallery and the clerks sitting at the table to read the Australian budget speech for 1994-95. If they do, they will find that the word `family' is shown once. It concerns the Family Court and the destruction of marriage and families. There is nothing for the family in the International Year of the Family.

PARA.TAB: The Salvation Army has said to the Australian government that if we are going to build a more solid and sound Australia and if people are going to avoid being unemployed, poor or homeless they need the mutual support of family members. The government has avoided that issue altogether. In the International Year of the Family, the Salvation Army has said to the government:

SPEECH.PARA: Budgetary decisions, particularly as they relate to the family, should enhance family life, reduce financial structures and strictures on families, and alleviate poverty in such a way that families are able to live with dignity.

That has been ignored completely. We have looked at the needs of people. Let us now look on the other hand at what those who supply jobs—the manufacturing industries of Australia—have said they wanted from the Australian government in the budget. The Metal Trades Industry Association has said that it wants a competitive macro environment—I guess that it means a competitive macro-economic environment—with a competitive Australian dollar, the maintenance of low interest rates and a competitive real interest rates structure.

PARA.TAB: As a matter of interest, when I looked at the current inflation rates of Australia and comparable countries, I found that our inflation rate is low. The government has claimed that it is low. The inflation rate of some of our competitors is slightly higher. For instance, the inflation rate of the United Kingdom and the United States is 0.5 and 0.7 per cent above the Australian inflation rate. Australia ranks with Canada, Finland, Japan, New Zealand and Norway in having equal or lower rates. But a large range of nations with whom we compete have similar inflation rates.

When one looks at the interest rates charged in Australia, one sees a real difference. As far as interest rates are concerned, Australia is one of the countries with higher rates. In the OECD, only Italy and Spain are above Australia in terms of current interest rates. Things will move ahead and the metal trades industry will achieve the investment that is essential for the budget and for the objective of creating jobs, but one of the prime things that people want is competitive interest rates so they can borrow for plant, equipment and factories. The government is not supplying them, and it does not look like it is going to happen. Interest rates will rise. In comparative terms, Australia's investors are at a disadvantage if they are going to pursue the objectives that will create jobs.

The Metal Trades Industry Association, which is a job supplier—a body which creates jobs—wants the government to make sure that industry cost structures are kept under control and that the increase in costs created by government must be stopped or reversed. A common cry among employers is that they cannot afford to keep employing while oncosts are so high.

Within the last few days we have seen the government do a 180-degree turn on the industrial relations bill and redundancy arrangements simply because the costs to Australian employers were so great that they were actually going to de-employ. I do not know whether honourable members were aware of it, but many manufacturers were thinking of shedding staff so they would not be caught with huge redundancy payouts that would bankrupt their businesses. This is not an abuse of labour. Manufacturers and employers in Australia today are in such a tender state that anything that will impose additional costs or difficulties on them will cause them to close their doors. They are not going to stick around and continue to run a business for the returns that are there under the current government.

The Metal Trades Industry Association said that we needed to get rid of inefficient and outmoded regulations that are hampering it. The MTIA remains concerned about the high level of taxation on inputs—that is, things it uses to make its products—particularly in respect of inputs to the cost of exports, including sales tax. Australia has one of the craziest regimes in the world as far as input costs are concerned. The government has picked up the detrimental features of Fightback, in that where it can grab money it has used a Fightback type formula to do it—but without any of the compensation that should be of advantage to Australian manufacturers, to job creation and to our exports.

If we look towards the future, we have only to look at some of our `big Australians', whether it be John Prescott of BHP or Professor Hilmer. I think they are pointing the way ahead, and the government is ignoring them. Professor Hilmer says:

SPEECH.PARA: A government seeking to use the power of goal setting would need first to ensure that it was setting high-quality goals, and second that these goals were not seen as rhetoric or marketing. . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now a little over 11 years since I was first elected to this House. I suppose this budget must represent somewhere in the order of the 30th economic statement or budget that this government has produced in that time. I can say in all honesty that it has been the best received budget in my experience, both within the public at large and, certainly, within my electorate. There are a range of issues that one could discuss during an appropriation bill debate. I do not propose to make wide-ranging comments on many of the aspects of the budget. That will be done by many of my colleagues and has already been done by some who have preceded me in this debate.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the key economic ministers—in particular, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), led by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—in bringing down what I consider to be a first-rate economic document, a document that has been extraordinarily well received by everyone within the community. Of course, there will be critics of any budget. Everyone will be able to point to particular elements of the budget with which they disagree, but I do not think anyone is really contesting the general broad economic thrust of the budget. That has been very clear to date in some of the contributions that we have heard from the opposition. Most of the debate from the opposition so far has been like being attacked with a wet lettuce over the wrist.

The point I would like to make about the budget during my contribution this afternoon is in relation to some of the key moves in terms of regional development. Many of those moves were spelt out the week before the budget was handed down in the government's white paper Working Nation, but of course the appropriations for those initiatives were contained within this year's budget statement.

In the week of Working Nation, in Orange six local government authorities which make up an organisation within my electorate called the Central West Economic Development Group held what I consider to be an historic meeting. The councils of Blayney, Cabonne, Forbes, Lachlan, Orange and Parkes were each represented at that meeting by their mayor and general manager. These councils form what is essentially the geographical area covered by the Central West Economic Development Group.

That meeting pledged support for the Central West Economic Development Group as the regional vehicle for responding to the regional development initiatives that were contained in the federal government's white paper on employment and growth, and it backed the Central West Economic Development Group in pursuing funding as outlined in the white paper. This course of events may not necessarily steal the nation's headlines, but as far as I am concerned it is a very significant statement locally.

The day the white paper was released—that is, Wednesday, 4 May—the head of the Central West Economic Development Group, Mr Alex Ferguson, was quoted by the local media as saying that the central west was well placed to take up the front running in response to the government's regional development initiatives. I believe that that is a very true statement. Even during the worst impact of the most recent recession, because of the nature of the regional economy that I am privileged to represent, we were spared some of the worst impacts of the recession. As of the December quarter 1992, the unemployment levels right throughout my electorate were of the order of 6 1/2 per cent, compared with the national average of around 10 per cent, which gives some indication of the strength of that regional economy even in these reasonably early days of recovery.

I believe that Mr Ferguson is spot-on when he talks about the opportunities for the central west to respond to those regional development initiatives. He went on to say that the group had been working very closely with the Department of Industry, Science and Technology for a number of years and that the policy statements in the white paper were no more or less than they had been talking about for the last six to nine months. However, he acknowledged that lack of cooperation from the various councils in the region could hamper these developments. He was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious they—
that is, the councils—

would need to start playing as a team to bring together 85,000 people and a great deal of wealth. The White Paper recognises that the very heart of regional development is the potential and ownership of projects by the community.

The very next day, the day after the white paper's release, the six local councils in question, which are all represented on the board of the Central West Economic Development Group, released a joint communique in which they confirmed that they would be moving forward together as a group to seek funding. Mr Ferguson was able to emerge from that meeting saying that the mayors had clearly acknowledged the imperatives for regional development and the need to get the ball rolling. He went on to say:

This was quite a meeting, getting together the mayors of the region to meet and discuss something that is important to all their communities. They are enthusiastic about the combined strength of the Central West and the benefit of a united approach to development.

Such a united approach is precisely what the federal government is on about: fostering a sense of collective responsibility for regional development. It is interesting that some fairly well-known Nationals who have had great aspirations for recovering the federal division of Calare since 1983, when it was lost by the National Party, have been wandering around with local media releases suggesting that this government has somehow forgotten them in terms of regional development. Very powerful statements from clearly non-politically based organisations like the Central West Economic Development Group, which does represent those councils, give some sort of credence to the fact that this government does acknowledge that there is a great deal in this budget for regional development.

PARA.TAB: As we have seen in many other parts of Australia, until now many communities have been unwilling or, indeed, unable to put aside some of their parochial jealousies, their vested interests and their cynicism in a way that would enable them to unite as a region and to pursue genuine regional development initiatives. If my own region is anything to go by, and I think it is, then the government's actions in Working Nation and the budget papers have been just the catalyst that was needed.

Those of us who are privileged to represent rural and regional Australia all know that there is tremendous potential in regions right throughout Australia. The problem until now, though, has been how to unlock that enormous potential that does exist. The government's national regional development strategy recognises that regions are best placed to take the lead in shaping their own future. It is not a case of a government imposing some sort of tops-down approach to regional development. We do not have a magic formula in this place for telling the various regions, which are very different in their composition throughout Australia, what is best for them. That would be insulting the collective intelligence and the collective strength of those regions. This approach is recognised as very much a bottom-up approach, but we will be providing the necessary seed money and, indeed, infrastructure support money to allow that to occur.

The approach recognises that the Commonwealth will not mandate some sort of uniform solution. We are prepared to work in partnership with the states, the territory governments and, importantly, with local government and local communities to make the best use of all those available resources and opportunities. There will always be, of course, some sort of cargo cult mentality when it comes to regional development. The prime supporters, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, as I am sure you are only too well aware in your own electorate, are the agrarian socialists—the National Party—who always see things in terms of a central government providing a quick-fix solution to some sort of perceived problem.

Predictably, many of these people, one of them being the New South Wales Minister for Small Business and Regional Development, Mr Chappell, have come out and accused the federal government of not throwing enough money in the recent budget at regional development. He can be excused for having party political reasons for making such claims, but others have no excuse other than they have missed the whole point of the government's regional development strategy. Fortunately, there are people out there like Alex Ferguson from the Central West Economic Development Group who have already recognised that the days of cargo cultism are well and truly over. He publicly stated last week that the regional development initiatives contained in the budget:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . heralded a new era whereby the Federal Government would no longer be the `Mr Fixit' for regional economies. The White Paper does, however, provide us with the tools to take control of our own region.

This is the bottom-up approach that I am talking about that is well supported by organisations like the Central West Economic Development Group, which has already undertaken very detailed ABS based research into the potential of the central west New South Wales region. The strategy that is outcome driven is in the process of preparation. Clearly, in many ways central west New South Wales is already ahead of many regions, and because of this I believe it is ideally placed to almost immediately, once the paperwork is ready to roll, tap into many of the initiatives.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity during my contribution to acknowledge the board of the Central West Economic Development Group, which consists of a range of people from business, unions, the Orange Agricultural College of the University of Sydney, as well as the six local government authorities, for placing this region in this very strong position. I certainly look forward to a continuation of this cooperative spirit as the central west regional development strategy is put into place over coming months. I am also looking forward to a continuation of the spirit of cooperation in a meeting I hope to organise shortly that will involve the Office of Regional Development, the Central West Economic Development Group, organisations like business enterprise centres and local councils so that we can further analyse and build upon the initiatives contained in the budget and the white paper. This meeting, I hope, will allow us to maximise further the region's potential.

There is one further reason, though, why I am very pleased about the role of the Central West Economic Development Group in this process. That is, the group was in fact established during my tenure as Minister for Local Government through a very similar program called the local enterprise program. In 1992 the Office of Local Government provided some $300,000 over a three-year period towards the operation of regional bodies with similar organisations in a range of regions throughout Australia, including the Gosford-Wyong area of New South Wales, Ipswich in Queensland, and south-east Melbourne.

Many of the aims of the local enterprise program fitted very comfortably with notions of regional development being pursued in many of these initiatives. They were: to facilitate fully the development of the growth potential of those key regions, thereby contributing to the expansion of the national economy; to focus on those regional competitive advantages which lead to enterprises with rapid growth prospects and capacity for substantial wealth generation rather than self-employment initiatives and small business with only some sort of a local domain; and to draw together the appropriate elements, individuals and, if necessary, regions to create the critical mass that is often necessary for effective national and international market entry and maintenance in the traded goods and services section.

In acknowledging the role of the government this time in pursuing notions of regional development, my former responsibility—the Office of Local Government—certainly played a very landmark role in driving this process. I am sure that many of those former officers will feel very distinctly pleased with the overall directions of the response to regional development contained in the white paper, Working Nation.

I thank the House for the opportunity to make some of those comments on the regional development aspects of the budget, certainly as they apply to my electorate. I believe it does represent a unique and wonderful opportunity for regions to do something very constructive as we now enter a very exciting period in the 1990s—a period of low inflation and growing employment prospects for many of those areas that have been affected by economic difficulties over the last few years. In the context of the 1994-95 budget, I believe that those regions are well placed to do well into the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sad to say but the Willis 1994-95 budget is corrupt. It is corrupt of ideas, it is corrupt of solutions, and it is corrupt of wealth creation. This budget—the Willis budget—sells Australia short and determines that many hardworking Australians will not share in the recovery that is anticipated by this government.

PARA.TAB: We are but two weeks into the budget session and the very bullish expectations from it are already beginning to be seen for what they really are—nothing but cheap, empty rhetoric. When we strip away the Labor rhetoric, so rich in its delivery but so boring after so many years of hearing it, we are left with nothing but empty words, empty promises and a lack of future for many Australians.

This budget was a time for leadership, which is something that the majority of Australians richly deserve and have been waiting a long time to receive. But they did not get it. Instead, we got the standard cry of that Labor `true believing' myth, which implies that the Labor Party cares about social justice. This is a real myth. The Labor Party cares about social justice as much as a grasshopper cares about its mate. This ACTU driven, democratic, socialist party is like all those other ideologues who have failed in recent years: it fails to deliver on its promises. Like the grasshopper, it devours anyone and anything that stands in its way.

The government promises the underprivileged help and justice, yet it remains content with reducing living standards. It promotes irrational industrial relations policies that prevent work rather than create work. This government does not care about anything other than building its own power base and holding onto its power. This budget is all about power and the need for the Labor Party to keep hold of it. It is silly to say that it provides social justice; it does not.

This budget increases government revenue, yet those opposite say that there will be no increase in taxes. But we must never forget the Labor Party's attack on the lower income Australians in last year's budget which directed tax increases for this year. So there are tax increases this year. This budget is the biggest taxing budget in the history of our nation.

The Labor Party claims that it provides social justice, but how can it when our country moves further and further into enormous debt? Social justice is not owned by the Labor Party. Its policy actions and legislation have created a new underclass, a new and growing poor. These people have been left behind by the true believers. To suggest that those who vote for Labor are the true believers is a nonsense. This party betrayed and corrupted their very values years ago. I feel sorry for those who voted Labor back when the importance of working hard was rewarded. They have been left with nothing but empty rhetoric from the two-bob toffs opposite who are more interested in the trappings of office than the real problems associated with the poor financial management by this government.

Social justice cannot be truly delivered by the Labor Party because it is unable to provide the initiatives required to deliver it. Is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) seriously suggesting that the 49 per cent of Australians who did not vote for him last year do not care less about those disadvantaged in our community? Are those opposite honestly saying that we Australians on this side of parliament do not care or even feel any responsibility for those Australians who are disadvantaged? Is anyone on the other side of the parliament brave enough to walk from this place and identify those of us on this side whom he or she thinks do not care about the disadvantaged in Australia? I do not think so. We have a Labor government with a born to rule mentality. It has lost its way with respect to those who have brought it to power and it continually neglects the social justice issues that it so cynically proclaims to have expertise in.

Let us examine why this budget is corrupt in its structure and why so many Australians should come to realise that the future of our great country is at risk whilst these laggards opposite continue with their deceit. In Australia we are blessed with great wealth, and the Labor Party espouses our nation's virtues. But would the House be aware that one in 10 people who are able to work are out of work? Is the House aware that it is highly accepted that one in five Australians are underemployed? Is the House aware that, under Labor, Australians are opting not to marry and not to have children? This will impact upon our society by the year 2006, when it is said that 50 per cent of households will comprise single people or couples without children.

Under Labor divorce rates are approaching 43 per cent of all marriages. Under Labor we have seen rising numbers of homeless children, many the victims of so-called blended families, who are on the streets and who are quickly assuming drug and prostitution lifestyles. Under Labor suicide rates of young Australians are amongst the highest in the world. What hope does this budget offer these young Australians?

Adolescent delinquency poses enormous problems for society in general and law enforcement in particular. Under Labor child abuse has become more prevalent, most particularly in these so-called blended families. Under Labor educational achievement has suffered a spectacular decline, particularly in the foundational spheres of literacy and numeracy. Discipline and respect, those vital ingredients in a successful education system and in a coherent and stable society, are hard to find in many of our young these days. Under Labor the single parent phenomenon is now a common experience presenting a new challenge for our society. Single parents are recognised as one of the poorest groups in Australia.

Beyond the rhetoric we have a growing social crisis which this government fails to identify. It is too weak to admit mistakes and take the necessary action to improve social benefits for all Australians. Under Labor the rich have got richer, the middle class has dwindled and there are now many more poor. A new underclass has developed under this government which proudly boasts about its achievements which are nothing but empty rhetoric.

How proud this government must be of its social justice policies when it allows fellow Australians to remain homeless. The Labor Party must really be proud to know that, under its policies, it allows 90,000 Australians to sleep out of doors each and every night. There are 195,000 Australians who live in caravans and 160,000 Australians who are waiting for public housing. Homeless Australians sleep in refuges, squats, lodges and accommodation supplied by charities. The rest of them sleep in doorways, fire escapes, trains, bins and old car bodies.

Recently, one young man was unable to find accommodation so he chose to sleep in a dumpster behind a shelter. He awoke quite early in the morning to some violent movement as a garbage collection truck emptied him into a compactor and he was compressed to death. No kids in Australia should ever be allowed to sleep in garbage bins, yet they are under this so-called social justice Labor Party.

How proud this so-called socially just Labor Party must be to allow one in five Australian children, who are our nation's future, to live under the poverty line. How proud it must be of the social justice programs and policies it is providing when 800,000 children have neither parent working. How proud this Labor government must be to provide refuge for homeless women when last year 23,000 women who sought safety just in Sydney were not provided for. Where is the Labor Party's justice when 2.8 million Australians live below the poverty line? Where is the justice when we tax all Australians living below the poverty line who earn an income?

Where is the justice for our native Australians? There is an urgent need to improve their health and fundamental living conditions, but this bleeding heart Labor government, this government of rhetoric, would rather establish a land fund for purchase of land than increase the funding for improved health conditions for our indigenous Australians. In 1972 Nugget Coombs wrote this about the Aborigine:

SPEECH.PARA: We are producing a race of cripples—children who will never be able to lead normal lives, every one of whom will be a cost to the state.

Coombs warned that, unless the `circle of paternalism, dependence and pauperism' was broken within the 1970s, it would be more difficult, if not impossible, to solve. Twenty years later it may be too late.

PARA.TAB: This Labor government reckons that funding a land acquisition fund relinquishes it from the years of neglect it has given the Aborigine over the last 13 years of Labor government and policies. What situation are the Aborigines in now? If they are not the poorest, they are one of the poorest groups of Australians. This socially just Labor Party still thinks it is working for their betterment. It has had 13 years of the past 20 years to improve that situation.

Let us end this myth about social justice being provided by this government. Sure, it gives handouts but what Australians need is more than a handout. What they really need is a hand up. Australians recognise the need to support our neighbours, for we are truly a caring character. Yet this government thinks and acts contrarily to our values by spending money, throwing money—more likely shovelling money—at the many problems rather than trying to solve the challenges our society has been faced with. Where in this budget are the jobs that have been promised for so long?

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you remember the Labor Party slogan during the 1993 election campaign: `Jobs not GST'. We have not got a GST but I can assure honourable members that we have not got the jobs either. Where are they? Mr Deputy Speaker, do you remember the then Treasurer Dawkins who said that the 1993 budget was all about jobs? Where are they? One in 10 Australians who are fit to work are still out of work.

We have the rhetoric of the bleeding heart Labor Party who insult Australians by referring to them as long-term unemployed. Do those opposite not understand that the long-term unemployed they suddenly discovered in the last few months and are now throwing money at are the long-term unemployed caused directly by the Labor Party? This government created the long-term unemployed problem. The long-term unemployed want only one thing. They do not want handouts. They want a job, yet none are in sight. This Labor Party taxes us, then spends the proceeds. It sells our assets, then spends the proceeds. It borrows money to pay for its programs, then it spends the proceeds. This government has caused more social problems than it has solved.

Who could forget this government's attitude to the self-funded retirees last year? Those Australians who had provided for their future were treated with such disdain by this government. Perhaps they did something wrong. Perhaps they went wrong by saving for their future after their retirement. Saving is a concept that this Labor government does not quite understand and is yet to discover. Do honourable members recall the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) saying last year that these Australians who had provided for themselves were sponging on the system? A Labor Party member was saying that pensioners and self-funded retirees were sponging on the system. What has happened to the true believers?

This budget is not the one our country needs right now. It is a budget of lost opportunity. It squanders the benefits of any recovery that our nation has been waiting many years for. It is a long awaited recovery which will overcome the pain of the recession—a recession deliberately brought upon us by this myth-making, sharing and caring Labor Party. Many of the budget estimates have been fudged, which would not surprise anyone in this place.

The budget breaks yet another promise of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister promised in 1992 to return the impact of inflation back to the taxpayer. Yet a whopping 8.1 per cent more income tax will be collected this year compared to last year. When is this Prime Minister ever going to keep a promise he makes to the Australian people? How long will it be before the Australian people—who generally hate scoundrels and laggards—give this Prime Minister the real short shrift? Remember the Prime Minister's promise about the tax cuts, the l-a-w, law? They are gone. Remember the gang buster investment waiting promise? That has gone. Remember those growth forecast promises? Within two weeks, they are gone, according to Access Economics. Remember the low interest rates promise? That is potentially gone, according to recent press reports from the Prime Minister and the Reserve Bank governor. Remember the Qantas sale promise? It has been made twice so far. That has gone. Remember our debt reduction program promise, `We are going to reduce the debt?' That is gone because the budget actually increases debt.

Government debt will almost triple from $33 billion in 1991. That might surprise some in the gallery. Our debt was $33 billion in 1991; it will increase to $95 billion only three years later in 1995. Remember the Prime Minister's promises? He said there would be more and better jobs. That promise has gone. He said there would be no new taxes. That has gone. He said there will be lower government debt. That has gone. There is no gain in this budget, just continued pain. Recent newspaper reports would indicate that about business investment.

What should have been done in this budget? What should it have provided for? First, there should have been an effort to reform the complete tax system, which discriminates against those Australians who are struggling at the moment. We tax those living under the poverty line. Secondly, we need policies that promote business growth, not hamper it with the current tremendous cost disadvantages of doing business in Australia. Thirdly, there should be a national savings strategy to reboost our national savings and reduce this growing debt crisis. The government should have looked at the way it does business and start to reduce the trappings it has got used to over the last 11 years and begin to become more responsible to the taxpayers of Australia.

This budget is a real dud. It is a dud because those opposite who get up and support it only speak in rhetoric. Although many of those opposite are people of truly high principle and would not wish to harm the Australian public, they have begun to believe their own rhetoric. I ask those opposite to look around and see what is happening in their own electorates and to demand more responsibility from the executive of their own party. Stand against those who would hold this great country back, and fight for responsibility of government. Say no to homelessness. Say no to unemployment.

I say to all Australians, `You pay the taxes. It is time to demand greater responsibility from your government. Demand lower debt, demand more savings and demand a more flexible business system.' It is time that these values came back into our parliamentary system and it is time for Australians to demand more from their parliamentary representatives. Instead of having people walk into this place, stand up and deliver rhetoric, let us get some responsibility back into government and start paying our way rather than borrowing our way. Talk is cheap, and this budget has sold Australia short.

TALK.START.PARA: It is a real delight to speak in this debate because the budget is a well targeted one. It concentrated on stimulating growth of employment and on increasing training opportunities and work experience opportunities for the long-term unemployed. It is an equitable budget and it will stimulate the level of economic activity in the private sector.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), was asserting that there is a debt problem in Australia. He clearly does not know the situation. The Australian public sector—Commonwealth, state and local government put together—has less debt as a proportion of GDP than any other Western country. Our debts are lower than those of any other comparable country in the world. To assert that we have a debt problem is simply ill-informed. I am astonished that the honourable member opposite does not know that. I would urge him to look up the latest OECD Economic Outlook to see the figures for himself.

However, I want to go on and talk about additional things that can be done about the unemployment problem. Quite clearly, it is Australia's most serious problem. It is clearly a problem to which there are no panaceas but to which a whole series of additional public policies and changes in business approaches, union practice and community attitudes are necessary. It is essential—and, in saying this, I think I would concur with the honourable member who spoke before me—for us to give additional attention to this problem. None of us can claim to have the whole answer to it, and we must go on exploring possibilities.

The essential reason for that is that there is a massive cost in both economic and human terms to unemployment, and we want to minimise that now and in the future and as quickly as we possibly can. The principal requirement is that there be a rigorous implementation of the goal of full employment. The government accepts the goal of full employment; it has reiterated that during the election, in the speech of the Governor-General and again in the green and white papers. The question is: how do we achieve that? There are a whole series of changes in policies still that seem to be very important.

One of the important changes is that we must be more sceptical of the extremist and dogmatic ideology, called economic rationalism by some people and, more accurately I think, economic fundamentalism which dominated a lot of public debate and the minds of many of the senior advisers to government during the 1980s. The influence of that ideology peaked at the end of the 1980s. But there are still many officials holding senior positions in the Commonwealth Public Service who are committed to it and who need to re-examine, in quite practical terms, the impact of the policies they have been recommending and what policy changes are necessary.

A return from that fundamentalist detour will involve a more reasonable approach to economic policy, based on the commitment to full employment, equity, economic growth and environmental sustainability. But, as well, it will involve a careful analysis of the way the economy and society operate rather than how neo-classical theory or fundamentalist ideological hypotheses suggest they do and practical means for achieving those goals in the least costly ways. Of course, when we start to do that, there will be no shortage of jobs needing to be done—none at all.

The task is to match the needs with the available people.
