For example, standards of primary, secondary and tertiary education and health care are being undermined by funding cuts; retrenchment of teachers and closures of hospital beds are increasing unemployment. We saw evidence of that in South Australia's financial statement yesterday. Last year about 150,000 applicants to technical and further education colleges all around Australia were unable to obtain places. To provide those places would increase employment of staff and the number of youth in training and so substantially reduce youth unemployment, as well as increasing the skills of the work force.

Services for the vulnerable—including the unemployed; the aged; the intellectually and psychologically disabled; families in conflict, including survivors of domestic violence; recent migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds; and Aborigines—are all inadequate and many have worsened relative to need during the long period of expenditure cutting. High unemployment intensifies demand for supportive human services, such as health, housing and emergency counselling. Yet cuts have continued in those areas.

Despite the fact that most of the services are being delivered by the states and territories, the Commonwealth has reduced their net funding from 9 1/2 per cent of national income 20 years ago to 4.9 per cent now, nearly halving the proportion of funds available to the states. During the last decade funding for scientific and cultural organisations, such as CSIRO and the ABC, on which the vitality of the economy and society depend, have been reduced by a third as a proportion of national income.

The main areas of employment growth during the next decade will be in the services sector. On the one hand, two-thirds of all people in the work force are already employed in the service industries: community services; wholesaling and retailing; professional, technical and other personal services; transport and communication; finance, property and business services; and recreation and, on the other, for many years the proportion of employment in agriculture, mining and manufacturing has been declining, and that trend is likely to continue. Those trends are a universal feature of developed countries. We must recognise the fact that they will continue in Australia and that, if they are not allowed to continue, we will be depriving ourselves of employment growth where it can most naturally occur.

The reason that is inevitable is that human services are highly labour intensive and are the least affected by technological change; they are far less affected by technological change than industries producing physical goods. The demand for human services rises with income and so increases as a proportion of total demand.

Macro-economic policy for the rest of the 1990s must be framed so as to achieve the highest rate of growth of output and so of employment which is both feasible and ecologically sustainable. That is the government's commitment. A major component of this must be improvements in the availability, accessibility and quality of human services. Rather than setting education and health standards based on the poorest quality in any state, Australia should at least aim to level up to the highest standard achieved in any part of the country and, whenever possible, to move beyond this and seek excellence. We all want excellence in every area of public life; we must seek it as well in the provision of human services. This would involve a major expansion of employment in publicly funded community services, whether provided by governments, non-profit community organisations—including churches and other voluntary groups—or privately.

Education and health are large sectors where increased employment would obviously be justified as it would be in services for families, the aged, the unemployed, the disabled and migrants. That is also true of services for Aborigines—and I was appalled by the previous speaker's comments about government support for social justice to Aborigines. Increased employment in research, development and demonstration and in legal, scientific and management advisory and marketing support would contribute to improving business prospects.

Community interest in the arts has been growing rapidly, as would be expected when average income is growing. Public funding should also increase in response and so boost growth of employment in the cultural sector. There is considerable scope for growth of employment in the cultural sector, as the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), at the table, is well aware.

These improvements and other parts of the strategy being described would lead to a permanent growth in the demand for labour. But another part of the expansion for labour comprises exactly the kinds of programs that were announced in the white paper; that is, those which increase the employment opportunities for the long-term unemployed—the people who have lost contact with the work force, whose skills have been undermined by a period of unemployment and who need additional help in getting back into work experience and additional training opportunities. That white paper program is perfectly well targeted to achieve those results.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the good of the whole country.

—Exactly. The response to the white paper and the budget shows there is overwhelming community support for those policies. Another area, though, where additional initiative is required is public infrastructure. During the last couple of decades there has been a substantial fall in the level of public investment. Allowing that to happen not only deprives ourselves of the increase in efficiency which can flow from improvements in the public infrastructure but also undermines the stimulus to private investment which public investment can provide. Public investment increases private sector efficiency and productivity and, therefore, stimulates growth of business investment. We should be aiming to build up public investment and private investment through those mechanisms.

PARA.TAB: These sorts of proposals should be partly funded through revenue growth as economic growth occurs and through other equitable and progressive changes to the tax system. As Australia is the lowest taxed developed country, we do have scope for deciding that we want to live in a decent civilised society and taking the necessary steps to achieve that.

Another dimension of a strategy to maximise growth of employment must be the continuation of the accord and income restraint. We could see during the 1980s the enormous benefit that wage restraint caused in the growth of employment and reduction of inflation. We need to continue those strategies during the 1990s. But, to make that morally tenable, we must ensure that higher incomes are also restrained. The explosion of executive incomes undermines the willingness of others on lower incomes to accept restraint. Yet both are essential if we are going to maximise growth of employment.

Many of these measures would directly or indirectly stimulate activity in the private sector, but two additional policies are of crucial importance. Firstly, it is essential to keep interest rates as low as possible. It has been very good to hear the commitment of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in recent days to that goal under very silly questioning from the opposition. Although investment responds principally to the level of expected sales, interest rates influence the cost of investment and are, as well, a powerful determinant of the exchange rate and of consumer demand. So interest rate minimisation is essential.

Secondly, one more innovative proposal which ought to be seriously considered, and which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which I chair, is presently looking at, is the possibility of reducing or abolishing payroll tax because that would remove a perverse tax on employment and reduce labour costs. Of course, that is a very complex proposal because that is a state tax and at present generates about $6 billion of revenue. But it could be offset by the introduction of a greenhouse gas emission tax. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has recently spoken about the possibility of changing the tax structure so as to provide incentives for reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. This would be a very feasible trade-off to examine.

Keeping interest rates down also avoids attracting short-term overseas capital unnecessarily and so avoids unwanted upward pressure on the exchange rate. Australia's international competitiveness has dramatically improved—by 30 per cent in fact—over the last few years with lower interest rates and a lower exchange rate, but we must maintain those conditions.

There are other aspects of a comprehensive additional employment strategy, but I have had time only to concentrate on the ones I have mentioned. I will also mention that the environment industry offers many opportunities for growth of employment. It is also important that we examine the possibility of reducing average working hours. Many people in the community recognise it as perverse that during the last decade there has been a growth in the average working hours for full-time labour at exactly the time when it ought to be falling. The examination of feasible ways of achieving lower average working hours is one way of sharing the available work more effectively.

A strategy such as that, in addition to those which are already in place, would maximise growth of employment. Economic growth alone will not be sufficient to achieve full employment. It would be very fortunate if we got down to five per cent, although that is the goal that the government is aiming for by the end of the decade. We should be aiming not only to rely on economic growth but also to find additional policies which would contribute to growth of employment. Each of those that I have mentioned should either be introduced or be seriously considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there was a time for courage, honesty, leadership, strength, the necessary decisions and putting Australia first, it was in the 1994-95 budget. Regrettably, it lacked any of these characteristics. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) in his first budget, in two words, wimped out. We are now in the 11th year of a Labor government. On every occasion the Labor Party has had the opportunity to do some good it has put itself and its party ahead of the interests of Australia and the Australian people and gambled our future for its own electoral good.

PARA.TAB: It is time the Labor government showed leadership. For 11 years people have been crying out for it, but in return they have received only lies, rhetoric, hollow promises and vitriolic abuse. They have never received decent leadership. Last year's budget was simply confirmation that the Labor Party was elected with no policies, having lied its way into office, and with no idea of how to address the fundamental problems facing our nation. It betrayed the Australian people. It let the Australian people down.

We cannot continue kidding ourselves or the people we were elected to represent. We need to honestly address the problems facing our nation. While the Treasurer had the perfect opportunity to do this, like all Labor Treasurers before him, he piked out and delivered a budget which will do nothing to address our problems. He has mortgaged the future of young Australians for his party's selfish political goals.

I will direct my attention to a number of areas of the budget, but I think one of the most crippling, telling blows in this budget is directed towards young Australians. This group of people has been the worst affected over the last decade by the incompetence and mismanagement of the Labor government. Look at what has happened to young Australians under this Labor government. They are going to inherit a massive debt which this government has done very little to address. Indeed, not only will they inherit a mammoth debt but also many young Australians will inherit a lower standard of living than we enjoyed. They are faced with massive unemployment. Nearly one in every three young Australians is faced with unemployment on leaving school.

Many university graduates are also facing unemployment upon leaving—something that our age group never contemplated, whether we were leaving school or university. There was always a range of jobs available for us to go to. There is also the issue of youth homelessness. The Burdekin report suggests that there are at least 20,000 to 25,000 homeless young Australians, and that figure could possibly be as high as 70,000. There is also the issue of youth suicide. We are faced with the chilling reminder that Australia has the highest youth suicide rate in the industrialised world, which I will elaborate on later.

These are the sad statistics of a decade of Labor government. It has, at a time of need, abandoned these young Australians when they are calling out for solutions. What is more, young ethnic and Aboriginal Australians are hit harder when it comes to unemployment, and the government simply does not care. We should be providing young Australians a future that they can look forward to. But, instead, this government has mortgaged their future and expects them to pay for it. I would like to know how. Neither this budget nor the employment white paper will provide any sustained and significant employment opportunities for young Australians. The financial and social consequences will be felt for many years to come.

One such social consequence is suicide. The rate of youth suicide in Australia is the highest in the industrialised world. For 15- to 24-year-olds, 16.4 suicides occur per 100,000 people. Research shows that, for every suicide, there are between 20 to 100 attempts. In fact, more young people in our country die by their own hand than in a motor vehicle. Yet, ironically, more attention is paid to motor accident deaths than suicide, even though fewer young people die by the car.

A recent article in the British Medical Journal quoted a historical study from 1907 to 1990 at the University of Sydney which showed that more than two-thirds of the changes in suicide rates in young men aged from their low to mid-20s are related to unemployment. Obviously unemployment itself is not the only cause, but the fact that unemployment causes low self-esteem, with people having nothing to do, crime, drug taking and other anti-social behaviour means that it is a prime cause of many problems that our society tragically has to face. This is an issue of major concern which the government must urgently address. I acknowledge the increase in funding to the national mental health strategy. Vitally important funding is directed to this area.

I do know that Lifeline made a submission to the National Health and Medical Research Council seeking funding for the organisation to work on a suicide prevention strategy. It is groups like this, and the Samaritan Befrienders in Perth, which are important to our community for the care they provide to those who are most in need. I therefore implore the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to direct more attention to this important issue and to listen sympathetically to these community groups who are actively working towards suicide prevention.

Finally on this topic, I must record my absolute dismay at the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to this issue. I was sitting in this place listening to the address in reply of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) when he said that `we have the highest rate of youth suicide in the Western world'. I distinctly recall the Prime Minister sitting across here laughing, to which the honourable member for Wentworth asked whether he was proud of such a fact. I think the laugh probably said it all. I think it is regrettable that Hansard did not record the Prime Minister laughing at the fact that we have the highest youth suicide in the Western world, for it would have shown the Prime Minister's true colours.

I know the Prime Minister often, when overseas, puts Australia down and criticises various aspects of our great nation, but for him in our institution of democracy to laugh at the fact that we have the highest youth suicide rate in the world is downright sick. Members opposite should hang their heads in shame for having as their leader a man who denigrates our nation and laughs at these very sad and telling statistics.

Further evidence that the Prime Minister cares little for Australia's youth is the fact that there is no minister for youth. They are an important national asset, yet the Prime Minister continues to neglect these young Australians. Last year the Australian Youth Foundation brought out a report entitled A lost generation. The report canvasses a vast range of issues of great importance to young Australians. It is a report worthy of a government response, yet nothing has been done about it, in spite of the fact that it has identified many issues the government should be addressing but has yet to do so.

I should add that I recently addressed questions to the Prime Minister asking why he has not appointed a minister for youth. I must say his answer was very disappointing. He said that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) is responsible for youth affairs, but obviously youth affairs are not important enough, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, to be given a portfolio. The interesting part is that the Prime Minister said it is not necessary to appoint a separate minister for youth because that responsibility goes across a number of portfolios. Why then does he have a minister assisting him on the status of women, when that portfolio also crosses a number of other portfolios, including health, ethnic affairs, social security, industrial relations and so on? The least he could do is give young Australians similar recognition and create a portfolio, if only one assisting him on the issue, for youth affairs. Any less will be to give a slap in the face to young Australians, as this government has consistently done to them for the last decade.

I now turn my attention to our health system, which has many problems with it. The former shadow minister for health and family services, Senator Newman, put a lot of work into this area, and I was very saddened when for health reasons she announced her resignation from the shadow ministry. I would like to pay tribute to the hard work of Senator Newman and her staff, and I wish Jocelyn well for a speedy recovery.

One issue I am concerned about is our growing hospital waiting lists. This is a problem that has existed for quite some time now, and it will continue to be a major problem for the government if it continues to try to appease the left wing of its party and ignore the commonsense and logical way to help solve the problem of our growing waiting lists. My office is often contacted by concerned people who are victims of our failing health system in that they, or one of their family, must wait to get into hospital for elective surgery. Presently there are 120,000 people awaiting surgery. They each have a problem which needs to be attended to, and more often than not they must wait a minimum of six months before they can have surgery. One lady who contacted my office had a cancerous lump growing in her throat, a gentleman required a hip replacement, while another required surgery on his kidney. All of these people are in a considerable amount of pain. They are not at all well yet, because of Labor's ideological hang-ups, they must wait great lengths of time before they can get into hospital.

Surely those members opposite, even those such as the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who lack the commonsense to realise the problems with our health system should be sympathetic enough to show some compassion and put aside their own ideological beliefs and agree to some necessary changes to our health system to cut down on these appalling waiting lists.

I realise that a sum of money was directed to Western Australia to fund more operations to cut the size of our waiting lists, but that will not fix the fundamental problem that still exists with the system. It is only a bandaid measure and, when we rip the bandaid off—that is, when the money runs out—there will still be a gaping hole that needs to be fixed.

I notice that the Prime Minister, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), the Assistant Treasurer and many others in the government do not have private health insurance. Instead, they rely on Medicare, which each taxpayer must contribute to, so that many people earning far less than those opposite are contributing to the health insurance of those opposite who believe in an antiquated ideology. In essence, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Human Services and Health, the Assistant Treasurer and any others opposite who do not have private health insurance are sponging off overburdened taxpayers and systematically ruining our entire health system.

Medicare was in principle a good idea. It was set up to ensure that there was some protection, in the form of health insurance, for lower income earners. It was introduced to ensure that those who could not afford private health insurance were protected from excessive medical bills. Unfortunately, those who could afford private health insurance decided to opt out of their private insurance and rely on Medicare. This meant that excessive demands were placed on the health system, with only limited funding; hence the waiting lists. If you look at the make-up of those waiting lists, you will notice they are the lower income earners, pensioners and social security recipients who cannot afford private health insurance. Indeed, the former Minister for Health, then Senator Richardson, said in a speech to the New South Wales ALP state conference last year:

SPEECH.PARA: If the drop that is in private health insurance participation rates continues at any rate like it has been, over the next few years, it won't be long until there will be enormous pressure on the public system . . . We've got to look seriously at how to get the numbers in private health cover up.

The then minister followed that up a month later by saying that people dropping out of health insurance `push the battlers to the end of the queue'. The former Minister for Health has admitted that change is necessary. It is now time for his rhetoric to be matched with action from the government. If the Prime Minister falls ill, he can afford to go into a private hospital and pay for himself, if the wait is going to be too long. But he should be privately insured and not reliant on Medicare, given the fact that Medicare was set up to look after the lower income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will never be kept waiting. He is the Prime Minister.

—Exactly. If we took pressure off Medicare by providing incentives for private health insurance, a major burden would be lifted off the public health system, and that would ensure that those waiting to get into hospital do not have to wait as long, if at all. If the government continues down the road of no incentives, we will only see a higher Medicare levy, higher health insurance premiums and yet even longer hospital waiting lists. The challenge is on the new health minister to show some real leadership and take on her own party, and to accede to commonsense by providing incentives for private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: It is regrettable that such an initiative was not implemented in the recent budget. If the status quo prevails, our health system will continue its rapid downward spiral. Only today we learned that in the March quarter a further 115,000 Australians dropped out of private health insurance. In the past 12 months, 500,000 have dropped out; in the past three years, 1.5 million have.

I would also like to speak on the issue of breast cancer, which has been quite topical. Many residents in the electorate of Stirling signed petitions calling for greater funding for research into this awful disease. Just as important, of course, is the need for screening and so on. There is no doubt that the major media attention which shed light on this issue is a primary reason for this increase in funding. Therefore, it is also worth congratulating some individuals from this place for their bipartisan efforts in pressuring the government into increasing funding to this. I refer to the honourable members for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), Pearce (Mrs Moylan), Adelaide (Ms Worth), Indi (Mr Lieberman), Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith), Capricornia (Ms Henzell), Forde (Ms Crawford) and Macquarie (Ms Deahm).

I notice that the Prime Minister gave all the credit for this funding increase to his wife, and I think that is a great slap in the face from the Prime Minister for four of his own backbenchers. I recall watching the debate on a motion from the honourable member for Cowan, and the thrust of the debate had unanimous support. It was the efforts of these eight members in particular which was a contributing factor to the increase in funding, and I think it is wrong of the Prime Minister to misdirect the praise from these members to his wife.

I will conclude by commenting on the budget in its totality. I think it is farcical for the government to say it has kept its promise of not increasing taxes, when we have the tax increases announced last year still to come in, coupled with the increase in revenue from present taxes. In particular, there is an 8.1 per cent increase in PAYE tax and a seven per cent increase in company tax—which, together, add $4.5 billion to the government coffers—and then a whopping 131 per cent increase in fringe benefits tax.

This budget continues in the tradition of past Labor budgets, in that it continues the deception and the dishonesty and it squanders some perfect opportunities to act like a real government and make some necessary hard decisions. Many in the media have said it was a boring budget and an election budget—which really means a decisionless budget—a budget which should have offered hope and held out a hand to those who have been left out in the cold by Labor for the last decade. Instead, it just kicked them in the guts a little harder.

The Labor Party has given up on the Australian people. It has decided it is unable to make proper decisions and, as a consequence, the Australian people must wait for a Downer government before they will get real leadership, correct and proper decisions, and no more squandered opportunities. I look forward to being part of a government which reunites our great nation and redelivers the opportunities that have been lost under this directionless and disgraceful Labor rabble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron), like that of most of those on the other side, was made entirely without reference to the state of the economy. On a day like today, with the release of the national accounts, I would like to start by making some points about economic growth and by describing what the current state of the economy is. These points are worth putting on the record, if only for the edification of honourable members opposite. Let us see where some of our current economic settings are and how they are conducive to continued strong economic growth.

PARA.TAB: Inflation remains at its lowest level for three decades. It is less than that of our major trading partners. Inflationary expectations are low. Interest rates are at their lowest level since the 1970s. Business confidence is high. In the manufacturing industry, business confidence is at its highest level for 30 years. Consumer confidence is at its highest level for 10 years and is at near record levels.

Productivity is increasing markedly and has increased over a period of time. Real unit labour costs have declined over the last decade. Profit share is at a near all-time high. Our international competitiveness continues to improve; it is now 30 per cent greater than it was a decade ago. Time lost in industrial disputes in 1993 was the lowest for 30 years. Our economic growth over the course of 1993 was four per cent, which is far better than in most other relevant industrial countries, which on average grew by about one per cent.

These are the economic conditions which obtain at present and which are relevant in very many respects to the most important aspect of the economy, which is growth. One aspect which is obviously very important to growth in the economy is the presence of incentives to invest in the Australian economy. It is important to list some of those measures which, in addition to the general economic parameters, currently exist as incentives for business to invest.

In the course of the last couple of years, the government has put in place a series of major incentives for investment which, over the course of the financial year 1994-95, will effectively provide $3 billion worth of incentives for business to invest. Some of those measures are the accelerated depreciation rates which were included in the One Nation statement, the development allowance for large projects and the more general investment allowance, the 150 per cent research and development expenditure write-off and the cut in company tax rates from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. I note in passing that at the last election those opposite wanted to increase company tax rates from 39 per cent to 45 per cent and include a 15 per cent GST.

In addition to that, the Working Nation and budget statements mention improvements made to the pooled development funds arrangements and also to the infrastructure bonds as incentives for investment. These are significant economic conditions and significant incentives for investment. I also make some comments in respect of the budget forecasts of our economic prospects. I refer to the budget speech of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), in which he said:
Our immediate prospects are for even faster growth.
Real GDP is forecast to grow by 4 1/2 per cent in 1994-95, compared to 4 per cent in 1993-94.
Employment is expected to increase by 3 per cent, or almost another quarter of a million jobs.
The unemployment rate is forecast to fall to around 9 1/2 per cent by June 1995.
Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index is forecast to remain low next year at 2 1/4 per cent, or about the level of our major trading partners.

SPEECH.PARA: With the release of the national accounts today we can see that those forecasts are certainly being met, if not exceeded. The percentage change of GDP from the March quarter 1993 to the March quarter 1994, in seasonally adjusted terms, is five per cent.

PARA.TAB: The trend estimates are worth commenting on. The trend estimate of gross domestic product increased by 1.2 per cent in the quarter to March 1994. The trend estimate of gross domestic product, average series, has increased by 4.3 per cent since the March quarter 1993. The trend estimate of all three independent measures—income based, expenditure based and product based—has grown in each of the last 10 quarters. The trend in gross domestic product as it is averaged, per capita, has increased in each of the last 10 quarters, after declining for the previous two years.

In addition to the national accounts, I refer to an article in today's Australian Financial Review which is headed `Small business shrugs aside economic woes to generate jobs'. It is a report by Nicholas Read on the latest yellow pages small business index which makes the point that the small business sector is still surging ahead as a source of job creation:

SPEECH.PARA: The latest Yellow Pages Small Business Index, a quarterly survey of 1,000 small businesses nationwide, said the sector had employment growth of 2.1 per cent in the last quarter and 3.1 per cent in the past six months, half of the total rise in employment recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
The report goes on to make the point that my own state of Western Australia had:

. . . led the nation in small business employment growth during the last two quarters, with 19 per cent of the State's small business proprietors increasing their numbers of employees in the most recent quarter.

It then goes on to make the point that following Western Australia in that area of growth is the state of Queensland. I refer also to the first paragraph of Budget Paper No. 1 to make some points about the budget deficit and the Working Nation statement. The first paragraph of the budget paper says as follows:

The budget deficit for 1994-95 is estimated at $11.7 billion, some $1.9 billion below the outcome now expected in 1993-94, notwithstanding the substantial measures announced in Working Nation to deal with the Government's foremost priority, unemployment.

What that refers to, of course, is the government's continuing commitment to ensure that we return to a low deficit and meet our commitment of a deficit of around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. That in a sense completes the circle of those economic parameters which the government is committed to: low deficit, low inflation, high growth, high productivity and high wages. At the same time, through the Working Nation package, we meet our commitment to what I regard as our most pressing social and economic problem, which is Australia's long-term unemployment.

PARA.TAB: As far as honourable members opposite are concerned, their solution to the long-term unemployed was to throw them off the dole after nine months, to slash $800 million from outlays directed towards the unemployed, and to slash wages. This is the policy to which those opposite were committed.

I draw the House's attention to some of the key aspects of the Working Nation white paper which mark a stark contrast between the approach of those opposite and the approach of honourable members on this side. There are real incentives for business in the Working Nation package, including increased access to capital for business, particularly small business; the suspension of the training guarantee levy; a training wage for juniors and adults; reform of the CES and private competition for the CES; a more effective government purchasing policy; and increased access to research and development tax concessions so small business can develop good ideas. Those measures are, of course, designed to maximise growth and are in addition to the job compact, which is intended to break the cycle of long-term unemployment by providing work experience and training for the long-term unemployed.

The compact will provide a guaranteed place for every person who has been unemployed for over 18 months through the provision of the training wage, private sector job subsidies, new self-employment opportunities, public sector work experience and training schemes, new work opportunities in the community sector and, finally, help for all unemployed young people in obtaining training and job placement immediately after leaving school. That is the array of methods which those on this side of the House are committed to.

Given the change of leadership of honourable members opposite, we on our side are entitled to ask whether those policies to which the opposition was committed at the last election are constant today. I refer to them again: tipping people off unemployment benefits after nine months, slashing $800 million from outlays directed towards unemployed people and slashing wages through the opposition's so-called training wage.

There are a number of points to make about the leadership changes opposite. Firstly, the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) were, of course, handcuffed to the Fightback package; they committed themselves entirely to it. It is worth drawing the attention of honourable members opposite to some of the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Stirling, in respect of the new Liberal leadership team. In the Sunday Times of 19 May, an article which bears the honourable member's photograph states that a Liberal backbencher from Western Australia described the new Liberal leader as a `fuddy-duddy'. In the Australian on Monday, 20 May, the honourable member for Stirling is quoted as saying that he is opposed to the ascension of the new Leader of the Opposition because `no-one in Western Australia knows him.'

Given that we have the new Leader of the Opposition and the new Deputy Leader of the Opposition trying to pretend that they are policy sheep in wolves' clothing, it is worth drawing attention to some of the comments that have been made about the new Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Canberra Times of Monday, 23 May, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Costello was devastated when he convincingly lost the deputy leadership after the election to moderate fellow-Victorian Michael Wooldridge. To this day, he finds the result impossible to comprehend.

PARA.TAB: The reason for the result is a combination of adverse reaction to his style, and deep fears about his right-wing views and hard-Right party connections . . .

His deeply conservative social beliefs and let-the-market-go-for-it economic views have also made it more difficult for Costello, than Downer, to soften his image amid the party's return to the centre.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many Liberals found Costello's rhetoric frightening and reactionary.

So, despite the effort of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to pretend that the policy has changed, here we find the real wolf in the sheep's clothing. The Weekend Australian of 9 April 1994, in an article on the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, refers to his unsuccessful attempt to wrest the deputy leadership on a previous occasion, and says:

When he said, during his campaign for the deputy leadership after the last election, that he had always had a strong interest in social issues, one Opposition frontbencher quipped that "saying Peter Costello had an interest in social issues is like saying Dracula is a vegetarian".

So it is quite clear to those on this side that the hardline policies continue to range supreme. I was very interested to see reference to the Victorian Premier describing the Deputy Leader of the Opposition as `dog'. I assume that, rather than a wolf in sheep's clothing, we are now entitled to refer to him as a rabid policy dog in sheep's clothing.

PARA.TAB: I want to draw the attention of honourable members to some of the other changes in personnel that have occurred on the other side of the House. We on this side awaited with great expectation the arrival of the former Senator Bishop in this House as the honourable member for Mackellar. We have seen her performances in recent days, and they have been the subject of some comments which are worth drawing to the House's attention. In the Sydney Morning Herald today, in an article entitled `Bishop's speech puts a chill in the House', Geoff Kitney says:

Two months after making the move which could have propelled her into the Liberal Party leadership, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop has made her maiden speech to the House of Representatives amid concerns that she may have difficulty holding on to a senior position on the Opposition frontbench.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

. . . Liberal MPs expressed disappointment last night, contrasting it unfavourably with the maiden speech of the new Liberal MP for Warringah, Mr Tony Abbott, which he made soon after Mrs Bishop's speech.

So the first speech of the honourable member for Mackellar to this House has gone down like a lead balloon. That endorses the view of the editorial of 1 June in the Australian. Under the heading `Ms Bishop's poor performance', the editorial says:

PARA.TAB: When Parliament resumed this week, the shadow health minister, Ms Bronwyn Bishop, only deepened the existing doubts about her substance and performance as a politician.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on:
Can she be an asset rather than a liability for Mr Downer? It seems doubtful, judging by Monday's performance in Parliament.

That also seems very doubtful, given the views of the electors when she fronted up to the poll in Mackellar. But I was intrigued to see that honourable members opposite preferred the contribution made by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott). I noted in his speech that the honourable member for Warringah referred to Mr Bob Santamaria as having `sparked my interest in politics'. Given that we now find the intellectual basis for some of the new entrants to the other side resting with Mr Santamaria, I thought it worthy to draw the House's attention to a contribution that Mr Santamaria made in the Weekend Australian of 18 and 19 May. Mr Santamaria, the philosophical parent of the honourable member for Warringah, said:

The Liberal Party is thrashing around in what may merely be another of the familiar leadership struggles, or alternatively, the party's "last hurrah". Those who think it is all a matter of John Hewson's leadership are mistaken.
He went on to say;
As far back as 1988 John Howard suggested the Liberals should go down the line of a family policy. Fully six years have passed. Nothing has happened.
He concluded by saying:
Changing leaders without essentially changing direction will get the Coalition nowhere.

On one occasion I had the good fortune to hear a longstanding member of the opposition, and a quite prominent member of the opposition, make the point that in the good old days of the Liberal Party, when the DLP was around, all that the Liberal Party candidates had to do was slip in their nominations and the work was done for them.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably for those opposite, times have changed. It is not enough simply for those opposite to put their nominations in and handcuff themselves to Fightback. It is time that they started to take the view, which we on this side of the House take, that Australia does have the capacity under our policies to become a high growth country, a high employment country, a low inflation country and a high wage country. These are the things to which we are committed; they are not the things to which those opposite are committed. Essentially what those opposite are committed to is the proposition that the solution to any economic ill is to slash the wages of those who work for a living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) might have addressed some of the more serious issues in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the serious issues that the budget has for Australian people rather than take cheap shots at the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop).

PARA.TAB: However, I am going to talk about the appropriation bill in relation to small business in Australia. In the third annual review on small business in Australia, the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development—the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths)—and the then Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, prefaced the report with the following comments:

SPEECH.PARA: A pressing goal for Australia in the 1990s is to ensure that we encourage and support a dynamic and successful small business sector, with an emphasis on export-oriented internationally competitive firms.
The last eighteen months witnessed important developments which clarified the economic significance of small business in Australia, and led to increased support for the sector's development.

Strategies to reduce unemployment must now take into account the contribution of small and medium enterprises to job creation, and further improvements to the business environment in which small and medium enterprises operate remain a priority.

Certainly there are measures taken in this budget by the government which have been a welcome relief to some in the business community but, coming off such a low base, frankly any crumbs from the table would have been welcome. The government has simply tinkered at the fringes, lacking the courage to make real inroads into policies that will drive strong and resilient businesses and markets in Australia by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: In discussing the budget implications for small and medium businesses we must link them to the white paper. Despite the government's rhetoric about the priority it argues must be given to small businesses, the reality is that the government did not give them any priority when it set up the task force to look at ways to reduce unemployment.

The committee consisted of bureaucrats and academics. I do not for one minute dispute their ability and their vast knowledge, but I would have thought that a government serious about finding jobs for 900,000 unemployed Australians would have taken note of its own rhetoric and included some prominent business people and organisations on that committee. It may have given some policy direction to reforms that will contribute to strong growth.

In the 227 pages that this government devoted to Working Nation, only 28 pages in a chapter called `Industry Development Policies' were directed at the small business sector. The fact is that apart from some measly crumbs, that document, the white paper, offers very little in terms of real hope for growth and expansion in the private sector. It has the potential to turn Australia into a nation of the best trained unemployed—a training nation rather than a working nation.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Monday during question time, in answer to a question from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), crowed about the increases in profit for Australian companies. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition will see that the level of profitability in Australia at the moment is well beyond the late 1980s experience, which itself had no historical precedent, . . . why would there be investment? . . . because profits have never been higher, principally, because there is demand in the economy.

The Prime Minister knows that profits do not necessarily equal investment. It may be correct to make the assessment that profitability is well beyond the late 1980s experience, to a point which has no historical precedent, but it came off an historically low base, and one would expect that from that low point any growth would look good.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's claim that profit equals investment is refuted by the Investment Monitor, which shows that profit is not being ploughed back into development of business in Australia; it is going offshore. Overseas projects in which Australian companies have an interest have risen from $9.5 billion a year ago to $37 billion today. That is a huge amount of Australian profits going into overseas investment.

It is no good foot stamping and scolding business for looking for the most attractive investment options. We have spent a decade lecturing business on efficiency and on the need to become internationally competitive. As I said earlier, the rhetoric is cosy but the reality is crass. In an article in the Business Review Weekly on 16 May 1994, Ed Shann pointed out that, if unemployment is to be reduced to five per cent by the end of the decade, as the Treasurer has suggested, Australia needs to grow at four to five per cent a year until then. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be great news for the share market if this happened, but you do not grow rapidly just by wishing to do so . . . The budget assumes a rise in business investment of 14.5 per cent in 1994-95. But business investment needs to sustain annual growth of 10 per cent for each of the five following years if Australian output is to grow by an average of 4-5 per cent a year for the rest of the decade . . . In investment terms we need a miracle. In the past 25 years, Australian business investment has not achieved double-digit growth for two calendar years in a row. To sustain output growth of 4-5 per cent a year this decade, we need business investment to rise in double digits for six years in a row . . . Australia is still putting hurdles in the way of investment . . . Supply side reforms are the key . . . Australia has to keep reforming the labour market, improving the tax system, lifting the efficiency of transport and public enterprises and reducing bureaucratic red tape on project approvals.

Yesterday during question time the Treasurer went to great pains to explain all the measures in the budget that are helpful to business. When we analyse those measures, we see that they pay little more than lip-service to a sector of Australia that holds the key to improved prosperity for all Australians and the key to funding sound social policies for those unable, through no fault of their own, to participate as employers or employees. There is little in the white paper or the budget to encourage long-term growth.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the small and medium business sectors are not asking for government handouts. Their main expectation is for a stable, reasonable policy that sustains a steady rate of growth, not the knee-jerk reaction approach to economic policy that sends interest rates skyrocketing to levels such as those experienced in 1989-90, driven largely by ill-conceived government policy, when interest rates lifted from 12 to 24 per cent within a very short space of time.

Businesses which had geared up with big expenditure on capital equipment to meet the high demands for the two preceding years were caught short by a policy that increased costs to an unsustainable level and decreased demand. Unable to withstand the onslaught, a record number of Australian firms went into bankruptcy. Hundreds of decent men and women lost the businesses they had sunk their life's work and savings into but, more devastatingly, it too often meant the loss of the family home, along with all the ensuing social upheaval. The Prime Minister, whose policies as Treasurer paid scant regard to the needs of small and medium business, has the gall to scold the private sector for not investing enough and for not employing more Australians.

While, on the one hand, the government talks about efficiency in the business sector and internationally competitive industry, on the other hand, it seeks to increase its own housekeeping by over $1 billion in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1994-95. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) said yesterday in his speech to this bill, the government is selling the family silver to meet the champagne bills. And champagne bills they are, with Gould bird prints for the Prime Minister, a Thai teak table and a carport extension for the Lodge which cost more than most of us would pay for our homes, not to mention the squandering of taxpayers' money on the many mismanaged departments.

This year alone there were audit reports that were critical in their assessment of programs such as the sports rorts, which cost the Australian people $60 million; credit card scandals, which went into millions of dollars; and the failure of the national energy management program. The list goes on ad nauseam.

The last thing the business communities want from the Prime Minister is a lecture on their responsibilities to be competitive and profitable and to solve the nation's unemployment problem by employing people they do not need and cannot pay for. The simple fact is that if we want more employees we need greater investment and/or more employers. The answer of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to the problem of mismanagement of the nation's economy is to rip some more taxes off the people of Australia. The business sector cannot, with such ease, increase prices in an already price sensitive and competitive market. If it looks like making—dare I say it—a profit, the government sends the Prices Surveillance Authority to investigate its operations.

Against some of the small taxation concessions for business, the government's net gains will be much greater. With fringe benefits tax up by a massive 130.7 per cent, to $3,230 million in 1994-95, the government shows little real understanding of its own rhetoric about developing export oriented business. Some of my colleagues on the other side think that when developing export industries, people just fly off to another country with a bagful of samples tucked under their arm and sign up multimillion dollar export contracts over a cup of tea.

Fringe benefits tax has to be paid for food that the representative consumes in the course of a meal with clients and a detailed account must be kept, clearly separating the representative's consumption from that of the client. Of course, there are no tax benefits for the cost of the client's meal. I know that there have been some legitimate concerns about abuse with the free lunch syndrome, but any sensible government trying to help its business community develop export industries would recognise that the requirements for doing business in some countries involves these legitimate expenses and it would set sensible limits on tax deductibility for entertaining allowances as a business expense.

In addition, the budget expects to raise an additional $1 billion from improved compliance, which is a very handy euphemism for tax terrorism. On the cost of compliance with regulation, legislation, licensing and taxation, the government set up the Office of Regulation Review with a view to reviewing regulation at the Commonwealth level. The irony of this is that this Labor government, in 1991 alone, excelled itself by adding 6,905 pages of legislation to the statute books in 2,116 acts. This is almost as many pages of statute as the 7,544 pages passed in the 10 years from 1960 to 1969. Government regulation has cost the Australian economy dearly.

In addition, there is all the subordinate regulation passed to accompany the acts. Perhaps legislative activity rises as national prosperity declines. In any event, the government plans to expand this Office of Regulation Review. If it is anything like the Industry Commission, which is in the process of moving from Canberra to Melbourne, with a budget allocation of $5.7 million paid by the taxpayers for redundancy payments alone, then the small business community can be sure that it will not get value for money in the regulation area, or should I say in the supposed deregulation area.

What small business needs from government is economic strength and stable, healthy economic policies. It needs investment and savings—and Australia has a very serious problem on both accounts, with an investment performance that lags well behind our Asian trading nations. We have not seen such low levels of investment per head of population since the Great Depression.

It needs industrial relations reform that works from a base of win-win, not the pretence of industrial relations reforms evident in the new legislation which passed up the chance to move out of the realm of the troglodyte and into the light, an opportunity sacrificed for self-indulgence and self-interest and cosy deal making between the government and the ACTU.

In an article in the Australian on 25 May Alan Wood was talking about the problems that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) is facing in reforming the industrial relations legislation and in facing the need for industrial relations provisions into the next decade or so. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: But Brereton's fundamental problem is that he has been cast in the role of defender of a system of industrial relations that is doomed by the inexorable march of economic forces beyond his control.
If he has been inclined to doubt that, he should do so no longer. One of the last bastions of the old system has finally fallen to the realities of global economics in the 1990s.

The surrender came in an extraordinary speech that has been given nothing like the attention it deserves, presumably because it was delivered on Budget night, May 10, when the eyes of the nation were elsewhere.

The speech was the second annual Kingsley Laffer Memorial Lecture, delivered by the chief executive of the MTIA, Bert Evans. In it, Evans finally and irrevocably abandoned the centralised industrial relations system he and the MTIA have been leading defenders of and key players in, for nearly half a century.

The other things that this country desperately needs if it is to get its small business or medium business sector going is infrastructure development. We have seen a run-down in our programs to maintain, repair and develop a road system. We talk about our developing tourism industry and how important that is to our economy, yet we do not encourage our tourists to come and visit this country when we allow our road system to run down.

PARA.TAB: Other infrastructure developments need to take place. There are micro-economic reforms that have been talked about since the Prime Minister was the Treasurer and set into train the deregulation of the financial markets, the floating of the Australian dollar and made the point that we badly needed to follow that with micro-economic reforms. Again, we have seen a lot of rhetoric but very little substance in terms of real policy.

In summary, this budget sets up more bureaucratic red tape and more or expanded existing government agencies; it slams higher taxes on business and offers an economic policy that is destined to increase the cost to business overall. It is not all bad news, as many agencies have worked effectively to assist the small business sector, but for the Treasurer to claim that the budget provides benefits such as the $0.4 million over two years to improve Australia's 800,000 business's access to training schemes—which, by the way, amounts to $4 per annum per company or per firm in Australia—is stretching it a bit. It is time the Treasurer stopped gilding the lily and provided a budget that delivers real benefits to stimulate small business growth and the prosperity of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we are discussing the appropriation, what we are talking about is our priorities as a nation. The appropriations and the white paper this year set the scene for growth, for jobs, for higher living standards, and for a better distribution of wealth in our community. In short, we have the best conjunction of economic circumstances in 30 years. We have high profit share, high rates of growth, low inflation and low interest rates; but, despite all of this, there remains a steady diet of pessimism, particularly from the opposition. It is a pessimism, I might add, that is not shared by the business community that the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) was talking about before. In terms of reaction to the budget and the white paper from business, C.J. Stewart of the Australian Hotels Association said that the white paper initiatives `particularly provide for business to produce the jobs rather than solely depending on artificial government schemes'.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said about the budget that `this is a very different approach from the past which will do much to build business confidence'. The Australian Mining Industry Council said, `Thumbs up for the budget.' Bert Evans from the MTIA, mentioned before, has had this to say about the white paper initiatives:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a constructive contribution to public policy, one which provides new directions to industry policy while genuinely attempting to address unemployment.

Finally, the Business Council of Australia has said variously that the white paper is a `positive initiative towards addressing the problem' and `an important breakthrough to introduce a training wage for adults, particularly when this can be combined with a subsidy for those unemployed for longer periods'. The Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales said that `the job compact will ensure that a person's need to find a job will merge sweetly with an employer's need to fill one'.

PARA.TAB: The reason I talk about these optimistic assessments is that we get this constant diet of pessimism from the opposition. I think the opposition is in danger of being too pessimistic, and this may have unfortunate consequences in the community. We are in danger in our community, if we are too pessimistic, of passing this on to our children. It is a fact that Australians are great knockers, and this does enable us to keep a realistic perspective; but, if we are too pessimistic about our future and we constantly feed this back to our children, then our pessimism could well become a self-fulfilling prophecy.

One gets a sense of this when one listens to the opposition in this House, and in particular to opposition reaction to the extraordinary national accounts which have come out today, which give us a 5 per cent growth rate. The opposition simply cannot believe it, and wants to talk it down. It becomes too easy to believe that the future holds bleak employment prospects, or that the world has become a more polluted and violent place, and so on. The fact of the matter is that our prospects now are infinitely brighter than they have ever been. They are infinitely brighter than they were at the height of the Cold War. They are infinitely brighter than they were at the height of the Vietnam War and at many other controversial periods in our history.

The fact is that our kids and our community need to hear more than the pessimism from the opposition which is constantly telling them that they are going to inherit a world of very dark and bleak prospects. What we need to talk more about is the things that make this country a lucky country, the things that will allow this country to continue to grow and prosper. This is a matter which has been referred to recently by Hugh Mackay, in a book entitled The Middle Years, where he warned of the danger of the kinds of downbeat assessments that are coming from the opposition, and of the consequences of those downbeat assessments being passed on to the next generation.

Recently, I was talking to a parent about this matter and he said to me, `There is a real question mark about the quality of life in the future, and there is a danger that we are feeding this idea back to our kids.' That is what this diet of pessimism from the opposition can produce. It can well become a self-fulfilling prophecy, if the opposition does not honestly tell the people of this country the good with the bad, as they see it.

Fortunately, this question has been recently addressed by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Macfarlane. In a recent speech which should be compulsory reading for every member of the opposition, he spoke about the need to counter the sense of pessimism that some are peddling about Australia's future, because that sense of pessimism fails to recognise some of the very important factors that are running in Australia's favour. I am talking about the Jeremiah type of attitude that comes from the opposition in this House day in, day out. When we get low inflation, when we get low interest rates, when we get high rates of growth, the opposition comes into this House and tries to constantly talk down this country's chances.

The fact of the matter is that the sorts of fallacies that are coming from the opposition, and the sort of nonsense that was put forward yesterday by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), can have adverse consequences. The recent speech by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Macfarlane, sets about outlining the things that run in this country's favour, the things that will give us a much brighter and prosperous future; and there is so much that is going right in this country.

To assess what is going right in this country, we need to understand what has occurred in the past. A very important part of the speech given by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank is where he points out that the real deterioration in Australia's economic performance occurred in the 1960s and 1970s. That was the time when this country's performance fell well below that of the rest of the world. He argues, looking at an assessment of inflation rates, balance of payments and unemployment rates for the period of the 1960s and the 1970s, that the real period of deterioration of Australia's economic performance was in the 1970s rather than the 1980s. I would like to quote very briefly from the speech that he gave. The Deputy Governor went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: While economic pessimism reached its peak in the 1980s, it was a lagged reaction to our economic performance, which had its most serious period of deterioration in the 1970s. For example, if we look at the balance of payments, it is now clear that the period of deteriorating performance was from about the early 1970s until the mid-1980s. Since then, there has been a slight upward trend in the trade position and a stabilisation in the current account position.
And he argues similarly on inflation:

It is clear that the damage was done in the 1970s and the early 1980s. The average rate of inflation between 1973 and 1983 was 11.3 per cent, whereas in the most recent decade it has been about half of that, and over the most recent three years it has been less than two per cent.

He argues that we have made very substantial economic progress in the 1980s, that we have been dealing with the fundamentals of the economy and that the time when we had real problems in this country was the time when those opposite were actually in charge of the affairs of this country. Sure, we are going to have to work hard, but what he goes on to talk about in that speech are the things that we are doing right in this country and the things that are working in our favour.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, he makes the very important point that we are now, in terms of our economic development, for the first time in a couple of hundred years in the right position in the globe, that is, we are closer to Asia than we are to Europe and North America. That means that we can plug into the growth opportunities arising from Asia. Secondly, he points out that we run a balance of payments surplus with Asia, so we have a surplus with the fastest growing region in the world, and that is very good for the medium-term development of this country. Thirdly, he points to the phenomenal growth in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures in recent years. The lesson from all of this is that, whilst we must maintain our capacity for self-criticism, we cannot let the pessimism that comes from those opposite stifle what are very bright prospects for this country into the future.

That, I guess, brings us to a discussion of what are the policy alternatives. The government has put forward its priorities for the year ahead. But what sorts of priorities is the opposition putting forward? What is the policy option that the opposition is putting forward in response to the budget and the white paper initiatives? As recently as 16 May the new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), was quoted as saying that, while Fightback was dead and buried, aspects of it needed to be developed and improved upon. This is the same person that was criticising the Hawke and Fraser governments for being too gutless to introduce a GST. Now he expects us to believe that he has got rid of all the baggage of support for a GST and he no longer believes in Fightback. This is the same person who we have had masquerading on Four Corners as a nice, compassionate guy, a sensitive new age person out there with his little Victa mowing his 3,000 acres of lawn, pretending that he is somehow different from what he has been in the past.

The fact of the matter is that in policy terms he is a wolf in sheep's clothing, and we can see that if we look at some of the statements he has been making about the desirable levels of taxation in this country. He has been making statements that we should have Asian levels of taxation. Of course, if we were to adopt Asian levels of taxation, we would have to cut public spending in this country by somewhere between $11 and $30 billion a year.
I will quote what the honourable member for Mayo had to say in a speech entitled `Australia-East Asia: Comparison of Economic Performance 1988-92'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister will have to accept that the level of taxation in Australia is too high. It is a fact that spending levels in Australia are over twice as high as East Asia. Mr Keating should substantially reduce taxes.

So he is calling for a tax regime similar to Asia's. If we were to adopt Indonesian levels of taxation, that would mean cutting spending in this country to the tune of $12 billion a year. That would be the equivalent of cutting out all current spending on aged care. If we were to move to the level of taxation that they have in Taiwan, that would mean cutting public spending by $33 billion a year, which would mean abolishing all the expenditure on veterans affairs, $3.9 billion; assistance to families with children, $9 billion; assistance to the unemployed and the sick, $7 billion; and assistance to the aged, $12 billion.

PARA.TAB: That is the program that has been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition. He is trying to mutate from a hardline dry into some warm, compassionate, cuddly, middle-of-the-road politician. The truth is that when one looks at his past statements on economic policy it is clear that the opposition still favours massive cuts to public expenditure, the abolition of the industrial umpire, and so on.

We need to look at what has been said in recent days by the new opposition frontbench. It has not changed all that much: it is really yesterday's men replacing yesterday's men. We might have a few new spokes, we might have a new Leader of the Opposition, but it is the same old flat tyre. It is the same old bunch of people on the opposite side in this House advocating the same old dry Thatcherite policies that we have heard from the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and from all of yesterday's men who continue to rotate positions on the opposition frontbench.

Let us talk a little about the new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo. The honourable member for Mayo has spent something like a third of his life living in Great Britain. No wonder he is such an admirer of Thatcherite type policies; no wonder he is such an admirer of the Adelaide Club and the Melbourne establishment. When the Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and pretends to be in touch with ordinary families or when he goes on television and pretends to be in touch with the ordinary concerns of people, people should bear in mind that he is someone who could not be further from the needs, aspirations and concerns of the average Australian. That is why I concur with the recent assessment of the Liberal Party given by B.A. Santamaria in the Australian at the weekend. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is pre-eminently the party of new-rich practitioners of the money market, of property developers, of the rapidly growing gambling interests of alleged `entrepreneurs' and those who service them.
This new class does not talk the language of the ordinary people, by whose votes the politicians live or die. It has no community of interest or even contact with them.
Who could have community of interest or contact with ordinary people if they continue to spend considerable portions of their time at the Melbourne Club and at the Adelaide Club?

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the rest of the frontbench. It is supposed to be lean, but the opposition frontbench has still got 44 people on it. That is not lean—it is still four more than the government—but it is certainly mean. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), is affectionately known by the Premier of Victoria as `Dog'. If that is what his friends call him, what do his enemies call him? Is that some sort of reference to the fact that he would favour even more massive cuts to public expenditure than does the Premier of Victoria? Is that what the term `Dog' refers to? Does it refer to a much harder line in terms of public policy? Can we expect an even harder line from the honourable member for Higgins than we have already had from the Premier of Victoria?

Dr Hewson is now in the industry portfolio. This is the man who believes in zero tariffs and scares the living daylights out of any serious manufacturer. There is Dr Kemp in the employment portfolio who does not believe in labour market programs. We have got his brother Rod in the shadow ministry and he ran Margaret Guilfoyle's razor gang for Malcolm Fraser. Finally, there is Ian McLachlan from the slash and burn school of environmental concern. So what we now have on the opposition frontbench is the hard Right of the Liberal Party; there is one wet in a shadow cabinet of 19. There has been a substantial demotion of those who believe in middle-of-the-road policies, because something like 10 of Dr Hewson's former shadow ministers have been demoted or sacked. The bias is pretty clear.

How new is the frontbench? It is not very new; there are three former leaders of the opposition sitting there. In the armed forces when the generals retire they all head out to the private sector, but in the Liberal Party they stay in the command structure. More retired generals now are sitting along the opposition frontbench than there are in the whole Israeli army. It is a frontbench of yesterday's men replacing yesterday's men. Nowhere is that more the case than in the Queensland Liberal Party representation on the frontbench. Two former ministers have been replaced by two former ministers, and there has been a substantial reduction in Liberal Party representation from Queensland. In fact, the elevation of John Moore means less: Moore means less with the Queensland representation in the shadow ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member must refer to other members by their proper title.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—I am sure the honourable member is aware of that requirement and I would ask him to refer to the honourable member for Ryan in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will conclude by saying that this budget has much to commend it to this House and to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my inaugural speech in this place I spoke of a sea of human misery. I spoke of a girl working at a late night diner who told me that she had gone hungry because she had bought a few packets of fags and the budget for her and her little daughter did not allow for that. I spoke of this foreman in the banana packing shed who said to me, `I'll tell you Mr Politician Man, I see people going hungry regularly.'

PARA.TAB: The week before Christmas I stayed with a family whose first two generations in Australia had cut cane by hand. He rang up on Christmas Eve to find out if the bailiff had served notice and thrown his wife and daughter out of their house and onto the street. His wife cried on the telephone the day before Christmas!

The President of the local Cattlemen's Union in my home town committed suicide as the banks closed in on him. This country has the great honour of having achieved the highest rate of juvenile suicide in the world. Included in those people were two youths from my own beloved mid-west of North Queensland. One of them wrote in his suicide note to his elderly parents, `I cannot find a job. God knows that I have tried. I cannot live with being a burden upon you any more. Please pray for me. I love you both.'

A total of 750,000 Australian small businesses have gone broke in the last seven years. Over 1,750,000 Australians cannot find a job. Around 4,000,000 Australians are living in a land without hope, a land where everything they have ever hoped for and worked for has now gone.

The people who are responsible for what has happened in Australia are referred to in probably one of the best pieces of journalism that I have ever read. It was in the Bulletin and was written by Trevor Sykes, the magazine's long serving editor, in an article called `Wasters of the Universe'. He refers to 16 people in there who have effectively been responsible for blowing $22,000 million of Australian capital into oblivion. He names only 16 of them, but I will name another one today in this place.

In this country a very large proportion of the banking sector is public sector owned banks—the State Bank of Victoria, the Government Insurance Office of Western Australia, and the Commonwealth Bank, to name but a few. The losses to the taxpayers of Western Australia, as disclosed by the West Australian Inc. inquiry, were $867 million. The losses to the taxpayers of Victoria—and to a large extent they flow on to the Australian people—were $3,000 million. This was disclosed by the royal commission held in Victoria. The disclosures in South Australia showed $3,100 million.

So in three states, and almost exclusively from public banks, $7,000 million was lost to the people referred to by Trevor Sykes as the wasters of the universe. Sixteen of them were responsible for $22,000 million. There is no doubt that $30,000 million in this country was lost from the banking sector because of the high-flying speculators of the 1980s.

Today in this budget debate I would like to outline—the basis of the problems in Australia can be sheeted home to the loss of that $30,000 million—the mechanisms by which that $30,000 million was transferred from the pockets of the people of Australia into the pockets of the likes of the wasters of the universe.

When the banks lost this money they had to get the money back from somewhere. Treasurer Keating said at the time, `We will put interest rates up to 25 per cent.' He did not say, `Let us get it back from the high-flying speculator thieves' because, as we shall see, these people were the friends of the Labor Party, their cronies and their bankrollers. He did not say, `Let the banks go to hell, they should not have allowed this to happen in the first place.' If he had said that, then the banks might have gone after his friends.

The rich, those of inherited wealth, were not troubled by the high interest rates. In fact, it helped them; they had money invested. The people who were blasted were the little Aussie battlers who had, in the best Australian tradition, the guts to get up and have a go, whether to buy a house or start a business, to make decisions and take risks which created jobs for other Australians, to make a richer and more prosperous Australia.

We shall now profile what happened in Australia by taking a case study. For those who have criticised me, members of this parliament and members of the media, they might have had an excuse to do this before. Today they will lose that excuse. In 1986 in Queensland there was a most extraordinary purchase. It was extraordinary to me, who had served in the Queensland parliament and the party that ran the government for 21 years, in so far as a high-flying speculator from Western Australia, a one-time associate of Alan Bond, purchased something which, on the face of it, was absolutely worthless. They were the Shoalwater Bay mineral leases and the Fraser Island mineral leases.
