For 21 years Murphyores, a company which was very friendly with the Queensland government, tried desperately to get out of the Queensland government, the most development oriented government in Australian history—one thing we were never accused of was being greenies; we were called everything else but that was one thing we were not called—the right to mine. Yet no-one was able to get any right to mine in 21 years of fighting with the state government. But, because almost all of this land was federal government owned, it went also to the federal government.

None of those governments, whether it was the Whitlam government, the Fraser government or the McMahon government, agreed to allow mining at Shoalwater Bay, so there must have been good reasons why people were not allowed to mine Shoalwater Bay. But the extraordinary thing for me was that this high-flying speculator, who had a great reputation when he came to Queensland, purchased the world's greatest lemon. It was quite intriguing to me why this person did it. It was one of those things that one just files away in one's memory banks.

A little bit later on it became public that the same high-flying speculator—his name is Mr Peter Laurance—had $80.9 million written off. I will table all of these documents, Mr Deputy Speaker, if it is agreeable to you, in due course. I refer to documents 1 and 2. One is a letter from the liquidator to the Queens

SPEECH.PARA: land Minister for Tourism, Mr Gibbs, in which he says:
This is to advise you that the obligations the above individual, Mr Peter Laurance, and his companies had to Tricontinental Corporation Limited have been fully discharged.

I table also a statement of claim made by the liquidators of Tricontinental upon the companies owned by Mr Peter Laurance, which indicates that he owes $33.4 million, the Pivot group, and, operating as Q-West, $47.49 million. A total of $80.9 million was written off.

PARA.TAB: I wonder how many small business people in this country, farmers in this country, people who have lost their homes in the last 10 years, would have liked to have had $80,000 written off—not $800,000, not $8 million, not $80 million, just $80,000. But they have been bankrupted, they have had their cars taken off them, their houses taken off them, everything they have worked for in their whole lives taken off them, while this particular fellow, the last time I checked up, was doing a world cruise. It was in the papers that he has $1 million penthouse for which he has a $1 a year lease arrangement for the next 60 years. So he is able to get $81 million written off and still able to troop around the world and enjoy the benefits of $1 million penthouses, and we do not know how many of those he has scattered around the countryside.

Let me move on. A short time after Mr Laurance secures the Murphyores company, Graham Richardson is appointed minister for the environment with the power to turn Pivot's authorities to prospect, which is what it held, into an asset which, according to then Senator Richardson—and I table a federal cabinet document which people have been kind enough to give me; I will table them all—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member for Kennedy keeps referring to the tabling of documents. He has not followed the procedures of this House or the protocols seeking leave and so leave will not be granted as he has not given the common courtesies.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—The situation is that the honourable member cannot table documents without leave of the House. When he has completed his speech, I will give him the opportunity to seek leave to table them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wise enough to have heard me say that I was going to table all of them at the end of my speech. If honourable members opposite try to stop them from being tabled, that is their privilege. There will be many attempted cover-ups as this matter unfolds.

PARA.TAB: To continue, he had the ability to turn Pivot's authority to prospect, according to Senator Richardson in the federal cabinet document dated July 1990, into an asset worth $270 million a year. So this is a pretty amazing power that Senator Richardson has: he can turn a lemon worth absolutely nothing into something that, according to him, is worth—as it says in the cabinet document, I must emphasise—$270 million a year.

The important fact here is that the National Party in Queensland would not allow mining. The federal government, whether it was led by Mr Fraser or Mr Whitlam or Mr McMahon, had not allowed mining for 21 years. The reason for that is well illustrated. I refer to a document that I will in due course be tabling, which is the RAKES report. RAKES stands for rapid appraisal of key endangered sites. It was a study undertaken by Stanton and Morgan of the University of New England's School of Natural Resources in 1977, and it was undertaken for the Queensland government.

That study ranked all of the sites in order of heritage listing and found that Shoalwater Bay was the No. 1 ranked site in Queensland. It was ranked over the Daintree, over the rainforests, over the Great Barrier Reef, over everything. I venture to suggest that since Queensland has the barrier reef and the rainforests we can safely construe that that site was ranked number one in Australia. That is why even a government such as the one that I belonged to, which was almost fanatical about development—and our opponents accused us of that on many occasions—was not prepared to go in and mine Shoalwater Bay.

A great number of bodies were opposed to the mining of Shoalwater Bay. They included the Livingstone Shire Council, which is a very development oriented council of the National Party persuasion; Senator Richardson's own departments of administrative services, environment and tourism; and the Queensland Water Resources Corporation. I will table document No. 9, which is the letter from the Queensland Water Resources Corporation, which outlines the reasons why it was opposed to the development.

Other bodies were the CSIRO; the Department of Defence; the Australian Heritage Commission; the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation; the RAKES report, which I referred to before; the federal ALP member for the area; the local National Party MLA for the area; Mr Whitlam's government; Mr McMahon's government; Mr Fraser's government; the Australian Conservation Council; the RSL; and the Queensland Professional Officers Association, to name but a few.

In fact, I could name 53 bodies whose duty it was to assess this area and which assessed it as an area that was not to be mined. Incredibly, that list includes the Bureau of Mineral Resources. I refer again to the cabinet document which states emphatically that the Bureau of Mineral Resources says that there is a 98 per cent chance that the resource is non-viable. So the bureau said that there is no value in mining the resource. That is in sharp contrast to the statements of Senator Richardson. It is interesting to contemplate why he was making statements on the issue of mining which were so completely different from those of the government's own Bureau of Mineral Resources.

So we find that there was only one person in a position of responsibility in Australia who was for the mining of this resource, and that was Senator Richardson. This is quite extraordinary, because Senator Richardson was the man who went to North Queensland and made the World Heritage listing which put 1,000 timberworkers—and that is not my figure, it is Mr Hawke's figure—out of work. It closed the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric operation which was being built and which was scheduled to employ 1,000 employees that year. The Oyster Point development, with 300 workers, was also closed. So that was 2,300 people whom he had not hesitated to put out of work in that period, and yet here he is suddenly becoming a developer.

The Queensland government was never accused of being green, yet the king of heritage listings is about to mine an area that we would never have been prepared to mine. Why did Senator Richardson propose the rape and pillage, to quote the locals, of what a unanimity of scientific expert opinion, public opinion and every government—local, state, federal—agreed was the last pristine wilderness?

Why did Peter Laurance buy the world's greatest lemon? I ask myself why this super clever, super corporate high-flier wunderkind of the tourism industry, darling of the Goss government, is buying the world's greatest lemon, a parcel of authorities to prospect over a resource that could never have been mined in the past nor ever could have been in the future. However, if you knew that one of the most powerful men in Australia would decide to grant you mining leases, then you would have bought a resource not worth Senator Richardson's $270 million a year but, yes, worth maybe $90 million a year. I make the point to the House that Mr Laurance had already received $2.2 million for leases that were absolutely worthless on Fraser Island. If you had bought it for a veritable peppercorn—after all you already have $2.2 million—then you truly would be the prince of entrepreneurs. You would have bought something worth absolutely nothing, knowing that very soon it was going to be worth $90 million.

If you came out of Western Australia, where this sort of operation was regarded as standard operating procedure—after all, you were trained under Alan Bond and Brian Burke—this would be the way you would have been trained to do business. After all, he had the protection of Senator Richardson and made himself the super green hero of Australia over the broken backs of 2,300 workers in North Queensland.

I submit that what was always being done here was a scam for compensation, the same as was worked by the state government for Peter Laurance on Fraser Island. Firstly, I submit as evidence page 5 of the cabinet submission, document 4, attachment G, using Pivot Murphyores's own data:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bureau of Mineral Resources has established the profit from the mining lease to have a 98 per cent probability of being zero or less.

So the expert opinion of the government says that they could never make any money out of mining it. So why were they so determined to mine it, and why was the good senator so determined to mine it if his own government department—the Bureau of Mineral Resources—said it was not going to be making any money out of it? Of course, if the game was always for compensation, then it was a game that was going to pay people an awful lot of money.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the marketplace decided that the mineral lease was worth only $350,000 because that is what Laurance supposedly—and I emphasise supposedly—sold the Shoalwater Bay mining leases to Ron Sheehan at Western Australia for. He sold them for $350,000—that was all. Really that is nothing in mining terms. So the market opinion was that the leases were worth nothing as far as mining goes. I might add here that Ron Sheehan, in an article which is also being tabled here, agreed that he had been the beneficiary of a very good deal. When asked about the fact that he now had a very valid claim for compensation worth hundreds of millions of dollars, he agreed that he had been the beneficiary of a very good deal. I'll say! He bought something for $350,000 and had created a substantial claim worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

Thirdly, I table as evidence a document marked 9, a statement from the then director of the Capricorn Conservation Council. This is an extract from the notes she took at the time where she is quoting the AMIC environment consultant, Geoff Farnell:

SPEECH.PARA: Why weren't Pivot here at these field inspections? They are arrogant . . . and are looking for compensation. Companies like Pivot do no credit to our industry.

That was the mining opinion. So there was the expert opinion of the government saying it was worth nothing; there was the market saying it was worth a measly $350,000—and even that, I suspect, is a scam—and there was the mining opinion saying it was worth nothing.

PARA.TAB: Let me move on. Presumably other people in other places will be taking note of some of this material that we are putting forward here. I am switching subjects very dramatically here. I want to refer to a report from the Queensland special task force. This report reveals:

The Queensland Police—in conjunction with the CJC, the NCA and the FBI—have been undertaking a covert operation on the Gold Coast under the code name Wallah. This is a follow-on to a previous operation code named Hacker 6 which terminated on 27/1/93.
The purpose of operation Wallah has been to investigate the involvement of well-known Australian criminals in prostitution, money laundering, standover tactics and SP bookmaking on the Gold Coast.
One of the outcomes of operation Wallah—and as a continuation of information gleaned—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the honourable member wishes to seek leave of the House to table certain documents. Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's recent budget and white paper provide Australia with the opportunity to move towards the year 2000 to capitalise on the recovery and ensure that the benefits are shared amongst all Australians. This government is fully committed to ensuring that the levels of economic growth currently being experienced are sustained and built upon. It is a simple matter of fact that without sustained and high economic growth, jobs will not be created and unemployment will remain unacceptably high. What has been forgotten is that it was this Labor government that was responsible for generating 1.6 million new jobs between 1983 and the end of the 1980s. We did it then and we can do it again.

PARA.TAB: The economic settings are in place for continued high and sustained growth. GDP is growing at over four per cent, inflation is low at less than two per cent, and exports continue to grow strongly, being up 176 per cent over the last 10 years. Economic growth is already translating into jobs with over 170,000 new jobs created since the March 1993 election, well ahead of the government's commitment to creating 500,000 jobs over the three years of the current accord.

I believe that jobs growth will be sustained and enhanced. A study by the Department of Employment, Education and Training entitled Australia's Workforce in the Year 2001 has concluded that the economy is capable of generating about 1.4 million new jobs over this decade. This is a realistic goal and the measures announced in the white paper to encourage investment, improve business performance and enhance export growth will build on the strong base of international competitiveness we already have in this country.

A second fundamental point is that the white paper initiatives are also aimed at two other key goals—integrating the long term unemployed back into the labour market as well as ensuring skill blockages do not constrain economic growth. The white paper contains some innovative initiatives to achieve both.

The government will provide an additional $770 million over the next four years to expand entry level training places by 50,000 per annum, an increase of 50 per cent over current levels. These additional places will be created through expanding traditional apprenticeships and traineeships as well as creating new ones in areas such as the environment and community services. Enhanced incentives to employers will encourage the take-up of these traineeships.

In the lead-up to the white paper the government consulted widely with business and was greatly encouraged by the willingness of employers and their associations to work in partnership with the government to secure the expansion of traineeships. These discussions have led to initial pledges for traineeship and apprenticeship positions approaching 25,000 places. I am pleased to see a number of prominent Australian companies included on this list such as Coles Myer and Telstra. I believe that other companies such as the National Australia Bank, McDonald's and the Sportscraft group are intending to expand trainee numbers provided that their current Australian Vocational Training Certificate System pilots are successful. I would encourage other companies to examine their current training arrangements and make similar commitments. As well, a number of major Australian companies are already trialling the new AVTCS pilots thereby demonstrating their commitment to the training reform agenda.

The government's decision to suspend the training guarantee levy is based on the expectation that employers and employees will continue to meet their training responsibilities. The government is prepared to abolish the TG provided that employers take up the additional training places funded in the white paper.

The government has also reached agreement with the ACTU on training wage rates. The new rates will be available whether or not wage subsidies apply or the person concerned is long term unemployed. The rates will apply if approved training is undertaken on or off the job.

Under the terms of the agreement with the ACTU the adult training wage rates will be linked to skill levels. These rates represent 80 per cent of the key award base rates determined by the 1989 national wage case minimum rate relativities decision. In addition, a new simplified wage structure for youths undertaking training will be implemented. Unlike adult training wages, youth training wages already exist. However, they are confusing—some do not operate, they are aged based and often inconsistent with minimum rate relativities.

The new structure simplifies the rates but delivers more flexibility and enterprise relevance in the training. The rates will be training and experience based, not age based. In all cases, the training required to qualify for the rates must be approved and lead to portable qualifications, and normally would be expected to equate to about a day's training a week.

There are thus two distinct streams with separate qualifications: wage subsidies based on the level of disadvantage, and training wages which relate to approved training. They can be accessed simultaneously. Combined, they can result in a cost to employers of as little as $10 per week, but the individual will get a job, training that leads to a qualification, and secure an award based rate of pay.

In order to get industry behind the training wage and to provide a new mechanism for fast-tracking the approval of companies' training programs, Nettforce will be established. Nettforce will work with employers to secure industry commitment to providing training and work placement opportunities for the unemployed and will build on the success of the Fox-Kelty initiative. It will also be responsible for providing interim approval of companies' training programs where there are delays or impediments.

Nettforce will be chaired by Lindsay Fox, a man who has shown his commitment to helping the unemployed get jobs and to convincing employers that they have the capacity to be able to employ more people. I attended a business breakfast in my electorate at Cranbourne last week and Mr Fox was the guest speaker. He called upon employers to see what they could do to provide jobs and support initiatives to address unemployment. Mr Fox quoted Henry Ford, the American industrialist, who said, `If you think you can, or if you think you can't, you're right.' This means that if society is prepared to be positive, the scope is there to succeed. If not, we will indeed continue to have problems of a greater magnitude than the circumstances require.

The overall economic fundamentals are there to encourage investment and economic growth. The white paper goes further in assisting employers to take up the challenge. The white paper contains a number of important initiatives to better service employers' recruitment needs and make service delivery more demand driven and responsive to industry needs.

These initiatives include 300 dedicated employer servicing units to deliver a consistently high-quality service to employers; CES officers will be placed in industry associations to provide better access to programs and to promote the new initiatives; 60 area consultative committees will be established to ensure CES service and programs complement regional development initiatives; efforts will be made to cut the red tape by reducing the paperwork burden for business; and $5 million dollars will be provided to address the special recruitment and training needs of small business, including advice on accessing programs and group training schemes.

Employers are concerned that many of the long-term unemployed are not `job ready' because they have been disconnected from the labour force for a considerable period. The government recognises industry concerns in this regard. It has designed the job compact to provide for case management to get people `job ready'—provided either by the CES or private providers—a choice of potential employees, and a trial period to ensure that an employee is suitable for the position.

In order to improve the quality of service to employers and the unemployed, and to get better job matching, the government will introduce competition for the CES. Case management and job placement will be provided by community and private providers as well as the CES. In order to ensure fair and open competition, a new independent regulatory body, the Employment Service Regulatory Agency will be established.

Dramatic changes in the labour force over the last 30 years mean that low-skilled jobs are no longer readily available for school leavers. Teenagers are often disadvantaged in competing for newly created jobs because of their relative lack of work experience, skills and qualifications. The white paper package addresses this by providing improved vocational preparation through two new initiatives, the youth training initiative and the establishment of the Australian student traineeship foundation.

These initiatives will lead to an improvement in the quality of young people entering the work force. The youth training initiative, YTI, will ensure that every young unemployed person has access to a suitable education, training or work experience opportunity.

The YTI will provide case management for young unemployed people who have been without work for 13 weeks. Case management involves an initial assessment of skills and knowledge in key areas as the basis for job placement or further training. Where a job is not immediately available, a training agreement will be developed to assist the person into the work force. Access to a range of training programs will be possible under the scheme. The training provider will generally be accredited and will provide young people with a basis on which they can build further training at a later date.

Currently, the curriculum for upper secondary school students is primarily oriented towards the needs of higher education. However, only approximately 30 per cent of school leavers go straight on to higher education. There is a need to provide upper secondary school students with greater choice in preparing for their post-school careers. In particular, there is a need to broaden the opportunities for young people, to prepare them better for work and to improve the school to work transition.

The ASTF will be charged with the responsibility for forging closer links between industry and school programs. The government will provide $38 million over four years for this. The ASTF will allow school students to combine their studies with work based learning and off-the-job training. Students will obtain a leaving certificate that recognises the vocational component of their schooling. The national program will build on a number of successful ABCTS pilot and state programs already under way.

Critics of the white paper raise a number of issues, many of them already canvassed today by those opposite. We hear that the unemployed do not need more training; they just need jobs. This shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the circumstances faced by many unemployed people, many of whom lack appropriate skills to compete for vacancies in the job market. We hear that we need real jobs, not traineeships. Of course we need real jobs. I said earlier that 170,000 jobs have been created since the 1993 election, and it is clear that we will exceed the 500,000 jobs over three years target—a target the opposition said was impossible.

The other point regarding traineeships is that about 80 per cent of trainees so far employed had been kept on subsequent to the subsidisation concluding. Real jobs are being created by giving employers the chance to utilise traineeships, and the unemployed the opportunity to prove their potential. We also hear from the opposition crocodile tears regarding the social impact of unemployment, but it is manifestly from its own policy positions, at least those that we last knew of, that the unemployed would be in a more disadvantaged position under a coalition government.
We also hear that the government is going on a massive spending spree. I quote from Tim Colebatch of the Age in an article which appeared on 5 May 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: The white paper is not the best we could do to bring back full employment. But given the political pressures on Labor to avoid tax rises and hold down spending, it is a pretty good second best.

PARA.TAB: It has seen the Canberra bureaucracy do what it does best: target new spending tightly to the areas seen as priorities for Australia's long-term economic development—and make the system a little fairer on the side. There is a quicker way to restore full employment: raise taxes on those with jobs and use the money to employ those without. But the Government, fearing the political costs, declared it would raise taxes only if the community was in favour. And clearly it was not.

Instead, we have chosen the long road. Jobs will come back via the normal business cycle, the improved competitiveness, the flexibility in export focus of Australian firms, by low growth in real wages and by ensuring that the long-term unemployed do not become unemployable.

Despite the Opposition's rhetoric, the white paper is offering cheap solutions to big problems. For 1994-95, its new spending adds up to $49 per person for employment and training, plus another $4 for industry, $2 each for regional development, science and income support, and $1 for trade. Total cost: $60 per head. That spending will peak at $100 per head in 1996-97. A spending spree? Let's get real.

SPEECH.PARA: As Mr Colebatch basically said, the white paper is not a quick fix option. It will not end unemployment tomorrow. But it was not intended to do so, nor is that objective really possible or practical. However, it does put in place an integrated, targeted program designed to facilitate the continuing economic recovery and to ensure that economic, and therefore jobs, growth continues. It will assist the unemployed to be better able to compete for vacancies and therefore more likely to get a job. It provides real incentives for employers to employ those who have been out of work for a long time.

PARA.TAB: It will improve the operation of the CES and develop other forms of assistance to help place unemployed people into real jobs. The social security changes will encourage people to seek work and will remove disincentives within the system. The regional development initiatives will facilitate local regions to maximise their local advantages and help put them into a position where they can move forward and assist in job creation.

Unemployment is a worldwide problem; it cannot be fixed overnight. The white paper provides an opportunity to put Australia in a position to address it over time. We would all wish to remove the plight of unemployment tomorrow, but it is not going to be that easy. We certainly will not see the unemployment problem solved by the coalition. Its approach of massive spending cuts and benefit reductions will increase the hardship that it presently decries.

We have an opportunity through the white paper—an opportunity to move forward as a nation to address long-term problems with lasting solutions. We owe it to the nation to take that opportunity; we owe it to the next generation of Australians. If employers and the community as a whole embrace the opportunities presented in the white paper, we have a good chance of succeeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address just a couple of comments that were made by previous speakers. The honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) made great play of the new frontbench. He mentioned that it had not actually been reduced, as was claimed. I remind the people of Australia and perhaps the government as well that it has the facilities of government. I also understand that in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet alone there are literally hundreds of people at the Prime Minister's beck and call. When we compare the resources available to government and the resources available to the opposition, it is scandalous to think that members of the government are going to criticise us for the way we organise our frontbench.

PARA.TAB: I remind the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin), who has left the chamber, that the government claimed some years ago that it was going to reduce, or eliminate, Commonwealth debt, but we discover in this budget that over the three years leading into June 1995 the Commonwealth government debt has gone from $30 billion to what will become $95 billion in June 1995. There is only one group which is going to pay for that—the Australian people. So let us get Australia's debt into context.

I come to the main purpose of my discussion here today, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1994-95. At the risk of reviving the tobacco debate, I want to focus my budget response on the subject of health hazards. Simply put, I think this government is a health hazard to the Australian people. The slogans `Labor is a health hazard' and `Labor is injurious to your health' should be displayed on the sides of buses. Labor reduces our economy's fitness and in doing so reduces the fitness of the Australian people. One has only to listen to what people are saying and take notice of surveys, such as the recent ABS survey, to see how much sicker our society is becoming as a result of Labor policy.

We see a youth suicide rate which is amongst the highest in the world. We see one million people unemployed and another million willing to work if jobs were available. We see an increasing reliance on charities, even by people who are in employment and people who are home owners. We see the highest levels of welfare dependency in decades. In 1973, 13.5 per cent of Australians over 16 received a government benefit. By 1993, this number had increased to 33.1 per cent.

We also see an increasingly large gap between the rich and the poor. The top 10 per cent of earners have seen their incomes rise by seven per cent since 1983. My electorate of Grey contains many of the bottom 10 per cent of income earners even though it produces 50 per cent of South Australia's exports—such is the reward for exporters that this government claims to be providing for so well. The bottom 10 per cent of income earners have seen their real wages fall by five per cent. The government may well point out a myriad of programs which give $2 extra to a single parent here and a dollar extra to a pensioner there, but it cannot dispute the increasing gap between rich and poor, because the facts are there in black and white.

Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recalled his favourite fairy tale: the coalition would abolish unemployment benefits after nine months. For some months now the Prime Minister has been playing the game of trying to convince the Australian people that at the last election the coalition was going to abolish unemployment benefits. It is just another of the Prime Minister's more blatant untruths. This was not the policy which the coalition took to the previous election. The coalition abandoned this policy suggestion, as it is clearly allowed to do—just as the Labor government did this week when we witnessed its recent backdown on the industrial relations legislation.

In reality, Labor has left the unemployed behind. Labor has been in government for 11 years. Let us not forget that. That is ample time for a government to introduce policies to get the economy on track and to look after the wellbeing of the Australian people. What do we see? We see the kind of social dislocation which the ABS survey highlighted in a community and in a country which has prided itself on its egalitarianism and fairness.

Labor's damage to Australia has been compounded by the 1994-95 budget, the so-called soft budget which supposedly does not raise taxes. The government breathed a sigh of relief when the budget received a relatively calm reception last month as compared with the debacle of the previous budget. We all remember when most members of the caucus trudged down to see the Prime Minister and the then Treasurer to get a whole range of things altered.

From the outset in this year's budget there was substantial doubt about the budget's predictions and its heavy reliance on growth in business investment. This doubt has grown every day as we await business investment. Doubts about the budget predictions will not be silenced by the Prime Minister's attack on banks, financial markets, business or any other group which he wishes to blame. The blame lies solely and squarely with this government. Labor has been in power for 11 years and, at the end of its term, it will have had 13 years to solve the issues of Australia. There can be no-one else to blame. Labor must eventually run out of scapegoats.

Earlier this month the Australian Financial Review described the budget as `a bit like applying the accelerator to a car coasting gently downhill'. I add that, as we coast downhill, the government is fervently hoping business can be made the scapegoat again. However, business does not appear to be coming to the party. Who can blame it? What has this government ever done for business, except lumber it with its industrial relations legislation? I am glad to see the government is approaching a backdown on the new legislation. The government lumbered business with a training guarantee levy—another backdown; I guess the government is learning something—the fringe benefits tax, the superannuation guarantee levy and all the rest of it.

Let us come to the budget's commitment to regional Australia. A total of $70 million over three years is earmarked for a regional infrastructure fund and $80 million over three years for a regional best practice program. That is very good but, considering that the government will reap an extra $1 billion from the increase in fuel tax in the coming year, with $400 million coming from the tax on diesel, I would have thought it could have managed something a little more appropriate for regional electorates. After all, Labor can manage $50 million for a new flag.

If we combine the $80 million and the $70 million for regional Australia over three years, it amounts to one-third of what the government is prepared to spend on regional Australia—one-third of what it is prepared to spend helping our regions grow, helping our regional families regain some prosperity and helping regional Australia attract investment. My electorate has a great reliance on exports, particularly agricultural exports. Farmers, if they are lucky, earn half the average income. We are currently facing a drought, so it will be considerably less than that. Twenty years ago farmers earned double the average wage. That is the way the government rewards exporters, particularly those in regional Australia.

So Labor will spend $150 million on regional Australia while, at the same time, it will spend $50 million doodling around with our flag, playing with new designs and presumably trying to sell the idea of a new flag to the public. So it is $150 million for regional Australia versus $50 million for a new flag which we are not sure anyone really wants. Would anyone say this is a fair comparison? Would anyone say this is a fair deal?

How does the Labor government explain this to regional Australia? How does it explain its priorities? The answer is this: the government does not explain anything to regional Australia. It stays well clear of regional Australia. The government sent Bill Kelty to discover regional Australia. Old Bill wandered around out there. He had probably never been there before. He came out from Melbourne and probably needed a very good road map. He produced this lovely coloured report, went back to Melbourne and then waited for Canberra to consider his great wisdom. Canberra quickly buried his findings.

Regional Australia waited for the government's response to Kelty's task force report, the government's statement on new policy directions for regional Australia, and the industry report. What did we get? We got Working Nation. If there is any title which sums up the hypocrisy of the Labor government it is that title. It would have been more aptly described as `Training Nation'. Training, training and more training is all this government has to offer our unemployed. Training helps prepare people for jobs and training is integral to our becoming a competitive nation. However, this government is simply recycling people through training course after training course, moving them on to different government benefits and generally shuffling the figures and biding time, hoping the unemployment problem will go away.

How about some other titles for Working Nation? Perhaps we could call it `Stagnation' or, in regional Australia, `Indignation'. We are really a waiting nation. We are waiting for this government to get its act together, introduce real reform and generate jobs. Unfortunately, 11 years is far too long to wait.

Regional Australia continues to wait for some meaningful support from this government. This budget is a political budget and an election budget. In this budget, the government concentrates on grabbing votes rather than creating jobs or attending to a myriad of other problems it has created. Unfortunately, for regional Australia there are not many votes outside the cities; there are more votes in metropolitan Australia. There are also the swinging votes held by interest groups to think about. This government loves those swinging voters in the special interest groups. That is why the budget made some big bang announcements.

One big bang announcement was the Aboriginal land fund. I am the first to advocate greater attention to Aboriginal issues in this country. However, this government's policies for Aboriginal Australia are plainly inadequate. I spent all of last week in the Pitjantjatjara lands in the north-west corner of my electorate. This is not the first time I have visited the lands and nor will it be the last. I met many Aboriginal people who are struggling to build up private enterprise and achieve greater self-development. But this government is still intent on treating them like a welfare case.

This 11-year-old government has clearly been unable to go any way towards resolving the problems faced by our Aboriginal communities. An example is the recent report on water in Aboriginal communities entitled Water: a report on the provision of water and sanitation in remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The report simply says that the government still has not got the water supply right. The government has not even got the water supply for Aboriginal people right!

It has been acknowledged that the main barrier to achieving an adequate water supply is political correctness. We have heard a little about political correctness lately. This government has been too immersed in being politically correct by giving Aboriginal communities the supposedly best water supply system to notice that the best systems are not the right systems. The government has been too concerned about giving Aboriginal communities water systems which are the same as non-Aboriginal communities, because everyone is equal, rather than giving Aboriginal communities what is relevant.

This is one story from the report. An Aboriginal community was given a new water system with a new you-beaut filter system. Unfortunately, a member of the community died. The community members, for religious and cultural reasons, left their home site for about two weeks. When they returned, their water system had broken down. This occurred because the filter had been allowed to dry out while the community was away. It became brittle and, therefore, broke. If government representatives knew about the community's habits and lifestyle, this would not have occurred. This sums up the government's whole attitude to Aboriginal communities. Doing what is politically correct will salve its conscience. The conscience of the politically correct brigade is more important than doing what is right. So it is with the Aboriginal land fund.

The Pitjantjatjara people have their land now. They have had it for over a decade. They are still struggling for self-development. They still need encouragement and incentive to achieve the development and enterprise which they aspire to. This government is simply too busy treating them like a welfare case to give them that encouragement and incentive. Other big bang statements included the breast cancer funding—which some say would have been better directed to existing establishments—the money for the Daintree and the money for our olympic athletes. They are all very worthy causes but clearly are targeted towards certain groups in the community.

I come back to the environment. The Labor government is interested in a republic. In my electorate is Lake Eyre and the Lake Eyre catchment area. The government wanted to put it on the World Heritage listing, which effectively means locking away the land. World Heritage listing is something out of the United Nations. It is something created by good intent—we would hope—but it is created by many people who would not even know what a democracy was. Yet this organisation has the right to suppress my electorate and to suppress people whom I represent—to kick them off their land! Is that social justice?

I will not talk about the International Labour Organisation, but I think it is time that the government looked at running this country for Australians rather than simply running it from Geneva or some other comfortable international position. The budget is simply a political document. It does not address the real needs of Australia. It will not solve the problem of the two million unemployed or give the two million unemployed people jobs. It will not start to address our savings problems and get on top of our Commonwealth debt. The budget is like the white paper; it is a document which is aimed at appeasing the Australian people while the government continues to wreck the economy. Therefore, I say that Labor is clearly Australia's most serious health hazard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper, the kernel of the budget, is a monumental effort to tackle the debilitating effects of unemployment. It provides some hope for those youths only staying at school due to the stark job picture. It enunciates and diversifies job and training commitments for the long-term unemployed. It encourages the jobless to exploit the increasing part-time opportunities through a modified earning allowance for unemployment benefits, widens incentives for employers to hire and retain people, sharpens Australia's overseas trade effort and makes tentative industry policy gestures. Additionally, it introduces the parenting allowance and makes each member of the married couple a separate, distinct entity for social security purposes. These are realities in Australian society that receive overdue practical recognition.

PARA.TAB: It has been claimed by the opposition that these moves are largely a sleight of hand to manipulate jobless figures. Admittedly, particularly in the context of yesterday's contribution by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) and her rather egocentric attempts to associate herself with the former British Prime Minister, the actions of the Thatcher and Major governments in Britain, where they have changed the definitions of `jobless' and `unemployment' 40 times to engineer cosmetic unemployment changes, provide an interesting parallel. However, the evidence is convincing that these initiatives and changes owe more to extensive study of the labour market.

Most particularly, these initiatives acknowledge the extensive growth of part-time work, which has been even more pronounced in Australia than in the United States, and the reality that these jobs have been disproportionately flowing to females and, more particularly, the spouses of the already employed. We thus find that in the OECD countries the proportion of women between 15 and 64 years of age within the labour force grew from 53 per cent to 60 per cent through the decade to 1990.

A relevant part of the 1994 World Labor Report cites a New York study which discovered that between 1977 and 1989 the proportion of men reporting significant conflict between work and family responsibilities increased from 12 to 72 per cent. We thus have a variety of factors evident here and overseas which are the driving force behind the changes the government has now introduced. These are ground swell changes, they are not a cynical exercise to disguise unemployment and underemployment. In Bruce Chapman's January 1994 paper entitled `The case for policy reform', he succinctly commented:

SPEECH.PARA: A fundamental point concerning the desirability of the Job Compact is that to be effective the arrangement must ensure that members of the targeted group are brought back into the world of mainstream work for periods extending well beyond the duration of the initial employment experience. Without this distributional benefits will be temporary only, and the medium term gains to the economy peripheral.

Measures in the budget go beyond this. It contains more than speculative efforts to tackle this situation. The refashioning of duration and maximisation periods of wage incentives are crucial for employers. An initially higher subsidy to overcome predictable doubts about the long-term unemployed due to stigmatisation is followed by a $500 bonus when a person has been employed for a year. Equally, the emphasis on skills is crucial given the acknowledged growth in wage disparities according to skills and education and the reality that Australia's opportunities lie in these sectors of employment.

PARA.TAB: These positive attractions to employing the long-term unemployed are accompanied by a radical alteration to wages with the introduction of training related schedules for both youth and older unemployed people. Understandably, the ACTU has been guarded in its approach to this issue, mindful of the widened possibility of abuse that can emerge. In the past there has been a questionable level of vigilance by government instrumentalities in relation to labour market subsidies to employers. This is typified in the largess shown to companies such as ADT Security, which received $437,000 in jobstart subsidies in 1992-93.

To all intents and purposes this was manipulated to give this company a distinct competitive advantage over other legitimate employers and destroyed the morale of hundreds of enthusiastic citizens who were hired in the process. How many of the 183 people hired are with the company in 1994? I predict that the CES has little interest in this issue. The desperation of the times and the lack of broader take-up under previous schemes dictates the need for some experimentation now. Let us hope that the union movement's willingness to recognise the national need is met with public service attention to the possible downside.

The efforts of the CES to be more receptive to industry needs should leave minimal grounds for complaints and inaction by employers. There will be 300 dedicated employers servicing units with a staff of 1,600 to deliver quality service. Officers will be situated within industry associations to widen knowledge of program availability. An effective instance of where this is already in place is the Local Government and Shires Association in New South Wales. Greater attention will be directed towards matching the unemployed with specific employer needs. Account specialists will seek to provide individual service to employers.

The latest Department of Employment, Education and Training overview of the western Sydney region again highlighted the pronounced concentration of non-English speaking background people in the Auburn municipality. In the 1991 census they amounted to 42.8 per cent of the population. This is twice the level of the entire Sydney region. Similarly, Holroyd and Parramatta continue to have proportions in excess of the average. This in turn is crucially related to the unemployment pattern. It was again shown in the April quarter that the central west region had an unemployment level of 16.9 per cent compared to the Australian average of 11.1 per cent.

It is also of relevance that the central west region, encompassing these three councils, with a level of 6 1/2 per cent for English speaking migrants significantly trailed the Sydney picture of 12.1 per cent. Widespread analysis has highlighted not only that deprivation, that job and training access disadvantage faced by non-English speaking background people, but also the reality that English speaking migrants tend to fair far better in the labour market than Australian born citizens. These are intrinsic to the disgraceful unemployment picture in our region caused by the interrelationship of a lack of developed networks within factories and workplaces, non-acceptance of qualifications from overseas and the primary importance of English skills.

On behalf of my electorate, I commend the strong statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which signalled that we should direct our efforts towards local skill formation rather than migration. The 1990s have witnessed an important and commendable reassertion of the need for Australia to profit as a nation from migration. Family reunion considerations lose nothing by also seeking people more likely to be employed. This has been occasioned by the reorganisation of the points system to give priority to those relatives who have higher levels of skill and youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Given today's stronger than expected growth rate and the increases in bond rates which occurred as an immediate reaction to that, does this now confirm that official interest rates will rise in the near future, notwithstanding the Treasurer's statement to the contrary yesterday? Can the minister confirm that Australia is now heading for a high interest rate recovery?

—No, I will not confirm that because it is a ludicrous proposition. As well as excellent growth coming through in these figures, which I am very glad to see that you conceded, there is also an extremely low inflation rate. Whilst the ground is there for a very substantial increase in business investment, that is yet to come through. All the indications are there that it will come through. Recently, the ACCI-Westpac survey reported, for example, that capital utilisation in business was at very high levels, higher levels than in the 1980s. Profits have increased by something like 130 per cent since the nadir of the recession in 1991. In that period there has been an increase in capital expenditure of only some four per cent.

PARA.TAB: So there is nothing in any of these figures which suggests that an interest rate rise is anywhere near likely in the immediate future. The Treasurer pointed that out in his remarks yesterday and he pointed it out again at his press conference today. So the concerns of the Leader of the Opposition ought to be allayed by that. This is a growth out of recession, the like of which we have not experienced in the past—at least not for some considerable time in this country.

The normal factors that would cause pressures for interest rates to rise, which are in very large measure delivered by an anticipation of a substantial increase in the rate of inflation, simply are not there. So I am pleased to be in a position to set the Leader of the Opposition's mind at rest on this matter. No doubt he will subsequently be able to report in his briefings to the media and others what I have been able to say to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Could the minister tell the House of the outcome of today's meeting between the government and the ACTU and of the continuing benefits of the accord to all Australians?

—It could only be termed a sensational outcome. It is in every way great news for Australia and great news for the working men and women of Australia who will benefit so greatly from it. In keeping with accord mark 7, the government has today agreed with the ACTU that we will jointly seek access to a safety net wage increase of $8 not before 1 July 1994, with a further $8 not before 1 July 1995. The increases will be available only to those workers who have made a genuine effort to achieve an enterprise agreement but who have failed. Access to the safety net adjustments will be staggered to limit their economic impact and to keep the focus where it should be—fairly and squarely on enterprise bargaining.

PARA.TAB: To further advance the accord's social justice element, we have committed ourselves to negotiations with the ACTU about a number of ways to assist the family. In this context, we will consider introducing a maternity allowance paid through the social security system. This will be done in the spirit of ILO convention 103 dealing with maternity protection.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind members of the provisions of standing order 55.

—That is another outstanding objective in a convention that I think we can all be very proud of. You are all quiet now, aren't you? The key elements of the accord are jobs growth, as well as the maintenance of low inflation. Today's agreement reinforces both of those goals. It is now more than 10 years since the first accord. It has delivered low inflation, sustainable and equitable wage outcomes, historically low levels of industrial disputation, and a cooperative approach which has seen the lifting of productivity and a much wider emphasis on enterprise bargaining—all the things that you hate to acknowledge.
—One in 10 out of work. You're a fraud!
—The honourable member for Fisher!
—Every Australian has benefited personally from the accord.
—And a hypocrite.
—It has delivered higher standards of living—
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. The honourable member for Ballarat will withdraw that comment.
—Mr Speaker—
—You will withdraw the comment.
—Your predecessor, Mr Speaker, said that `fraud' and `hypocrite' are not unparliamentary.
—You will withdraw the comment.
—If you find it offensive, I will withdraw it.

—Every Australian has gained personally from the accord. It has delivered a higher standard of living through increases in pensions, family allowances and wider access to superannuation. That is in great contrast with the policies of the opposition and its performance when in government. It left us with double digit inflation and with double digit unemployment. That was the opposition's record in government. We had a record level of industrial disputation in 1983 and, of course, the most confrontationist of industrial relations systems.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The fundamentals of question time which you have referred to in some remarks recently are short answers giving information. We are now getting a written speech which would be much better applied in the appropriation debates to which the minister has access. He can go on rabbiting. We are not taking any notice. He is a fool. But I would like him to save our time.

—There is no point of order. The member for O'Connor knows the appropriate way in which to approach the dispatch box on that particular matter. The minister is entirely in order. The minister has indicated he has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Given that the government ignored warnings by the Reserve Bank to make greater progress in reducing the budget deficit, will he, in the light of today's national account figures, be forced to lift interest rates to curtail inflationary expectations, and will that be a further disincentive to business investment?

—I have been trying to work out why it is that the honourable member for Kooyong and the Premier of Victoria refer to you as `dog'. I think the reason must be the basset-hound-like appearance that you present at the dispatch box when you come forward here; they had a more unkind version, I understand.
—The minister might come to the answer.
—That question, Mr Speaker, was a typical—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister has the call.

—That was a typical `the glass is half empty' question, with the presentation of those national accounts figures. There is nothing in these national accounts which ought to cause anyone to anticipate a rise in interest rates any time soon. There has been a very substantial fall. There is no requirement for there to be any lift in short-term interest rates arising from any of the matters that have been revealed here—in the current account deficit figures, in the inflation rate, or in the growth rates.

PARA.TAB: This constant effort to talk up interest rate rises is, I suppose, something akin to the typical performance of the opposition when interest rates are coming down. The opposition opposed every single step in the process by which interest rates went down. If the opposition predictions were correct for these account figures today, we ought to be talking about the second quarter of a double dip recession. The simple fact of the matter is that we are not.

In so far as these figures indicate anything for interest rates, it is for the interest rates that are of most concern to business and, for that matter, home buyers in this country to stay down for the foreseeable future. The very sensible answers that were given yesterday on this matter by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are exactly the sorts of responses that ought to be made to your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the government recently announced changes to the income security entitlements of older women, in particular for widows aged over 50 years? Can the minister provide details of the new measures?

—I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for her question, and I acknowledge her ongoing concern for the position of women in this situation. This morning I announced a number of new measures that are of relevance to women who are widowed, divorced or separated, who are over the age of 50 and who have no recent work force experience. This follows from some of the consequences that we have experienced as a result of the decision made in 1987 to phase out the so-called widows B pension. This was a pension which was payable initially to women over the age of 50 who had no ongoing caring responsibilities; that is to say, they were not looking after children, not caring for a disabled relative or were not themselves disabled.

PARA.TAB: The basic premise behind this decision—which, as I have said, was made in 1987 and which, I might add, was supported by the opposition—at the time was basically to shift the assumptions that we make about women's participation in the work force. The fact is that there has been a major transformation in recent years in the degree of female participation in the work force. Taking women in the 45- to 54-year age group, around 70 per cent of single women and around 65 per cent of married women are active work force participants—and that represents a marked shift from a few years ago. I guess that means the idea that in the work force we have women who are considered to be dependent simply by virtue of being women, irrespective of whether they have caring responsibilities or not, was seen by the government, and is still seen, to be an anachronism.

But, having said that, we have to recognise that many such women have grown up with a set of expectations about their role. The fact is that the experience of the phasing out of the widows B pension has shown that a number of such women have experienced significant difficulties, particularly the older ones. With the way the phase-out operates, the woman has to be over the age of 50 as at July 1987 to qualify for the widows pension. Effectively, that has raised the qualifying age each year until now it is 56 years and 10 months.

A number of my colleagues, particularly the honourable member for Capricornia and also the honourable member for Macquarie, have drawn my attention to the serious difficulties that many such women, who have had no recent work force experience, have had in re-adapting to the work force. I think we have to take cognisance of that. In recognition of that, I announced a number of new measures this morning.

In particular, we are introducing a new widows allowance which will be available as a non-activity tested payment for women who have become widowed, divorced or separated over the age of 50 since 1987 and who have no recent work force experience. They will be able to receive a payment equivalent in rate to the JSA or newstart rate but without the activity testing and work testing requirements that attach to those payments. That new payment will come into force from 1 January next year. In the interim between now and then, we will be relaxing the reporting requirements necessary to qualify for JSA or newstart for women in that category.

In addition, we are not saying to those women that we just expect them to go into a state of quasi retirement; we will continue to encourage and facilitate such women entering the work force. In order to give effect to that, we will be making access to the highly successful JET, jobs education and training program, which is currently provided predominantly to sole parent pensioners, and which is a demonstrably effective form of assistance to help such people gain access to the work force—that is, people who have no recent work force experience and who are experiencing significant difficulties in coming back into the work force.

I think this measure will significantly alleviate the position of such people without compromising the overall objective that the government was seeking to achieve. The age at which people will be able to qualify for this new widows allowance will be frozen at 50 for the next 10 years. Thereafter, the qualifying age will rise by one year each year. That will bring it effectively into conformity with the eligibility conditions for the new non-activity tested partner allowance available for the spouses of unemployment recipients over the age of 40 and, again, without recent work force experience. I think we have to acknowledge that some of those people have difficulties. We have taken cognisance of that. A number of my colleagues have expressed serious concerns, and we have taken those concerns on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the minister to his comment reported in this morning's press that he is a `pay by results operator'.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bennelong is trying to get to his question.

—I also refer to Mr Sharkey's comments yesterday that the CFMEU felt `angry' and `betrayed' because it had not got value for its half a million dollar contribution to the ALP at the last election. Has Mr Sharkey been ripped off? What results is he entitled to expect for his half a million dollars? How much more does he have to pay for the results that he thought he was buying in the first place?
—The honourable member for Bennelong should not come into this House trying to misrepresent Mr Sharkey or anybody else. He should not attempt to defame Mr Sharkey or this government.
—Did you get the $500,000?
—The honourable member for Bennelong has asked the question.
—Or it didn't go to the ALP. It went somewhere else, did it?
—The honourable member for Bennelong!

—If the honourable member wants to ask me a serious question about the matter I announced in this House on Monday I will be more than happy to answer it. But I would think that the record of this government—
—Who pays?
—Would you just wait for the answer? I would have thought that the record of this government in taking steps, as we announced this week, to ensure that daily—
—Taking steps or something else.
—I warn the honourable member for Bennelong.

—hire employees in the building industry were not impeded by the TCR standard, which was imposed as a result of the Industrial Relations Reform Act, by introducing amendments next week to clarify that situation so that there is no double-dipping in the building industry is the best possible proof of the soundness of our relationship in terms of industrial relations and in terms of making sure that we have an orderly system that is in the best interests of productivity and decent industrial relations.
—Why didn't you conclude that before you started?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—If the honourable member wants to ask me a serious question I will be more than happy to answer it. But the fact is—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left! I have remarked before that ministers are entitled to be heard in silence. Has the minister concluded? The Minister has concluded.
—Mr Speaker, I was on my feet at the dispatch box and he was sitting down.
—I was looking down.
—You were deliberately ignoring me, Mr Speaker. I have the call.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat! You are certainly not easy to ignore.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. What steps is the government taking to ensure that the report of the Access to Justice Advisory Committee leads to genuine reforms to the legal system and real gains in access to justice for Australians?

—Honourable members and, I think, the general public would have some right in feeling somewhat cynical about another report about the necessary reforms for the justice system and improved access for ordinary Australians. Indeed, I think we could probably fill a small law library with similar reports over recent years. But what the Access to justice report does is, in effect, examine the work of these other reports. It looks at the best practice of new initiatives being taken in a range of other jurisdictions throughout the states and at the Commonwealth level and at reforms being undertaken in the legal profession itself.

PARA.TAB: It endeavours to put together a comprehensive but practical plan for reforms which would improve the way our justice system operates.There are 70-odd recommendations which canvass the role in which government operates, the way in which our legal aid system operates, the structure and best operation of the legal profession and the role the courts should play in the reform process.

Some commentators have said that the report is disappointing. I noticed in yesterday's Financial Review a piece by a Mr Bruce Donald, who said that really all the Commonwealth should do is pass a single piece of legislation essentially nationalising, if you like, the legal system. This conveniently neglects to recognise the fact that Australia effectively is nine separate legal systems: the Commonwealth, the six states and the two territories. There is no single line of authority, no one government that is responsible for or that can take command of the reform agenda. In essence it requires a cooperative approach by all governments, by the profession and by the courts. Unlike reports in the past, I think there is now some ground for optimism that what is needed—and that is a sense of consensus in terms of achieving reform—is within grasp.

We have seen the legal profession, particularly through the Law Council of Australia, undertake a very significant push towards getting a truly national legal profession. That aim is being well progressed. We have seen a number of states undertake their own reforms, most recently a package announced today by the Attorney-General of Victoria, Mrs Wade, outlining a range of reforms which are fully consistent with the recommendations in the Sackville report. We have seen very significant reforms recently in the state of New South Wales. I understand that the state of Queensland shortly will be bringing forward its own package. So I believe we have the background circumstances for there to be truly cooperative action across the states and the Commonwealth and with the courts and the profession to see some significant improvements.

For its part, the government has acted quickly on the Sackville report. I have already announced a six-step plan in terms of the implementation of the committee's recommendation. Immediate steps which the Commonwealth can take, such as the examination of the tax deductibility of legal expenses, will be started shortly, as will a reference to the Law Reform Commission about the cost indemnity rule. The Attorney-General's Department, which is a major purchaser of legal services in this country, some $12 million annually, has taken steps to use its market power to provide a better informed legal market in terms of the cost of services. All these measures will go towards improving our legal system. But it will take goodwill and cooperation. The Commonwealth is certainly willing to play its part. I certainly believe the legal profession is. I now call on my state colleagues and other Australian jurisdictions to play their part in this vital reform process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Voluntary Redundancies: Telecom and Australia Post

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the minister: is it a fact that within both Telecom and Australia Post voluntary redundancies are only available to employees who are union members or, not being union members, who agree to pay on some occasions up to ten years of backdated union membership dues as a prerequisite to receiving voluntary redundancies? How does the apostle of anti-discrimination defend this highly discriminatory practice?
—Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —These are my responsibilities. These redundancies are available to all. The general rule is that we make sure that involuntary redundancies are used as a last resort. That is good industrial relations. The fact is that involuntary redundancies can be used, but they are rarely made access to because that is the best way to run industrial relations. We do not want to run a stupid set of industrial relations principles that the opposition would proclaim, whereby people are thrown out at short notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the minister aware that at the National Congress of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia held in Canberra last weekend the problem of post-traumatic stress disorder was once again raised as a major issue within the Vietnam veterans community? Can the minister inform the House what measures the government has put in place to address this condition which affects many of our returned veterans, particularly Vietnam veterans?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for her question. Indeed, I am aware of her interest in Vietnam veterans issues generally and am looking forward to going to her electorate in September to attend a very major function of the Vietnam Veterans Association in the Blue Mountains. I am aware that the question of PTSD was very much in the minds of the people at the Vietnam veterans congress, which was held here in Canberra on Saturday and which I had the pleasure of officially opening.

PARA.TAB: Post-traumatic stress disorder is an anxiety disorder with symptoms which include: flashbacks and dreams of the traumatic event often accompanied by feelings of worthlessness, isolation, difficulty in concentrating, rage, survival guilt, and other forms of alienation and avoidance. It is a chronic condition. It is not something that can be cured. It is a condition that needs to be properly managed. It is a condition that for some time not many people knew much about. It is only in recent times that sufficient scientific evidence has become available to show just how serious this condition is.

I understand that approximately 15 per cent of Vietnam veterans, who form the bulk of our younger veterans in this country, suffer from this disease. In the United States the number is as high as 50 per cent. It has become a very major problem not only for the veterans but for their families. Last week in the West Australian there was an article about the 19-year-old son of a Vietnam veteran, who was diagnosed as having secondary post-traumatic stress disorder. It seems that after one of his regular fights with his father, he stole a fire engine and arranged to deliberately crash it. It concerns me that we have an extension of this disorder. It is no longer just the veterans but the veterans' families who are suffering. The incidence of breakdowns in family relationships amongst Vietnam veterans is very high.

As a result of budget initiatives, some $20.6 million has been appropriated to my department over a period of four years to look at questions such as this. Last week at the repatriation hospital at Heidelberg I had the pleasure of opening the PTSD unit. It is headed by Professor Philip Morris—I am told he does not smoke, either—who is very well known in the PTSD field. We are going to set up a national centre which will get all the appropriate information together and diffuse it into the major cities and the major regions around Australia. The emphasis will be on rehabilitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going to become a bureaucracy.

—No, I am quite happy to talk to the honourable member for Farrer about that and see if we cannot do it in such a way that it will have the greatest effect on the people that it is supposed to help. There will be a great emphasis on rehabilitation, and I think that is important—not only in terms of providing people with work prospects, getting them back on their feet and giving them a bit of confidence, but also to see whether we can rehabilitate family relationships as well. The Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, which has now been in operation for some years and which will be beefed up as a result of the latest budget initiatives, will have a very big role to play in this.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I have directed that research projects be undertaken into the health, social and vocational needs of younger veterans as well as a study to compare the death rate and causes of death amongst Vietnam veterans and the general community. We are going to compare them to see whether what the Vietnam Veterans Association says is true: that there is a greater incidence of suicide amongst those veterans than in the general community. These studies will assist in planning future responses to the special needs of younger veterans and will build upon the government's current initiatives.

Being of that age, I do have a particular empathy with the problems being suffered by our Vietnam veterans. It is about time we got very serious about their situation. Whilst I do not in any way distinguish veterans from any particular conflict, I think that they are a special group and that we should do something about it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer him to page 118 of Budget Paper No. 2 on appropriation provisions for compensation payments to Voyager collision survivors. I remind him of his comments in this place in May last year when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . I do believe that now we are at the stage where the Voyager claims can be reasonably settled to the satisfaction of both sides.

Is it true that much of your department's past opposition to settlement of the Voyager claims stems from the views of a now retired departmental officer? Can you confirm that this officer has been re-employed on a consultancy basis to review the remaining 25 cases? Is it true that he has recommended further litigation to settle these cases rather than adopting your previously announced process of mediation? Does that explain why there is no financial provision in financial year 1994-95 for compensation payments for the remaining 25 survivors?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that I am not terribly familiar with that particular page of the appropriation document, but I might have a look at it to satisfy myself. The position regarding the settlement of the Voyager claims is as I stated in May last year. As I understand matters, all of the Voyager claims made prior to the nature of that settlement—that is, claims lodged prior to the coming into operation of the Comcare legislation in 1988—to the best of my knowledge have been negotiated, mediated, agreement reached on them and, again to the best of my knowledge, payment has been made.

PARA.TAB: At the time, the Commonwealth's position and part of the cabinet decision regarding the settlement of these claims was that the Comcare legislation, particularly section 44 of that act, which removed common law actions by Commonwealth employees against the Commonwealth, would be a bar which the Commonwealth relied on. That bar does not apply to Voyager victims in any particular sense; it applies across the board. Claims have been made after that time and claims have been made more recently. No doubt claims have been made given the publicity which was generated at that time. I am not saying that those claims are not legitimate, but they were not filed prior to that cut-off date.

I have, obviously, acted in accordance with the cabinet decision regarding the Commonwealth's position: that is, claims filed after that date were not to be admitted and were to be defended. My general approach is that all claims which the Commonwealth is a party to should be attempted to be negotiated—that is a general approach which I take. I believe that is certainly the approach which we will take regarding the Voyager claims.

A further matter which needs to be taken into account is the High Court's decision regarding the constitutionality and the scope of section 44, which is the basis of the Comcare legislation and the basis of the Commonwealth's position. I am examining that decision and its implications. Hopefully, we can still settle the outstanding claims.
