The position as it stands today is that all claims made prior to the introduction of that legislation have been negotiated, settled and paid. Consistent with the cabinet decision of May or April of last year, claims made after the introduction of that legislation have not been admitted and have been defended. We will look at the nature of the existing claims to see whether they can be settled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Special Minister of State. I refer him to an article in the June issue of the Australian Business Monthly. What is the government's response to criticism that the Native Title Act has created not certainty but confusion and could bring mining exploration to a standstill?
—I thank the honourable member for the question. The article is shallow and misleading. The position is, as you would know—
—You're an expert, are you?
—Just remember that your response to Mabo was a little sterile. You provided nothing for—
—The minister will direct his remarks through the chair.
—All right. I shall.
—And he will continue to be heard in silence.
—As will all ministers.

—Their response to Mabo was sterile, through you, Mr Speaker. The fact is that the High Court has found in common law a new form of land title known as native title. The essence is that that title should be treated like any other form of land title. Industry leaders have understood that and now recognise it. We have passed legislation to ensure certainty of past title, and we have now in place a regime which can give certainty over the use of future title.

PARA.TAB: The position in Western Australia is that the Western Australian government is, for instance, telling miners there that they must comply with its acts. It is now issuing titles that may not comply with the federal system and which may be held to be invalid at some stage in the future.

I make a plea to miners in Western Australia that, in addition to complying with state law—which, of course, they must—they should not wait for the High Court to make a decision about the validity of our act. They should comply now with the national Native Title Act. If they comply now with our act, they will be certain that they are covered by our act. So, whatever the outcome of the High Court decision in six or 12 months time, they will have the certainty of the Commonwealth's act and will, of course, be complying with the state act. It is important that they do that.

In addition, I suggest that there are ways in which right here and now miners and other land users can have the certainty of the current Native Title Act; there is no reason why they should wait. These are the sorts of things that miners, for instance, and other land users can do to give certainty today to their future uses of land.

For instance, the act includes a fast-tracked non-claimant process for determining whether native title exists over a particular area of land. This procedure is open to all states and territories as well as to those who already have an interest in land. Just two months after notification, a developer or anyone else can know whether the land is subject to a native title claim. If there is no claim, a government can then proceed to take action on the land—for instance, in giving the developer a grant or a licence—comfortable in the fact that the title and the action under it will be valid, even if native title should be established at some later point in time. Furthermore, the developer can be certain that it will not become liable for any compensation, regardless of any later valid native title claim. It is important that these people understand that the current act gives them that certainty.

As for mining companies, there are a number of things that they can do now to get access to certainty under the current Commonwealth regime. For instance, if a mining company has an existing interest in the land, such as an exploration licence, it can make a non-claimant application with all the benefits and certainties that I have just outlined. It can also encourage native title holders to enter into an agreement with the government under section 21 of the act so that the title holders can surrender their native title rights and interests by way of negotiation. That is available to miners today.

Further, it can also encourage state and territory governments to assist them where acts attracting the right to negotiate are proposed. Where a government follows the notification process and no native title claim is made within two months, mining activities can validly proceed, but subject to state and territory laws governing mining and land management.

Finally, another important element of this is that it is also possible for state and territory governments to facilitate exploration activity. They can propose that exploration methods with a minimal effect on native title be excluded completely from any right to negotiate procedures. I can inform the House that Commonwealth officials have recently indicated to all states and territories some broad guidelines for the application of these provisions.

I stress that industry groups should now be encouraging state and territory governments to submit exclusion proposals to the Commonwealth. I reiterate: there is a certain way through the native title issue, and that is to apply, use and access the Commonwealth's Native Title Act today. Whilst miners, for instance, must comply with state acts, they should also be ready to use the Commonwealth's act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I do mean Old Backflip, not the junior water boy.

PARA.TAB: I repeat, for the benefit of employers—and the overwhelming number of employers, of course, act with good reason—that they have nothing to fear. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. What will this year's aid budget do to meet the enormous health needs of people in developing countries, and what benefit will this be to Australians in general?

—I thank the honourable member for Franklin for asking the question. His long-term interest in the aid program is well known. He was a member of the committee which recently in a bipartisan fashion reported to this House on health needs in developing countries and what the aid program could do to attack those problems.

PARA.TAB: That report did indeed identify some horrendous difficulties. The diseases which have been wiped out in this country effectively, such as poliomyelitis and neonatal tetanus, are rampant in our part of the world and certainly deserve attacking through our foreign aid budget. That budget this year, as the House will know, has been increased to $1,486 million, an $82 million increase over last year's budget expenditure. That represents a real increase of 3.6 per cent—something of which I believe the government is entitled to be very proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Check the percentage of GDP compared with us in government.

—It is interesting that the shadow minister should interject in that fashion and invite me to compare it with the Fraser government's record on this matter. I wonder whether the House would be interested in these figures: in the six years from 1975-76 to 1980-81, during which the honourable member for Kooyong had responsibility for the aid budget, he managed to get an increase in the budget in three years—a 2.1 per cent increase in 1977-78, a 2.4 per cent increase in 1978-79 and a 0.9 per cent increase in 1980-81. How did he go in 1979-80?

—Mr Speaker, I will take a point of order. This little worm is misleading, and he knows it. The percentage to GDP was double what he has been able to achieve. He has been condemned by all the community groups, and blatant lies are being told here.
—The honourable member for Kooyong will withdraw the last comment.
—Why? What was it? I can't withdraw what I can't remember. It is no selective amnesia. What was it? I can't withdraw what I can't recall.
—You accused the minister of uttering lies in this place. It is unparliamentary language, I have reminded you, and I ask you to withdraw.
—I will withdraw.

—With regards to the performance, I might say that the honourable member for Kooyong is in great danger of overstepping the mark and, in fact, invoking standing order 1000—for his benefit, that is overacting.
—I was just getting onto some other records, as the honourable member invited me to do.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister has obviously been reading from an extensive document. I ask that he table that document in the House so that we can see exactly the figures that he is quoting to the House and compare them with the true figures.
—Is the minister quoting from a confidential document?

—Absolutely not. I am quoting from page 57 of the Statistical Annex A to Budget Paper No. 2, which I introduced. I am very happy to table that document if the honourable member cannot work it out. What I do want to say, just to finish these figures, is that in 1979—
—What was the percentage of GDP?
—The honourable member for Kooyong will not start again!

—In 1979-80 there was a real decrease of minus 1.1 per cent and in 1976-77 of minus 2.4 per cent. But, in his first year, he really distinguished himself by having a real decrease in the aid budget of 8.8 per cent. That is a very large decrease compared with the 3.6 per cent increase in real terms.
—Off the lowest base.
—Order! The minister has the call.
—I might add, in response to the Leader of the Opposition, that this is the largest budgeted increase in real terms and in money terms for 20 years—since the days of E.G. Whitlam.
—What was the percentage of GDP?
—The Leader of the Opposition will not interject across the table.
—That increase—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister will resume his seat. The minister has the call. Under standing order 55 he will be heard.

—That increase has made possible the very large increase in the aid budget dealing with the health initiative. That $110 million increase will take total health spending in the aid budget to well over $200 million. Incidentally, that is the very figure by which the opposition promised in Fightback to cut the aid budget over two years. That increase in the health budget will save up to 200,000 lives. That will enable—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Simply in the interests of accuracy, the diminution in aid in 1986-87 was 12 per cent.
—This is not a point of order. You are endeavouring to debate an issue. Resume your seat.
—How do you answer that?
—I warn the honourable member for Gippsland for constantly interjecting.

—That will substantially increase funds for the program to eradicate polio and neonatal tetanus by the end of the year. Polio paralyses some 100,000 children each year, particularly in our region, in Laos and Cambodia. A newborn child dies every minute from neonatal tetanus.
—I think you had better sit down, Gordon. You are lost.
—I would have thought the minister for health would be interested in these facts rather than interjecting.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—She's not here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. Her pronouncements have bemused me. We will also concentrate on combating malaria, which affects more than one million people in our region every year. We will step up our efforts against HIV-AIDS which, unless controlled, will threaten the lives of up to 14 million people in our region by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member asked about the benefits to Australia. These diseases are no respecters of national boundaries. There is a threat of malaria coming across our northern borders. It is also the case that, as we increase our contacts with South-East Asia through the engagement which the government is promoting, we are at more risk of tourists, business people and so forth bringing back diseases such as HIV-AIDS or malaria. So it is very important that, for our own purposes, we attempt to combat these diseases.

Finally, one great advantage of this program will be to showcase our own Australian expertise in dealing with these diseases. Just as in years past, through the aid program and through education given in Australia under the aid program, we were able to internationalise the education sector in Australia and turn it into a billion dollar export earner, I believe the same thing will happen in the high value-added health sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister indicated that he was prepared to table some figures.
—I table the document.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to an article by his assistant minister in the Canberra Times which describes the guidelines on harassment in the workplace for Commonwealth public servants as: `guidelines on how individuals should be treated with some basic respect and courtesy'. Would the use of terms `Tory bitch' and `fat-arsed bitch' reportedly used by the Prime Minister when speaking of female journalists breach the spirit of the government's guidelines?

—What a coincidence—the same question asked in the Senate and here in the House of Representatives! That question has been asked by members who knew that the Prime Minister specifically denied that claim in a press conference at 1.45 this afternoon.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. What action is the government proposing to take following the public announcement from the ACT government that it will support a national approach to the banning of X- and R-rated computer games?

—Members might recall that the Commonwealth, with the support of the states and territories, introduced a scheme for the classification of computer games in April this year. That scheme basically reflected the scheme in place for film and videos, with the important addition of the classification of G8 to recognise the particular need of younger children, and the need for parents to be given guidance in the appropriate material for younger children.

PARA.TAB: At the time the scheme was introduced, a number of jurisdictions indicated that they would allow within their boundaries games up to a classification of X. Certainly a majority—at least initially—believed they would be allowing games up to a classification of R, which is the standard in film in video. Subsequently, all Australian jurisdictions, most recently now with the Australian Capital Territory, have indicated that they do not wish X and R computer games to be shown. That means that these games will now not be available at all in Australia.

The government proposes to amend the ordinance setting up the classification scheme to remove R and X games. Any games submitted for classification which would have otherwise fallen within those particular categories will now be refused classification. Up to this point, no game has been submitted for classification which would have fallen within the X and R categories. The government will also be changing its classification bill—which will be introduced and debated in the parliament a bit later this session—to remove X and R games.

One final matter which should be mentioned relates to the slightly different and stricter classification guidelines which apply to computer games. This flowed from a genuine community concern that the interactive nature of these games—in particular, the fact that they are very much targeted at children and young people—meant that there should be stronger guidelines in the classification system. However, it would be an odd result if a film were classified at, say, M level but, because it is being shown through a computer medium by way of, say, a computer laser disc rather than videotape, it were to end up with a different classification. That is possible given the slightly different and stricter classifications applying to computer games.

The nature of the Commonwealth's concern, and I think the concern of honourable members and of the states, is the interactive nature of computer games and the need for a stricter system. If something is merely being shown in identical form, such as on a television through a videotape or on a computer screen through a laser disc, it is sensible that a similar classification be reached in terms of that product since there is a difference only in the technology; there is no difference in the end product. So we will need to clarify that particular situation.

I welcome the decision of the ACT government; I think it is a responsible one. It means that we have had a consensus of all governments in this country in terms of the showing of X- and R-rated computer games. I believe that it is a sound decision which all governments, again, have taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about X-rated videos?
—The same situation exists with videos as with computer games.
—Why don't you bring in uniformity?

—It is up to individual states and territories to make their decisions. That is the nature of the censorship arrangements we have in this country. I repeat: it is a matter for each individual government, state and territory, to determine which games and which films it wishes to be shown within its boundaries.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, my question is directed to you. I seek your guidance, perhaps under standing order 999. Yesterday, the Minister for Communications and the Arts brought Anzac Day into the melee on a complete falsehood and was asked but was not ordered to withdraw. Today the honourable member for Ballarat was forced to withdraw comments not even objected to by the minister at the dispatch box. Why was the honourable member for Ballarat treated one way and the minister treated another way?

—If the Leader of the National Party has the opportunity to read Hansard, he will see yesterday's events clearly outlined there. My comment at the time was that, in my view, the words which were uttered at the time were not unparliamentary, and I stick by that. With regard to the comment by the honourable member for Ballarat, in my view, to refer directly to another member in this place as a hypocrite is unparliamentary, and I will rule accordingly. I know that honourable members in this place genuinely have a desire to improve the image that they themselves have and that others have of them, and I am endeavouring, and I would hope with their cooperation, for that to continue.

—Mr Speaker, with the Main Committee of the House of Representatives scheduled to commence sittings for the first time in room 2R3 next week, is it still anticipated that the House will be able to give complete consideration to the government's entire parliamentary program? If it is not, can you confirm, or are you aware, that the guillotine will nevertheless be employed next week, contrary to what was given as a main justification for having a second chamber?
—I think the honourable member for Curtin had best direct that question to the Leader of the House.
—I was asking whether you were aware.

—Mr Speaker, I have a question which I direct to you. TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a schedule showing government responses to House of Representatives and joint committee reports for the period 17 August 1993 to 12 May 1994, and reports presented to which responses are outstanding. Copies of the schedule have been made available to honourable members and will be incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: SCHEDULE OF GOVERNMENT RESPONSES FOR THE PERIOD 17 AUGUST 1993 TO 12 MAY 1994 AND REPORTS PRESENTED TO WHICH RESPONSES ARE OUTSTANDING

This document continues the practice of presenting to the House of Representatives at approximately six-monthly intervals a schedule listing Government responses to House and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this schedule to the House follows the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 25 May 1978 Prime Minister Fraser informed the House that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the incoming government. The Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983, at which time the ministerial statement method of response was continued. More recently, the Government has advised that responses to committee reports will be made by means of a letter to a committee chair, with the letter being tabled in the House at the earliest opportunity. However, for the purposes of this schedule, the date of the presentation of the Government's response to the Parliament has been taken as the date of the Government's response, not the date of any correspondence with the committee.

The schedule does not include reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, or the reports of the House of Representatives Committee of Members' Interests, the Committee of Privileges, the Publications Committee and the Selection Committee. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes, which are tabled by the Committee. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The threats to a sustained economic recovery in Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw something that was very unusual earlier on this afternoon: we saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on his rostered day off, calling a press conference and sitting beside the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to try to bask in reflected glory over a beautiful set of numbers. He described them as the best set of numbers for 30 years.

PARA.TAB: One could not help but go back and think of the way in which he used to gloat over figures whilst he was the Treasurer of this country in the mid- and late 1980s. Who will ever forget when he appeared on the PM program in March 1993 and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I mean this is a beautiful set of numbers for us. For policy this is a beautiful set of numbers.

It was a precursor to Australia going into its worst recession in 60 years—a beautiful set of numbers. Who could ever forget the largess of expression when he talked about the effervescence flowing out over the cup? Who could help but feel a bit of a chill run down the spine as we saw the Prime Minister come out from his rostered day off and try to do the same thing with the rhetoric this afternoon?

PARA.TAB: We had a recession, the recession that followed closely on that beautiful set of numbers, in March 1990 to deal with the problem of the current account deficit. It was as a result of the sickness of the current account deficit that we had the treatment—the Keating treatment—of recession; a recession which was given to try to overcome the sickness of the current account deficit. He did not fix the sickness; the sickness is still there in the Australian economy. But now at last we are emerging from his treatment. That is what the economic recovery tells us: we are emerging from the treatment that the Prime Minister administered to try to fix the sickness. The sickness might still be there, but the good news for Australia is that we are now finally recovering from the Prime Minister's treatment.

Let me say on behalf of the opposition: we welcome growth in the Australian economy; we welcome it. The Australians who have been hard hit and pushed from pillar to post and wrung out through the wringer of the Keating recession—the recession that they had to have; the recession that he gave them; the recession that put a million people out of work—need some good news. The good news they need is that they are finally recovering from the treatment he administered to them in the worst recession in 60 years.

But I say to those opposite: do not think for a moment that you can sit down, as the Prime Minister did, and say to the people of Australia, `It's all hunky dory; it's a golden age.' Do not think that anybody out there actually believes that the problems of the Australian economy are over; do not think that it is acceptable in this country to have 900,000 people out of work; do not think it is acceptable in this country to have a widening gap between the rich and the poor; do not think it is acceptable in this country to have the creation of a new underclass—the legacy of a decade of Labor—in Australian society permanently locked out of the work force, with unemployment being the great cause of poverty that it is.

I heard the Prime Minister say in his press conference earlier on this afternoon that we are not going to see, under Labor, a class of working poor. No, we are not, because he has turned them into a class of workless poor. That is what he has done to them—locked them out of the labour market, locked them out of wages altogether and locked them out of all of the social stability that comes with that, all of the identity and meaning that comes with that. He has created a new class of workless poor, an underclass, in this country.

What Australia needs is sustainable recovery. It needs a recovery that can be sustained on a long-term basis. It needs a recovery that can grow, and that growth needs to be managed in a way that will really do something for all of the victims of the Keating recession—the men and women put out of work, those who are locked out in that lowest decile by the widening gap between the rich and the poor; those who are now part of Labor's underclass. What we need is sustained recovery built on sound foundations.

Today's national accounts figures are good growth figures. As I said, we welcome growth. But, as the Treasurer himself admitted in his press conference earlier this afternoon, it is a growth based on consumption—two-thirds of it government consumption. It is not a growth which is soundly based on business investment, on new plant and equipment or on industry and business picking up, investing and employing.

In fact, today's national accounts figures show that there is a 6.8 per cent decline in expenditure on new equipment and that business investment is still showing a downward trend. They confirm the figures of last week which showed that private new capital expenditure was down in the March quarter by five per cent. Remember this: the crucial forecast in the government's budget was for a surge in private business investment. That is the crucial figure.

When we woke up the day after the budget, we saw headline after headline in the Australian newspapers—`gamble', `gamble', `gamble', `gamble', `gamble'. The press said that the government, instead of taking an axe to its own expenditure and taking the advice of the Reserve Bank Governor, Professor Garnaut, Vince FitzGerald and the opposition and doing something about the fiscal deficit, had decided to gamble on private business investment. That was the big gamble—the big punt on private business investment.

All we can say is that the recent figures show no sign of a surge in private business investment at all; no sign of that massive lift, no sign in the capital expenditure figures; no sign in the national accounts—no sign that business investment is coming back. To sustain recovery in this country, we need a recovery which is based on savings, investment and jobs. We need to switch from consumption to investment. The downside of the national accounts figures that have been released today is that they rely on consumption in the way that they do.

What about savings? These figures show the lowest household savings ratio in recent memory—and the figure is still falling. We are not seeing the savings which are necessary for investment and we are not seeing the investment which is necessary to fuel a continuous growth cycle. If we do not have that base for permanent substantive growth, we are going to go into the old boom-bust cycle again. We are going to hear all of those words come back to haunt the Prime Minister as they did last time—`effervescence' and `beautiful sets of numbers'. But it all turned to dust and dross as a result of the Keating recession that we had to have.

I think there was actually another purpose in today's press conference. I think it was an attempt to jawbone the markets. It was an attempt to say to the markets that the fears in relation to inflation and interest rates should not take hold. After the release of today's national accounts figures, the bond markets passed a verdict almost immediately. They pushed up bond rates in relation to not only three-year bond rates but also 10-year bond rates.
The bond markets know what the government refuses to admit. They know that there will be a tightening of monetary policy. They

SPEECH.PARA: know that there is a problem in relation to interest rates and they are already beginning to factor higher interest rates into the equation. It is not as though the government makes out that interest rates are a problem that has been solved in Australia. Australia still has some of the highest real interest rates in the world. The Treasurer knows that to be the case.

PARA.TAB: If we deduct the CPI figure from the prime bank lending rate, Australia has a real interest rate of around seven per cent. That figure compares with 3.7 per cent in Britain, 4.9 per cent in the United States and 1.7 per cent in Japan. Australia has high real interest rates—some of the highest in the developed world, surpassed only by that much admired laboratory for the ACTU, Sweden. In relation to those countries that we like to compare ourselves with, those countries that are predominantly free-enterprise mixed economy countries—

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want to talk about Sweden any more.

—No, we do not want to talk about the Swedish model any more. We had our brief flirtation with the Swedish model. It was a flirtation long enough to leave us with permanent disease in relation to our labour markets. But we do not talk about Sweden any more because the Swedish experience has proved conclusively not to be an example in relation to Australia. The point is that Australia still has high real interest rates. When a country has high real interest rates they act as a disincentive to business investment, the engine that is needed for the economy to grow.

PARA.TAB: The bond markets have already made their judgment. As soon as the national accounts figures were released, they made the judgment that interest rates were on the way up. It was no good the Treasurer coming in here yesterday and saying that interest rates would not go up in the near future—I think that was the phraseology. Interest rates on the bond markets went up today. Everybody knows that real interest rates are already high and are going higher. They know that there will be a correction to monetary policy.

The Governor of the Reserve Bank has been warning the government about it. The Governor of the Reserve Bank said to the government, `Do better on your budget deficit. Restrain your own purpose expenditure,' because it is Commonwealth owned purpose expenditure that is driving the government deficit. Yet this government squibbed and squandered. It squibbed the tough decisions and squandered the opportunity to do better. Don Mercer was right. You know he was right. He was right when he said that, as a result of your failing to take the tough decisions, you are exposing Australia to the old repetitive cycle of boom-bust.

Having given away the lever in relation to the fiscal deficit, you have only one lever left which is in relation to monetary policy. The Governor of the Reserve Bank is holding that lever over the Australian business community and the bond markets are already factoring that lever into their decision making. Why is it?

TALK.START.PARA: —They did that before the recession.

—Of course. It was interest that took us into the recession that we had to have, in an attempt to get rid of the current account deficit which persisted. You went into the village trying to get rid of the cockroaches. You napalmed the village but the cockroaches were still there. That is what happened at the end of it. Now we are trying to build the village again. The cockroaches are still there and you are saying, `Isn't our construction of the village wonderful? It is all coming back.' But the cockroaches are still there. The treatment was worse than the disease. You know that. It is only now that the Australian economy is recovering from the treatment, let alone the disease.

PARA.TAB: Why do you have a problem with business investment? Part of it is that we have high real interest rates. Part of it is that there is an expectation that they are going to go higher. Part of it is that your industrial relations laws are not business investment friendly. Eight weeks ago the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was proclaiming a new era of industrial relations. After eight weeks he has done his double backflip with pike off the high board and said, `All of those laws that I introduced were not such a good idea after all.'

If they were not a good idea yesterday, why were they a good idea eight weeks ago? Why was it necessary to introduce them in the first place? Let us put another thought into the mind of the Minister for Industrial Relations—he who gets paid by results: maybe the rest of his bill was no better. Maybe the reasons why the unfair dismissal laws were no good are the same reasons why his labour court is no good, why his attempt to restrict section 45D of the Trade Practices Act is no good, why his trying to make unions immune from common law is no good, and why his enterprise bargaining proposals are no good. Do we have to wait 80 weeks before he finds out those sorts of things?

We have high real interest rates, and business expects them to go higher. We have bad industrial relations laws. We have an FBT which is incredibly complex and which nobody can work out. We have a Corporations Law which has added 1,100 pages of complex legislation in the last couple of years. We have a climate where you cannot make an investment decision without a QC sitting by your right-hand side, and you are worried you are going to be made liable anyway. Business investment is not coming through. And the government is not making it easier. It is not creating a climate where we can have a sustained economic recovery. That is the tragedy, the difficulty and the underside of today's national accounts figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today was a bad day for the new shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), to have to make his maiden speech in that position. Clearly today's numbers are very good results for the nation, very good results for the government and not so good for an opposition that wants to try to pretend that the economy is in bad shape. He spent a quarter of an hour trying to work up some gloom and doom, but at the end of the day the reality is that the Australian economy is growing faster than any other country in the Western developed world. That is the bottom line from today's figures.

PARA.TAB: We know that the recovery is here in a substantial way. Anyone who had lingering doubts about that after the December quarter accounts sees those doubts dispelled now. It is unambiguously clear that we have moved up to a strong rate of growth. That rate of growth is as high or higher than the growth rate of any other country in the Western world. That is the sort of bottom line from which discussion about the national accounts has to proceed. From there, where does the opposition go? The shadow Treasurer tried to say that we have a problem in the sense that this is not a sustainable recovery. Of course it is the opposition's role to try to find `dark clouds', a phrase he is wont to use in his press releases. But try as he may to work up some dark clouds, I must say to him that the economic weather is very bright and sunny out there. Most other people are reaching for their sunglasses, rather than looking at dark clouds.

This country is in a very good position for sustained economic and employment growth. There have been few times in its past when the nation has been so well-placed for sustained economic and employment growth as it is at present. That is the reality of our position as we see it. Indeed, I think it is the reality that many other people increasingly see. Before I pursue that point, let me say a little about today's figures, because they are important. The five per cent growth for the 12 months to March, on the seasonally adjusted figures, is probably a little above where we really are in terms of our trend rate. The trend rate as published by the Statistician for that 12-month period is 4.3 per cent. That is probably a more accurate picture of how the economy is really going because some one-off factors have pushed that rate up to the 5 per cent level.

In particular, there is a lumpiness of government consumption expenditure, both Commonwealth and state. This has meant that a lot of it has been deposited into the March quarter, giving a particular stimulus to growth in that quarter in a way which obviously cannot be sustained in other quarters. Also, in the private consumption area we had the particular fact of Easter coming just at the end of March and forcing the pre-Easter sales to come into the March quarter, thereby leading to a substantial real increase in retail sales in March and giving us a spurt in private consumption expenditure in the March quarter which obviously is not going to be sustained. So in that sense we had a couple of one-off factors which mean that the 12 months picture that we are looking at is not really the true picture of where are, although it certainly indicates that the economy is growing very strongly.

The trend rate of 4.3 per cent is probably a better picture of where we are at present, but that in itself is the cause of an extremely good rate of growth, virtually as good as any other country in the Western world. The confirmation of that rate means that not only are we chalking up those figures now but we can have immense confidence about the future. Let me quote someone who is not normally noted for making complimentary remarks about the government or the economy. I refer to Mr Spicer from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, who has issued a press release today entitled, `A very encouraging result'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's recovery is the real thing—
not some mirage; it is the real thing—
and in seasonally adjusted terms—
he goes on to say that there is a five per cent annual growth rate—
takes Australia to the very top of the international growth rate league tables. Even private sector investment has contributed to Australia's rate of growth.
He talks about the 5.8 per cent figure, which includes the Gladstone powerhouse point that the shadow Treasurer mentioned. He says:

There is still a long way to go before we can actually say the economy has fully recovered, but it is well on the way. There are still tens of thousands of jobs to be created but the level of confidence demonstrated by this result will provide greater hope that the white paper employment targets can be achieved. The task now is to shift the level of public consumption to investment. In this respect the need to reduce public consumption spending remains paramount if the recovery is to be maintained. Nevertheless our growth rate is as good as can be hoped for at this stage of the cycle.

That, as I say, is from a source which has not been known for making complimentary remarks in the past. That is a clear appraisal by the ACCI of how it sees the situation. That will be, I am sure, the view, virtually universally, of the business and finance sectors of this economy as they look at today's figures.

PARA.TAB: Today's figures are not only good in the sense that they have that strong growth; they also have low inflation. Inflation in the 12 months on the implicit price deflator is less than one per cent. On non-farm GDP it is 0.7; for the whole GDP it is 0.9. There are various measures of inflation, but these are all-embracing ones. We normally refer to the CPI, which is currently 1.4 per cent. These figures are under one per cent. So we have strong growth of the economy—obviously strong growth—and, associated with that, very low inflation by our historical standards. That is exceedingly important in terms of having confidence about a sustained recovery.

It is important that we have a sustained recovery. There is no doubt about that. No-one wants a short-term recovery which just fizzles out. We do not expect that to happen because we have in place the bases for a sustained recovery. It is argued by the opposition that it is not a sustainable recovery because we do not have business investment going yet. It is always the case that business investment takes a while to get going. In this particular recovery it has taken a long time to get going, that is for sure. There have been some particular factors associated with that. One is the fact that just prior to this recession we had a lot of heavy investment and the economy went into recession quite quickly. Then we had a lot of excess capacity. Companies have still got excess capacity but those capacity utilisation rates are moving up. As they move up further, there will be increased pressure for business investment. But you do not invest if you do not need to, if you can meet demand from your present level of capacity.

Business, to its credit, has been operating a lot smarter. Through enterprise bargaining and various other pressures for productivity improvement in a more competitive economy, businesses have been working their plant and equipment more efficiently and as a result they are able to meet demand without further investment. Those factors plus the balance sheet restructuring that has been going on—that is, getting rid of the excessive levels of debt that they built up at the end of the 1980s, rebalancing their balance sheets and using the high profit share that exists at present to get their balance sheets into shape—have been keeping investment down.

But now that is essentially a product of the past. The balance sheets have been restructured. The capacity utilisation rates are moving up, despite increased productivity. In those circumstances there is obviously increasing pressure on business to invest, otherwise it is going to see the opportunities by-pass it. Businesses will go somewhere else if they do not invest, so of course they are going to invest sooner or later. It has made sense for them not to invest to this stage but it will not make sense to keep on not investing because it will be forgoing good business opportunities. There are many other reasons why business would want to invest. It clearly has a strong recovery going; it has strong levels of demand—businesses can see that—and it has high profit share. The profit share today has moved up to virtually the highest it has ever been, just fractionally below the peak levels in the mid-1980s.

We have strong profitability and a strong capacity therefore to invest. We have wages at low levels, inflation at very low levels, productivity improving and international competitiveness greatly improved. We are 30 per cent more competitive internationally than we were when this government first came into office. This is a fantastic array of conditions for increased business investment. We must expect that business will seize the opportunities. Business is not so stupid as not to do that. The fact that we have had low rates of business investment in the last couple of years does not mean that we cannot get a sudden turnaround. We have had periods like that in the past.

During 1979-80 investment fell by 3.7 per cent and it increased the next year by over 17 per cent. During the recovery in the early 1980s we saw declines in business investment in 1982-83 and 1983-84 and it bounced back by over 14 per cent in 1984-85. Quite rapid turnarounds were common in our not too distant economic past. It makes sense. Once businesses as a group decide that it is time to get moving, they see the conditions and get into it. That is what we can expect to happen this time.

Despite the fact that the capital expenditure figures which came out a week or so ago showed a fall in March, it does not mean that there is no likelihood of pick-up in investment in 1994-95. That survey shows that a substantial increase in business investment is expected in the June quarter and a further increase in 1994-95. We remain quite confident that the budget forecasts for both this year and next year—business investment for this year is basically expected to increase only by around one per cent and in 1994-95 to increase by some 14 1/2 per cent—are quite credible and appropriate. In those circumstances, we will obviously have that further condition we need to go on to the next stage of maturity in the recovery, which is to get that investment coming through. That will enable us to move on to a further stage in the recovery.

The other factor that is mentioned as an inhibition to a sustained recovery is the current account. Some people, including those in the opposition, say, `You have some problems because you have a high current account deficit and with recovery that will go higher and you will have an incapacity, as we had at the end of the 1980s, to maintain growth.' In 1994-95 we will see an increase in the current account outcome from $16 billion to $18 billion. But we have to bear in mind that this year, 1993-94, we are doing much better on the current account than we forecast, despite lousy commodity prices that have just started to come around in the last few weeks.

Commodity prices are obviously not helping us as a nation. We are still strongly reliant on exporting commodities, despite a significant spread in our exports over the last decade or so. With those low commodity prices, nevertheless we have been able to chalk up a much better current account outcome than we budgeted for—despite the fact that we are having much stronger growth than we budgeted for. We budgeted for 2 3/4 per cent GDP growth in 1993-94. It is currently running at 4 per cent or more, and over the last 12 months it has been at 4.3 per cent. Despite that, the current account outcome is still on line for our revised forecast of $16 billion, not the $18 billion that we originally forecast.

So we have stronger growth and a better outcome despite poor commodity prices. That is because a lot of things are going well for us in the diversification of our exports. Tremendous results are being achieved by this nation in the area of manufactured exports and exports of services. In comparison with most other countries, we are seeing the volume of these exports growing at quite exceptional rates by any standard. Since 1985-86 manufactured export volumes have grown by 13 per cent and services have grown by nine per cent. In 1993-94 they are growing by 15 per cent and 11 per cent respectively.

We are looking at increasing rates of exports of manufactured goods and services. We are becoming increasingly less reliant on commodities. This is very good for us. Although commodities will always be very important to us, given our natural resources, we need to diversify because the long-term terms of trade of commodities is adverse. We therefore have to get more of our exports into the cycle of goods which maintain comparability and price with our imports. That is what we are doing in spades.

Since the mid-1980s commodities have dropped from 80 per cent to 65 per cent of our total exports. This is due to diversification. It is picking up pace. It is not dropping off; it is going faster. It is going faster because we have international competitiveness, low inflation, strong productivity growth and low unit labour costs and the capacity for our manufacturers to face up to international competition and to improve their exports. In the face of declining tariffs, the manufacturing industry is more confident now than at any time in the last 30 years. That is a product of its capacity to restructure.

All of this gives me great confidence for the future of this country. I think the Australian economy is as well placed as it has ever been for a period of strong, sustained economic and employment growth, and it has the capacity year after year to knock those unemployment levels down to something which we can all feel is more tolerable. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commend the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) because they would make great used car salesmen. They are selling the Australian economy as being in great shape based on some very poor economic indicators and a very poor position. Any threat being posed towards the sustained growth and sustained economic recovery of Australia at the moment is as a result of this Labor government's economic policies. Any glimmer of economic recovery, which we welcome, is not happening because of this government but despite this government.

PARA.TAB: How can a government that continually increases general taxes and taxes on business, continually increases foreign debt and continually increases government spending claim to be initiating economic recovery? The simple fact is that it cannot. How can a government that has pushed our foreign debt to in excess of $200 billion, has seen our net Commonwealth debt increase from $30 billion to $95 billion during the term of this current incumbent Prime Minister and that has held unemployment in double digits claim to be initiating economic recovery? The simple fact is that it cannot.

How can a government whose industrial relations laws are in tatters, whose current account deficit is ever expanding and who has overseen the percentage of fuel excise spent on the roads drop from 67 per cent of the take to just 7 per cent of the take while that fuel tax is absolutely exploding claim to be initiating and supporting economic recovery in this country? The simple fact is that it cannot.

The fact is that this Labor government is threatening sustained economic recovery in Australia. This government is gambling with Australia's economic future. Treasurer Willis is playing Russian roulette with a pistol at the head of the Australian people, not his own, and he is holding the trigger and saying, `Don't worry, trust me.' That is what we have heard from the Treasurer in this debate this afternoon. At the media conference this afternoon we heard the Prime Minister and Treasurer saying, `Trust us. Don't worry. It's all right. We're going to fix the recession that we created, but trust us. We won't do it to you again. We won't see interest rates rise. We won't see people lose their homes. We won't see farmers lose their farms, business people lose their businesses and the unemployment queues go back up over one million.'

The Prime Minister is gambling with this country's future. His favourite gambling game is craps. We all know about the Prime Minister and his BS. This Labor government is taking enormous risks with Australia's future for short-term political gain, as did some very notable corporate cowboys in the 1980s. Remember names like Skase, Spalvins, Yuill and Connell, who continually told their shareholders, `Don't worry, trust us,' whilst they borrowed, borrowed, borrowed and spent, spent, spent.

The creative accounting that established the equity to support these borrowings became an art form in the 1980s. As we have heard today, the creative salesmanship of the leadership of this Labor government is becoming an art form. It keeps telling us, `Don't worry, trust us.' The ghosts of these corporate cowboys are now in government in the 1990s with their now familiar approach of tax, tax, tax, borrow, borrow, borrow and spend, spend, spend. All the while they keep saying, as we have just heard from the Treasurer, `Don't worry, trust us. We know what we are doing. We have done it all through the 1980s and we are now doing it in the 1990s.'

Both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister saw this country and economy dive into a recession. They started it. The Prime Minister, when Treasurer, said that it was the recession we had to have. Now they are saying, `Don't worry. Trust us. We're going to ease ourselves out of it.' As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), stated earlier, the bond markets have reacted. They know what will happen. Interest rates will go up. The government has been warned by the Reserve Bank to be careful and to take measures, but the Treasurer is saying that interest rates will not go up. All they can say to the Australian people is `Don't worry. Trust us. We know what we are doing.' I believe the Australian people have finally woken up.

What about the money we borrow? We glide straight over the issue of foreign debt. In today's papers it was raised not by the Australian people or by the opposition, but by the members of the Labor caucus. An article today reports that the Prime Minister spoke to the caucus about the current account deficit and foreign debt and how interest payments are pushing up the current account deficit. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Keating moved to comfort Caucus with a long dissertation on why the foreign debt was not "bad".

PARA.TAB: Employing the same arguments he used in the late 1980s as Treasurer, he said there was a different perception when overseas investment was balanced with the foreign debt.

This is despite official statistics showing the costs of servicing foreign debt and equity are about $18 billion a year, while Australian lending and investment brings back only about $5 billion a year.

SPEECH.PARA: An article by Ross Gittins highlighted the same point, that we keep cruising straight across our current account deficit. Not one person on the government front bench has any experience in running a business, in making a profit at the end of each year to make sure he can pay his tax and his employees' wages, and to make sure they have a job at the end of the year. Government members have no experience in running a business. They have no experience in running this country, so we cruise straight past this exploding foreign debt. As Ross Gittins said:
. . . how come the . . . current account deficit is $13 billion?

PARA.TAB: Because of the bit that they don't tell you about: the net income deficit. It's running at $11.9 billion. In April, the net income deficit explained $1.2 billion of the total current account deficit of $1.6 billion. And it was up almost $200 million . . .
So, what is this great lump that takes a small trade deficit and turns it into the huge, $1 billion-plus current account deficit that appals us every month?
It's the interest bill on our foreign debt. . .

SPEECH.PARA: It is there every single month. Twelve times a year we must pay that interest bill. As that debt increases we need economic growth and business investment just to pay the interest—not to help increase the benefits to our economy or to improve employment prospects; just to pay the interest on that foreign debt.

PARA.TAB: When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition made his speech on the budget yesterday, we heard an interjection that the debt servicing ratio is coming down. That is irrelevant. By comparison, it is too high. This government is adopting a car salesman approach, a McCarthyist approach. It keeps telling people, `It's all right. We're reducing the economic indicators.' It does not matter. They are still miles too high to gain the benefits that this economy is supposed to be getting and that both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are telling us about today. Anybody on the government benches who has ever run a business in private enterprise knows what it is all about. They know about producing income and profit to make sure that the business is sustainable.

What business person would go into a program of selling assets and using growth dividends to pay for one-off programs to fund an ever growing public service? They would not do it. They would reduce the principal that they pay that high interest on. They would do something about. But not this government; it does not know. An article in the Weekend Australian reports comments by Mr Don Mercer, Chief Executive of the ANZ Banking Group. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mercer said that while Australia was "well-positioned for the strong and sustained recovery it deserves" he feared the opportunity would be wasted.
"Put simply, most of the gains from a stronger economic outlook—the so-called `growth dividend'—are not being used to wind back the deficit and increase saving but it will be spent," Mr Mercer said.

That is exactly what will happen. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister, and all the members on the government side, can say to us and the Australian people as much as they like, `Don't worry; trust us,' but indicators show that they are not managing this economy properly. They should have seized upon the opportunity to use that dividend growth. If they sell assets, they should use the proceeds of those asset sales to reduce our debt so that each month we do not pay so much in interest payments servicing that debt and we are not putting pressure on our economy.

PARA.TAB: We heard from the Treasurer that one-off factors were holding the economy back. How many years will we hear about one-off factors? Every time something good happens in our economy and it looks like it should come across, there is a one-off factor that is `just holding us back'. It `just has us by the shirt tails'. The government keeps saying that the current account is improving. It is not improving. Our real interest rates are too high. Our foreign debt is too high. Our debt servicing ratio is too high. Our unemployment is too high. Our industrial relations policy is completely confusing and business investment is not coming through. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the best conjunction of economic circumstances in 30 years. So what do we get in this House today from the opposition? We get a diet of pessimism. The opposition says that growth is bad. `We cannot have high growth. Growth is bad. Low tax is bad.' We have given $3 billion worth of tax concessions per year to business so that they will invest but, according to the opposition, that is bad. It says that low inflation is bad. If we listened to the opposition, nothing is good in this country. Do you know why? It goes to the heart of their philosophy. The opposition's creed is: greed is good. Greed is the only thing that it believes is good, which is why it has produced policies such as those enshrined in Fightback.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to see from recent events that some on your side of the House happen to agree with that assessment of your philosophy and approach to economic affairs. The former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: To walk away now would be to make the Party what it has never been—the plaything of faceless "power brokers" and political operators, and the captive of particular interest groups whose priorities are not those of ordinary Australians.

That says it all. The barren nature of the opposition's policy alternative is coming not just from those opposite. In the Weekend Australian, B.A. Santamaria, someone who is not known to support the current government, spoke on the policy stance of those opposite and those leading it, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello). He said:
It is pre-eminently the party of new-rich practitioners of the money market, of property developers, of rapidly growing gambling interests, of alleged "entrepreneurs", and of those who service them.
This new class does not talk the language of the ordinary people . . . It has no community of interest or even contact with them.

That is certainly true going by the contributions in the House today. Not many other people in the community agree with the opposition's assessment of the economy—certainly no-one who is in charge of or responsible for running a significant business in the country, with the exception of perhaps one person. Nobody agrees with the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what the business community has had to say in recent times. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said that the budget `will do much to build business confidence'. It has not been known to support the Labor Party in the past. The Australian Mining Industry Council, which is not known to be a strong supporter of the government, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Thumbs up for the budget.
Bert Evans, the Chief Executive of the MTIA, described the initiatives of the white paper:
. . . as a constructive contribution to public policy, one which provides new directions to industry policy while genuinely attempting to address unemployment.

The list goes on. Nobody who is significant in the business community, who is responsible for investing and employing people, agrees with the opposition. That is how out of touch the opposition is with the business sector and the ordinary people in the community.

PARA.TAB: When we deliver $3 billion worth of tax concessions to business, those opposite come into this House and say we should not deliver them and that we should lop that amount off the deficit. We will not do that. They do not believe that growth is good. They have no policies apart from abolishing the social safety net, be it in industrial relations or in the social welfare system. They have no taxation policy other than flat taxation and a GST. That is why they believe that greed is good and why they are opposed to so many other aspects of the current economic policy.

What have those opposite had to say about an economical alternative if everything that we are doing at the moment is so bad? The only thing they have really called for is massive cuts to public expenditure. That is still clear. However, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has said that, whilst Fightback has been dumped, there are parts of it which can be improved upon. The part which those opposite are obviously going to improve upon is the massive cuts to public expenditure.

We all know that the Leader of the Opposition is on the record as saying that we should have Asian levels of taxation in this country. If we are going to have Asian levels of taxation, we will have to have Asian levels of spending. If we are going to move towards Asian levels of taxation and spending, we will be looking at cutting in this country somewhere between $10 billion and $30 billion worth of revenue per year. If we moved to an Indonesian model, the opposition would lop $12 billion off current expenditure, the equivalent of abolishing all current expenditure on aged care.

If we were to move to the Taiwanese model, the opposition would cut expenditure in this country by $33 billion per year, which would be equivalent to abolishing all expenditure on aged care, assistance to families, veterans and so on. Its only current economical alternative is massive cuts to public expenditure. That is something which will be exposed in this House in the weeks ahead.

What will also be exposed is the nature of the alternative leadership that the opposition is putting forward. There is no doubt that in the recomposition of the frontbench all those people who were pre-eminent in putting Fightback together have come back into prominent positions. We have a few new spokes in the wheel, but it is the same old flat tyre. These people come from the group that brought us Fightback. All the people who were advocating inequitable forms of taxation, such as a 15 per cent GST, massive cuts to public expenditure and so on, are all back in prominent positions on the front bench.

The former Leader of the Opposition is the spokesman for industry. That should scare the living daylights out of any serious industrialist in this country. People who manufacture and export goods in this country are frightened witless of the former Leader of the Opposition being in the role of industry spokesman.

Let us look at who else there is. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is affectionately called `Dog' by the Premier of Victoria. If his friends refer to him as `Dog', what do his enemies call him? Is it some sort of reference to his approach to economic policy? Does it refer to `Mad Dog', which means we have to have even larger cuts to public expenditure? Is that the sort of alternative that the opposition is putting forward?

Look at the employment spokesman, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). He does not believe in labour market programs. He was a prominent adviser to former Prime Minister Fraser while his brother worked for former Senator Margaret Guilfoyle.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not care from where it originates, but the use of the expression `dog' is clearly unparliamentary. I regard it as offensive to have any of my colleagues referred to in that fashion. If your superior, Mr Speaker, can declare that the use of the word `hypocrite' is unparliamentary, surely to goodness the use of the word `dog' is unparliamentary. I ask that it be withdrawn forthwith.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to speak to the point of order. During question time, the colleague of the honourable member at the table, the honourable member for Kooyong, referred to me as a little worm. I allowed this to pass, partly because I did not hear it. I wonder whether you might also take that into account.

—I want to speak further to the point of order. I will be frank. What has triggered this is the extraordinarily narrow interpretation that Mr Speaker has taken. If you are going to disallow `hypocrite', then `dog' should not be accepted.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member for Lilley might assist the chair by withdrawing the remark. He cannot get away with expressions like that by attributing them to somebody else.

—It was not my expression, but I withdraw. The frontbench of the opposition is composed of members of the hard Right all drawn from the Fraser period. They are all conspirators with the President of the Liberal Party, Mr Staley. They all oppose safety nets, want the abolition of the industrial umpire and put forward massive cuts in public expenditure.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has claimed that the frontbench is lean. The numbers were brought down from 45 to 44. If that is lean, I would like to see what is really lean. More than that, it is not lean, but it is certainly very mean. The honourable member for Wentworth is in the industry portfolio. He believes in zero tariffs. I am sure that will please many manufacturers in this country.

We have a hard Right composition. It is not lean or new, but it is mean. We have yesterday's men replacing yesterday's men. They just keep doing the circle. In the military, retired generals usually go to the private sector. In the Liberal Party, they stay on the front bench. There are more retired generals there than there are in the Israeli army. That is the sort of frontbench that the opposition puts forward as a credible group that can formulate an alternative economic plan for this country. The fact is that there has been no change in the opposition except for a move to the right. It is an advocacy of very harsh public sector cuts and a continued advocacy for unfairness in the taxation system.

The government will continue to produce strong growth and, with that, the jobs and increased living standards that we require and a fairer distribution of wealth in our community. They are a set of decent principles and standards which are opposed by the opposition. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —These measures to change the nature of the family reunion program emphasising youth and skills, taken in an independent category, have occasioned a major change in the intake to the point where most analysis shows that the actual skills level is above that of the Australian population. However, at the same time, we have to ensure that English literacy assistance goes to those Australians who are unemployed after decades of productive work in occupations where English skills were not necessarily essential or actively encouraged. That has been a focus of the government, particularly over the last two to three years.

PARA.TAB: The measures specifically relating to citizens from non-English speaking backgrounds will be of some assistance in my electorate. Reid, as a site of AMES facilities, relatively cheap housing, existing non-English speaking background populations, reasonable public transport and DIEA units, receives many new arrivals. Teachers and principals have recently raised the particular problem of ESL pupils being established in their classes for six months and then, after a struggle to assist, moving from the DIEA flats to other areas. The teachers are then forced to start again. One group of pupils was dislocated at an early stage. Teachers had to go through the disheartening process of trying to help another group with very few language skills whilst at the same time keeping to the curriculum with the rest of the class.

Equally, it has been queried whether disadvantaged school programs necessarily fully compensate for the strains on already underprivileged schools by being the nurturing grounds for large numbers of students lacking elementary English skills. I note in comparative US situations demands and threatened legal action by Florida and California against the US administration because of the undue burden on their states occasioned by unauthorised migration.

There are positive initiatives in this budget. The total program to help the survivors of torture and trauma receives a healthy increase. Advocates will aid people such as the Bosnian victims by accompanying them to services, explaining their problems and aiding them to locate the required help. After January 1995, those people who have become permanent residents through the humanitarian program will not have to live in Australia for a set period to obtain the aged pension or disability and sole parent pensions. We speak here of people who for all intents and purposes are the equivalent of refugees. Seven thousand people who have typically suffered extreme hardship and the threat of death are helped by this change in the next financial year. The recognition that these residents had limited options should continue to be accompanied by strenuous restrictions on easy access for other permanent residence categories. In contrast, they freely select Australia, with its advantageous social welfare provisions, over other lands.

I also endorse the government's expenditure for a campaign to promote citizenship and the additional moneys that will fund 25 additional grants in aid. I am well aware of the tremendous effort current recipient groups undertake in my electorate for settlement needs. The migration agents registration requirements have put a particular stress on those few with accredited employees. A particular thrust would be to help the labour marketability of new arrivals through ensuring access to training.

I recently held discussions with the National Immigration Forum. One of its many legitimate concerns was the non-availability of a designated and funded group to assist humanitarian non-refugee claimants. I note that, within the $2 million for an extra 40 grants, specific provision is made for the settlement needs of these groupings. I well understand that this does not necessarily cover advocacy requirements, but it does indicate government recognition of their situation.

The government has committed itself to maintenance of the literacy component within the workplace English language and literacy provisions at nearly $8 million. This is a facet of a broader agenda that in recent years has guaranteed more help for long-term residents who worked in often arduous industries for decades, surviving without extensive English. In 1994 they are gravely threatened by the changing nature of the work force and industry itself. Those retrenched have difficulties competing in a buyers' labour market.

I take the opportunity to express disquiet at an unexpected outcome of AMES changes. We appreciate the government's introduction of a 510-hour guarantee and widespread exemptions from payments. Unfortunately, this has been accompanied by a requirement that employees unable to complete their courses in one year because of work commitments should have to pay an annual fee—in other words, pay for a second year if they have not completed the course in the first year. This should be reviewed. English as a second language training within the special intervention program for unemployed people will be doubled to 22,000 starts by 1995-96.

Finally, I welcome the opportunities opened up by the white paper regarding the new enterprise incentive scheme expansion and permission for such organisations as migrant resource centres to tender as NEIS managing agents. DEET advisory committees will increase options for consultation with migrant groupings. There will be a network of 50 DEET liaison officers to ensure advances in service delivery to migrants. The dramatic presence of regional employment disparities was highlighted by the Kelty development task force. Some suggestions have been mirrored in the white paper. Working Nation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The opportunities Australians have to work and to prosper are, in large part, determined by the economic prosperity of their local area. . . The better (business, government, unions and community) interact, the more likely it is that economic and social objectives will be achieved.

Amongst objectives in this government assault on unemployment is the effort to lessen capital problems for small and medium enterprises by reducing the concessional tax rate for pooled development funds from 25 per cent to 15 per cent for income derived from investments in such firms. This will possibly sponsor regional development. Some restrictions on PDFs will be relaxed to encourage take-up, particularly by superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, for infrastructure bonds the government proposes a 33 per cent optional tax rebate as an alternative to non-assessible income. Bonds can now be utilised for aviation facilities, electricity transmission and water infrastructure. Importantly, disposal of any infrastructure construction will be permitted within the 25-year period if the proposed purchaser is sufficiently commercial. The existing maximum period of 10 years for the tax concession will significantly rise to 15 per cent. All of these measures are relevant to chronic unemployment black spots such as Sydney's Auburn municipality and the Granville ward of the Parramatta council.

I refer to an article headed `Enterprise Zones Will Not Work' by Phillip Kasinitz and Jan Rosenberg in the City Journal of autumn 1993. Admittedly, this was limited in its coverage to a particular initiative: tax breaks for private employers to situate their jobs in depressed US areas. The article systematically delineated practices in Red Hook, Brooklyn. After summarising the failures, it concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in a loose labour market it is easier and more efficient for employers to find new employees through informal referral systems, particularly when local residents are perceived as unreliable and prone to crime. The idea of enterprise zones reflects a basic misunderstanding of the relationship between living space and working space.

I congratulate this government on changes to PDFs and infrastructure bonds and the labour market improvements which should interface with the 60 area consultative committees. As noted, the latter can become positive boosters of the jobs compact. What has to be monitored with tremendous vigilance is the nature of these committees and the utilisation of the regional strategies infrastructure. Depending upon the interest of other levels of government, as much as $150 million could be allocated to these areas by 1997-98.

PARA.TAB: The previous local government works program was noble in sentiment and entailed a welcome equity provision in its allocation of nearly $350 million to municipalities of higher unemployment. It aided urban renewal, public facilities, and roads, water and sewerage allocation. They often encompassed recreational and tourist projects. Unfortunately, whilst going in the right direction, the bands receiving assistance were too wide and tied to per capita criteria rather than to unemployment levels alone. Narrower groupings of especially deprived councils should have received greater help.

More seriously, the case of the use by the rather notorious Parramatta council again involved a geographic distortion that owed more to electorate boundaries and less to analysis of depressed areas. It is noteworthy that the main project was an adjunct to the Riverside Theatre, which provides as much public information about its finances as Coca-Cola does about its formula. The Commonwealth parliament cannot surrender oversight on the false assumption that, because federal ministers and public servants are at arms length, political distortions do not emerge. These committees and these financial incentives must be cemented in a very real analysis of the specific skills disparities and unemployment levels within councils and regions so as not to allow the edifice complex to reign supreme.

I note on page 19 of the summary paper advocacy of `the formation of regional economic groupings and increasing their ability to function effectually'. In the report itself, at page 164, there are promises of `assistance to regions to establish a representative regional wide development organisation. In many cases existing regional organisations will meet the criteria.' Laudable sentiments, I am sure, but we must guard to ensure that the embryonic bureaucracies of larger councils with their backslapping relationships with chambers of commerce do not ipso facto predominate over smaller councils with more pressing demands who lack those resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I wish to address one of the most important issues facing the resources sector in this country today, namely, Australia's policy stance on the greenhouse effect. When I say `Australia's policy stance on the greenhouse effect', it is really the government's lack of a credible stance I am referring to.
