In its eagerness to get the budget out, the government overlooked important developments in the greenhouse agenda. If the government's current inattention continues, this debacle will be remembered for far longer and have more impact than this budget ever will.

PARA.TAB: The entire greenhouse debate is marked by confusion. It is my aim to put some clarity into this debate today. The greenhouse effect is a phenomenon in which some of the solar energy reflected from the earth's surface is absorbed by the atmosphere rather than being lost to space. As a result, the temperature of the atmosphere may rise. The enhanced greenhouse effect refers to human activity in industrial processes giving rise to greenhouse gases. The so-called greenhouse gases are those which allow the atmosphere to heat up in this way.

The principal scientific debate relates to the amount of these gases required for the temperature of the atmosphere to rise significantly. The commonest greenhouse gas, and the most easily produced by industrial processes, is carbon dioxide. It is worth noting that carbon dioxide is a naturally occurring gas which makes up a significant proportion of the earth's atmosphere.

Today I will not buy into the scientific debate over whether the greenhouse effect is as serious as some commentators have suggested. I will merely call in passing for some more balance in the debate, and for both sides to give each other a respected hearing. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, in its report released earlier this week entitled Greenhouse response: effectiveness of the implementation of an interim program, noted that there has been a warming of the Earth's surface consistent with the increase in concentration of greenhouse gases, but it remains to be established whether the warming can be attributed to the enhanced greenhouse effect. That very good report goes on to say that it is clear that if this change in temperature continues to grow in magnitude it could have serious implications for the earth's climate.

So what has the Australian government done about greenhouse? The answer is not much, and certainly not enough particularly when the opportunities that exist are considered. In August 1990 the government announced the creation of nine sectoral working groups to examine ecologically sustainable development, which included the examination of greenhouse issues. While these nine groups were significant in bringing together disparate views and finding common ground, no-one involved would deny that the momentum generated then has largely been allowed to dissipate.

In October 1990, the Commonwealth adopted an interim planning target for the reduction of greenhouse gases. This target involves stabilising the emission of these gases at 1998 levels by the year 2000, and then reducing emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005. This target was subject to the most important caveat that Australia would not proceed with the adoption of measures which would have net adverse economic impacts nationally or would affect Australia's trade competitiveness, particularly in the absence of similar action by other major greenhouse gas producing countries.

Let there be no misunderstanding, greenhouse is not just an environmental issue; it is a very real economic and trade issue, particularly for Australia. At the same time as the interim planning target was announced, the need for a nationally coordinated approach was accepted and the government began working towards a national greenhouse response strategy. As part of a holding approach while the strategy was developed, a number of measures were identified which were to both reduce greenhouse gas emissions and result in cost savings. Then in June 1992 the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed by 154 countries, including Australia. The convention's objective is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to achieve stabilisation for greenhouse gas emissions at a level that would prevent dangerous human interference with the climate system.

This objective is to be met through a range of measures including research and development, education, and information programs. An unofficial target of the convention has been that countries should stabilise greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. Australia has ratified the convention and, following ratification by the 50th country, the convention recently entered into force.

PARA.TAB: A meeting of the parties to the convention will be held in March 1995 in Berlin. This will be the first meeting of the permanent body which will drive the convention's objectives and activities in the future. Closer to home, the national greenhouse strategy was released by the Australian government in December 1992. It is the vehicle by which Australia will meet its international obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

The goals of this domestic strategy include: to contribute towards effective global action to limit greenhouse gas emissions, to improve knowledge and understanding of the enhanced greenhouse effect, and to prepare for potential impacts of climate change in Australia. The five areas for priority action are: the preparation of a national greenhouse gas inventory to facilitate monitoring and evaluation of the progress of the strategy, community involvement, the establishment of a national greenhouse advisory panel, measures to address greenhouse gas emissions in the production and use of energy, and research and development.

This strategy is being implemented in phases. During the first phase particular attention is being given to energy production, distribution and use. This is entirely reasonable as there are many initiatives which can be adopted which not only reduce greenhouse gas emissions but save money as well. For instance, replacement of electric motors with more energy efficient motors will save a business money through decreased electricity consumption, which also reduces greenhouse gas emissions from the plant supplying the electricity—plain commonsense.

The government has correctly identified a number of measures as a first step which can establish a framework for proposals for further reductions in greenhouse gases to be considered at an international level. These initial actions emphasise an integrated least cost approach to energy planning; energy pricing adjustments which better reflect economic, social and environmental costs; the promotion of greater use of co-generation schemes; minimum energy performance standards for appliances and equipment; fuel efficiency improvement in new motor vehicles; provision of information for energy users; and research and development in relation to energy efficiency, energy demand reduction, renewable energy systems and reduction of adverse environmental impacts.

This is all very worth while, in particular with regard to co-generation. I was very pleased to see the progress recently in the east of my electorate of Gippsland, at Orbost, of a significant co-generation facility proposal to burn wood waste, generate electricity, and kiln dry hardwoods for furniture and structural uses. This is certainly the way of the future, and I commend honourable members seeking to encourage regional development to examine the progress of this outstanding operation in East Gippsland.

To summarise, over recent years the government has been working on a range of measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Australia while committing Australia to even tighter targets and schedules in the international arena. Unfortunately, both of these elements of the government's approach appear to be doomed to failure. Sadly, the government has failed to put in place effective energy management programs which would help Australia meet the various targets.

In May 1993 the Australian National Audit Office reported that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had not taken sufficient action to implement the package of greenhouse initiatives announced in October 1990, despite the sense of urgency intended by the government. The audit office also found that, by the end of 1992, the complete framework for making energy savings in the government's own operation was still being put into place. It also found that the significant use of energy in manufacturing had been relatively neglected and that there was scope to expand greatly the understanding of energy efficiency in other sectors. The audit office also concluded that studies with the states on the energy use of appliances and buildings needed to be advanced to nationally consistent actions.

A report by independent consultants at about the same time as the Auditor-General's investigation queried the effectiveness and relevance of the government's programs. The House of Representatives committee report on greenhouse, which I referred to earlier and which was presented in this parliament one or two days ago, found that one year on from that Auditor-General's report of May 1993 little, if anything, had changed. That committee's report highlighted the government's failure to provide anything like the staffing or funding necessary for effective programs. The failure of this strategy will compound undeniably the reluctance by business to adopt new and more energy efficient technologies. Yet this is a key plank of the government's high profile campaign to reduce greenhouse gases.

These measures are the most basic. They are often called `no regrets' measures because they result in cost savings as well as reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, these measures are not enough to meet Australia's greenhouse reduction commitments by themselves. Even if they are adopted without qualification, they will allow just half of the 20 per cent reduction target to be met. It is very clear from discussions with industry that far more work has been done on addressing the implications of meeting that second 10 per cent reduction than has been done by the government to meet its first 10 per cent reduction.

Unfortunately, the government has crashed at the first hurdle in regard to greenhouse. Addressing this problem will require a concerted and cooperative effort by electricity supply utilities, business groups and government to put Australia's energy management strategy back on track.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the wind farm proposal?

—The honourable member for Dunkley asks about the wind farm proposal in Gippsland. I noticed that he raised this in a 90-second statement on Monday. He said that it was located in Lakes Entrance. But it is located in Toora in South Gippsland, which is some two hours drive from Lakes Entrance.
—Well, in your electorate.
—It is certainly within my area. The honourable member also went on to say in blessed ignorance that it had been abandoned because of the excessive costs of maintenance.

—No, it has nothing to do with maintenance. It was abandoned because it would require a subsidy of $1.2 million every year to continue it. I have written to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) suggesting that the federal government, given its environmental and greenhouse rhetoric in particular, may wish to contact the Victorian government and work through arrangements to share this burden. It would cost Victorian taxpayers $1.2 million a year. So, if the honourable member for Dunkley is as good as his own personal rhetoric, he will make supporting representations with me. The federal government, which is happy to take the glory regarding—
—It will test his bona fides.

—It will test his bona fides; it will test them beautifully. If you want the wind farm to continue, you should get the Commonwealth government to share the $1.2 million subsidy required. For the information of the honourable member for Dunkley, I am still waiting for a reply from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, but I hope that he will see the sense in assisting the project.

PARA.TAB: I will return to the subject matter at hand. As a start, it is imperative that the federal government demonstrate leadership on the issue and overhaul its own energy management programs. The second plank of the government's strategy on greenhouse is the international agreements that I have already touched on. In recent days, the coalition has highlighted the importance of international treaties in arbitrarily restricting the sovereignty of Australia. We believe that Australians have a fundamental right to determine their future without interference from other countries.

I think the government has abrogated to a very large extent the national sovereignty and our ability to determine our own destiny. I think the government shows a blatant disregard for the importance of this parliament, in that treaties can be signed by the executive—and it is currently estimated that Australia is now a signatory to more than 2,000 treaties—without any proper parliamentary scrutiny or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as happened in the UK; just as happened in New Zealand.

—The minister interjects that it happens in the UK and New Zealand. Of course you would put that argument because you are always wanting to follow the leader on the international stage. How about we make our own decisions about what is in our own interests. As a result of the government's abrogation of its responsibility in so many international conventions and treaties, you can rightly fear that the government will commit Australia to a reduction in greenhouse gases that will damage our trade competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: There is a real danger that Australia, in an effort to appear greener than green, will agree to greenhouse reduction targets that will severely damage our competitiveness. This is particularly so if a per capita decrease in greenhouse gases is agreed to. Australia has a high per capita greenhouse gas emission because of the availability of cheap fuel and enormous mineral resources. The combination has meant that Australia has naturally developed a high reliance on resources and energy intensive industries. These industries contribute crucially to our present standard of living and to our future prosperity.

Agreement to a percentage cut in greenhouse gas emissions would hit Australia's industries hardest because of our dependence on energy. Our trade competitors would reap the benefits while we do business with one hand tied behind our backs. In order to meet the UN convention target of stabilising greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels in the year 2000, the United States would require only a seven per cent reduction in emissions while Australia would have to undergo a massive 24 per cent reduction. It is also important to remember that countries that import our coal would be subject to the same reductions. This could be a disaster for our industrial backbone, particularly when you consider that, despite our high per capita emissions, Australia contributes only one per cent of global greenhouse gases. It is vitally important that the government not compromise our national interest by agreeing to measures which affect Australian industry more than our trade competitors.

We must take a strong position to the next greenhouse meeting in Berlin in March of next year. The government must be prepared to stand by its prepared position and not accept a compromise which damages our international competitiveness. The delegation to Berlin must be firmly aware of the economic consequences of trying to be greener than the rest of the world. It must recognise that climate change is as much a trade and competitiveness issue as an environmental issue. I think the comments of Senator Gareth Evans in recent weeks show how embryonic the government's thinking is on this matter.

It is not good enough that cabinet has yet to determine its position on this issue, as Senator Gareth Evans recently admitted in the press. Unfortunately, the government has let the issue slip while the budget was prepared, but it must focus on it now. Now is the time that the government should be taking its position to like-minded countries and developing alliances which will carry real weight in Berlin. The government must also address the shameful neglect of domestic energy management which has caused its commitment on the entire greenhouse issue to be called into question. If it is left until cabinet turns its mind to it after the budget, I fear that it will be far too late.

This is an important issue which occupies a great deal of time and effort by individual members, but I do not see the commitment to reducing greenhouse gases being translated from generalised rhetoric and platitudes into concrete action. We have already had an Auditor-General's report slamming the government for its inaction and its failure of leadership. Twelve months later, that has been repeated by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. There are enough warning signs for the government to give this vital issue—now and into the future—the priority and attention it so obviously deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills provide funding for the activities of the Commonwealth government. This government is proud to defend its expenditure to enhance the wealth, equity and future prospects of this nation. It is to the discredit of the opposition that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and his colleagues are on record in support of Fightback's slashing of government services to Asian standards. During the debate on the matter of public importance this afternoon, that issue was raised. Indeed, the Liberal Party spokesman on employment, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), informed Liberal students last year that he was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . impressed on a recent visit to China, Korea and Japan how the operation of market forces has a powerful equalising influence on the material conditions of the people.

On this side of the House, we do not consider that the Asian experience of social equality provides a powerful lesson for Australia. The government is prepared to defend its welfare system, particularly from those whose perceptions were formed by the view from the Shanghai Hilton and by the renowned world vision of the Adelaide Club.

PARA.TAB: The government in Australia is neither high taxing nor high spending. Government taxes and expenditures as a proportion of gross domestic product are among the lowest of the OECD members. Unlike the opposition, we do not mouth idle words about efficiency. This government is committed to ensuring that its services achieve world's best practice. This applies right across the board, from education and training to labour relations, to taxation, to regulations, and to infrastructure provisions. A national competition policy will be the outcome of the recent Council of Australian Governments agreement to implement the findings of the Hilmer report.

The industry, science and technology portfolio is one of the most vital areas of government. Australia's interests are well-served by a dynamic Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), who combines realistic appreciation of industry's capabilities with a sound knowledge of the international marketplace. Senator Cook's leadership is set to improve the opportunities and future prospects for our children.

By contrast, the opposition has placed its dumped former leader, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), in this important shadow ministry. Still clutching a copy of Fightback to his chest, the shell-shocked member for Wentworth told Perth radio's Howard Sattler last week that Fightback would `continue to be revamped and looked at in the light of current circumstances' and that `most people in our party were very proud of what we took to the last election and it's a question of refining it, developing it, repackaging it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was dead and buried.

—Not only is Fightback dead and buried in the electorate, but also, unfortunately, like Dracula, it now seeks to rear its head. The honourable member for Wentworth is understandably still bitter about the betrayal and treachery of his colleagues about whom he has made public comment. Perhaps he should have recalled the words of Sir Humphrey Appleby in the television program Yes, Minister: `You have to get right behind someone to stab them in the back.'

PARA.TAB: The investment prospects of this nation are too important to be held up by personal revenge. Investors have the right to know the opposition's policies, even if the likelihood of the opposition forming a government is remote. Investor questions need to be answered. Is the honourable member for Wentworth proposing to undo the sensible approach to industry policy adopted by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) who, it must be said, quietly went about his business without any noticeable support from his colleagues? Is the honourable member for Wentworth going to repackage his zero tariff policy? Is he going to extend his confrontational approach to industry beyond the auto industry, the clothing, textiles and footwear industry, the tourism industry and the building industry? Let us hope that he does not ask for assistance from the present Leader of the Opposition.

Following the present Leader of the Opposition's discussions with Ford in the United States last year, he issued a press release dated 15 July 1993 entitled `Ford confirms it could leave Australia' in which he said that it was clear to him:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the level of tariff protection in Australia, and plans to reduce tariff protection were not an over-riding consideration, particularly as Ford operates with just a 2.5 per cent tariff in the United States.

What did industry think of these views? The President of Ford Australia, John Ogden, was reported as saying that the then shadow Treasurer, the current Leader of the Opposition, was talking `absolute farcical nonsense that defied description'. Mr Ogden specifically denied the assertion that Ford's main concerns were the inflexible labour market, restrictive work practices and low productivity, and not the opposition's destructive tariff policy. In this regard, I refer to a report by Tom Connors in the Canberra Times on 17 July 1993.

PARA.TAB: The rise of the current Leader of the Opposition has been attributed not only to the treachery against the honourable member for Wentworth but also to support from the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, and his so-called pragmatic political philosophy. The Fraser government's desperation for power was unquestionable; we all know that. But in clinging to power it was paralysed by a gridlock of vested interests. Tax rorts, financial deregulation, tariff reform and a sensible approach to workplace relations were only a few of the issues the Fraser government avoided.

The dismal statistics of the Fraser government's performance on economic growth, inflation, unemployment, international debt and industrial disputation are well known, but it is worth recalling the figures on industrial research and development. Under the Fraser government business expenditure on research and development fell from around 0.4 per cent of GDP to around 0.25 per cent of GDP.

The policies pursued by this government have reversed the Fraser government's destruction of Australia's industrial research and development capacity. This year's science and technology statement produced by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology shows that over the last 10 years Australia experienced the fastest rate of growth in external patent applications in the OECD, and one of the fastest rates of growth in business expenditure on R&D. Australia's expenditure on research and development by government agencies and universities, at 0.79 per cent, is well above the OECD average of 0.62 per cent. But business expenditure of 0.57 per cent remains well below the one to two per cent range of major industrialised nations.

Earlier this month I called on the opposition to address the very serious matter of a shadow minister for science denigrating Australia's capabilities. I am delighted that the current Leader of the Opposition has so promptly moved the honourable member for Goldstein on to other duties. I have no doubt that, in so doing, he acted on advice from Liberal premiers, who were horrified by the damage to their efforts to promote investment in Australia caused by the shallow, politically motivated comments of the honourable member for Goldstein.

But I am still not happy with the opposition's approach to science and technology. In view of the pressing need to boost industrial research and development, and to link public sector science to industry, it sends all the wrong messages about bundling science and technology into the education portfolio. The last time we had a minister for education, science and technology was back in the 1960s when Malcolm Fraser held that position. Now we have another example of how it will happen in this portfolio: Malcolm Fraser's hand is now in science, technology and education. This will have been an unfortunate side-effect of youthful experimentation by the current Leader of the Opposition. This is a flashback to the 1960s by the current Leader of the Opposition.

But, for all his faults, the honourable member for Goldstein has the capacity to quote and quote well. One of his favourite quotes is from Michael Porter, an influential Harvard academic, who has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The overarching principle in addressing science and technology should be to create an innovation policy and not just a science and technology policy. Science and technology cannot be decoupled from its commercial application in seeking to enhance national advantage.

That is a perfectly logical statement. But, of course, Professor Porter is quite correct, and that is why the opposition must immediately decouple science and technology from education where its commercial application will be swamped politically by the persuasive voices of a thousand and more sincere, hard-working and underfunded academics. The challenge for Australia is to continue to grow our industrial research and development base. That is why the government, in the white paper entitled Working Nation, places priority on supporting innovation. There should be bipartisan support for this policy.

PARA.TAB: This government is committed to increasing the number of firms undertaking research and development in Australia—small firms as well as large in the service and resources sector as well as in manufacturing. To this end, the eligibility requirements for the 150 per cent tax concession for R&D have been eased, allowing greater access for small and medium sized enterprises. Honourable members will recall the notorious Fightback policy was to reduce loss of revenue via the R&D tax concession by eliminating so-called tax rorts. What hope would small businesses have in claiming the tax concession for R&D under a coalition government? They would be swamped with paper.

In Working Nation the government has also introduced a new support scheme for specific early commercialisation in small high-technology firms. The government will develop a national technology diffusion and access network to enhance the links between business, science agencies and research and technology centres. Existing centres, such as the Queensland Manufacturing Institute in Brisbane and the South Australian Centre for Manufacturing, provide the model for new centres. Close links between our first-rate science base and our industry are critical to Australia's economic future. The government will be establishing a further 10 cooperative research centres later this year and has increased the base level of training and funding of the national science agencies. The Australian Institute of Marine Science has established a research group in Karratha, Western Australia. This will enhance national and international profile of aims in the field of tropical reef research.

The former opposition spokesman on science and technology, the honourable member for Goldstein, made a number of ill-informed statements about the government's support for CSIRO in the white paper and the budget. It is important that the misconceptions spread by the honourable member for Goldstein be firmly and comprehensibly rebutted. Recent government measures and CSIRO's own initiatives will ensure that the organisation continues to deliver excellent returns on investment by business and the Australian community. The increase in the base level of funding will enable a number of priority projects to begin or continue in the coming triennium.

For example, CSIRO will spend $10 million during this period to improve the access of small and medium sized enterprises to CSIRO technology and expertise. It will adopt a targeted approach to small and medium sized enterprises, establishing outreach groups throughout the organisation. It will increase the emphasis on secondments to and from industry. In this way, CSIRO hopes to double interaction with small and medium sized enterprises over the next five years. As well, CSIRO will be allocating some $7 million over the next three years to improve companies' access to-state-of-the-art or `smart' manufacturing technology and enhance their market responsiveness.

A more outward looking CSIRO will also boost its support for Australian companies in their efforts to tap into export markets. Over the triennium, CSIRO will continue to shift resources in response to national research priorities. CSIRO will increase its internal funding for research in minerals, manufacturing and the information and communications industries. Internal funding for environmental research will be maintained at about its present level. Rural research continues to rate highly. About 40 per cent of CSIRO's total research effort is devoted to this area. Current restructuring proposals aim to place the organisation in the best possible position to support the changing needs of its stakeholders in the animal, food and fibre industries over the next decade.

Over the triennium beginning with the financial year 1994-95, CSIRO will continue to receive appropriation funding averaging some $438 million per year in current prices. So the government is retaining the 30 per cent external earnings target for CSIRO. External earnings ranging from $220 million to $226 million per year are expected from CSIRO over the next three years. The significant amount of funding from these external sources reflects the strong links which continue to develop between CSIRO and the end users of research. I am glad to say that CSIRO will be in an improved position to attract external funding as a result of measures announced in the industry statement, Working Nation. For example, the lowering of the threshold for the 150 per cent tax concession will provide a greater incentive for small to medium sized enterprises to invest in R&D; changes to syndicated R&D arrangements should have the same effect.

These facts speak for themselves. CSIRO's important role has been maintained and enhanced by the government. The industry, science and technology policies of this government, set out in the white paper, Working Nation, and funded through the appropriation bills, signal a new phase in the government's approach to industry policy. This phase is about changing the emphasis from the adjustment policies of the 1980s to the post-tariff reform needs of the 1990s and beyond. It is also about removing impediments to industry, investment, productivity and innovation. We now have an industry policy that builds on the success of recent trade negotiations and the earlier work to restructure the Australian economy. Working Nation provides a stable framework for business to plan new investment and increase employment. I commend the expenditures, to implement the government's industry, science and technology policies, to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1994-95 seeks appropriations from consolidated revenue of $29,810.7 million to meet recurrent expenditures of the government—recurrent expenditures which, of course, include salaries, the costs of running the departments and some ongoing program costs. This is an additional amount of $830.8 million, which is up 2.9 per cent on the previous year and is $1 billion above the estimate last year. I think this is where we have to start to look at the government's credentials.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), gave an animated speech about what the government is doing in a particular area of its budget. But the overall trend, not the specifics, of where the country is going is fundamental. What we notice about this government's policy in economic terms is that we are increasingly running into debt. That is not by my standards or the coalition's standards, but by the government's standards.

It is absolutely fascinating to go back and have a look at what the government said in 1992 in regard to its One Nation package. When we have a look at its 1992 package we find that it set very clear standards that had to be achieved. The government said at that stage that it would only be economically responsible if the 1994-95 budget debt came in under $1 billion. That was only two years ago in February 1992. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) then said that the government would be economically responsible only if this nation brought in a budget deficit of less than $1 billion. In other words, its expenditure over receipts should be less than $1 billion.

What do we have in this budget? On the government's own figures, we have overspent by $11.7 billion. The opposition did not set this standard; the government did. The great tragedy for this country of ours is that the government continues to borrow money mainly from overseas to sustain its spending, and it spends more than it receives year after year. If we as a country are going to do that, one day somebody will have to find the money to pay it back. But this government appears to be ignorant of those simple straightforward facts. This budget can be likened to any family that earns $30,000 and spends $33,000. In other words, it overspends by 10 per cent. The government can set standards. It claims to be a master at setting standards. But the real test for any government in Australia is whether it can achieve the standards that it sets.

The government also said in its One Nation statement that in 1995-96 we would have a $2 billion budget surplus. What does the budget show us this year? The government brought in projected figures of $9.8 billion. In other words, the government was $12,000 million out. Either the government was telling us untruths in 1992 when it said that it was fiscally responsible to bring down a budget with a surplus of $2 billion or it is telling us untruths now. I think any objective observer of this would know that what we are being told now is totally irresponsible. The government knows it and it is doing it obviously with an eye and mind to the future political opportunities which it thought it might have.

Why believe in this government? That is the big question which all Australians should ask. The government set the standards back in 1992. It claimed they would be responsible standards. In this budget we see the government falling far short of its own standards, not just by a few hundred million dollars but, literally, by billions of dollars. So, in a financial sense, Australians cannot believe this government; nor should they ever believe the Labor Party when it talks about the economic management of this country.

One of the greatest indicators of the total irresponsibility of the Labor Party in managing the economic affairs of Australia is to go back and look at our overseas debt from 1901. In the first 83 years since Federation, Australia built up a gross debt of around $35,000 million. Eleven years later that figure stands at approximately $220,000 million. In other words, in 83 years it increased by $35,000 million and in the last 11 years under Labor—just listen to the figures—it increased by $185,000 million. That is the record of mismanagement of this government.

Speaker after speaker for the government will come in here and try to tell the Australian people that there are marvellous programs under way in this budget. On paper that might be true, but the reality is that Australia is continually borrowing from other people's savings to a point where it is going to create great difficulty for this country to repay. It will not be this generation which meets the repayments on the debts being incurred. Our children and our grandchildren will be responsible for the debts incurred by this Labor Party over the last 11 years—literally thousands of millions of dollars. It will be on their heads and around their necks for probably 10 to 15 years at least. Government members might come in here and talk about the marvellous programs, but they are not funding them out of the capacity of this nation's wealth at this stage. I think it is a great tragedy that we are going to leave our children with a greater debt than ever before.

Month by month we find that our current account deficit continues to be large. We often hear from the media that it is a bit better result, but the last couple of months have not been too good, not very good at all—a debt of around $1.6 billion. In the last month under your policies the debt went up $100 for every man, woman and child in this country. Nobody should be proud of that record.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do to stop it?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! If the honourable member for Braddon addressed his remarks through the chair he would not encourage that sort of interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take note of your comments. Not only can this government not be believed financially, but it certainly cannot be believed in other areas. To illustrate that, let us take one of the new catch areas—leading lights I suppose the Labor Party would say—in its training program.

PARA.TAB: It is all about trying to make a virtue of the one million people who are unemployed—a situation that was created by this government. Thousands and thousands of Australians were thrown on to the dole queues and now the government will make them highly trained unemployed people. At the end of the day, I suspect and firmly believe that the unemployment queues will not be all that much shorter.

Let us just go into what the budget says. It is really a charade. The paper projects 98,500 new places in 1993-94, rising to 148,500 in 1995-96. An analysis of the actual situation reveals a very different outcome. In 1993-94, a target of 46,000 apprenticeships is less than the target that we had in 1992-93. In actual fact, we are going backwards, not forwards.

Even in 1995-96, the target of 60,000 new apprenticeships will not have returned to the levels of four years ago. The government claims to do something for the unemployed, but in actual fact the target figures are not as high as they were four years ago. Let us look at traineeships. The target of 34,000 new trainees in 1995-96—double the current target—is unrealistic. Why do I say that? I say it because of experience. Again we find that this government sets itself targets but rarely if ever does it achieve them.

Let me illustrate. Since its inception, the Australian traineeship system has achieved only 68 per cent of the targeted number. So, even though the government says it is going to target 34,000 new trainees in 1995-96, which is double the current target, I wonder how many will really be achieved? It is all very well for the government to come in here and try to lead the Australian people to believe that there will be a massive increase in opportunities for employment and work because our young people and the people out there on the dole queues are going to be trained and therefore will get a job; the history of this government in this area and in many other areas is that it fails to deliver. I have no hesitation in saying that it will fail to deliver again.

From 1985 to 1993, of the 80,000 students who commenced traineeships, 24,000 dropped out—a 30 per cent drop-out rate. The traineeships include career start traineeships. In 1992-93, 3,000 career start traineeships were targeted. Have a guess as to how many actually commenced. This is 1992-93—we are not going very far back into history—and how many were commenced? The answer is 373, about 11 per cent. Eleven per cent of the targeted figure actually commenced. I wonder how many people ended up completing their traineeships. It was probably less than five per cent of what was hoped for.

What about prevocational places? Let us look at the government's record there. The target was 10,000 places for 1993-94 and 1994-95 and 15,000 places for 1995-96. That is less than the 18,000 places provided in 1992-93. So we have 10,000 and 15,000 places respectively in the years coming up, less than the government had targeted for 1992-93.

Let us look at Australian Public Service trainees. The white paper projects 1,500 places in 1993-94 and 2,000 in 1994-95. That is less than the 2,151 places in 1992-93. The traineeships in all the areas I have mentioned are an absolute charade on the Australian people. It is absolutely disgraceful for government members, particularly the Prime Minister, to come into this place and argue the case for people who are desperately lonely out there, people with families who are unable to make ends meet. The government holds out this carrot to them as if it is going to give them something marvellous, yet it is less than the government has offered before. Even the targets the government had before were never met.

There will be a tremendous number of disappointed people out there, unfortunately. I only wish the government could achieve its objectives. I only wish it had achieved its objectives in previous years. The government cannot be trusted to achieve its financial targets. It cannot be trusted to achieve its training targets for the million or so unemployed people out there.

The same is the case with industrial relations. We have just had a new industrial relations bill come into this parliament. It was supposed to be the new, you-beaut industrial relations package for this country, which would help lift us out of our malaise. What do we see within two months? We see the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) come into this place and do a total U-turn on some of the fundamentals of that package because the government did not get it right. The minister maintained that this was the industrial relations act of all acts, yet within two months we see the government again fail to deliver on its rhetoric, on its promises to the Australian people.

Unemployment is certainly the biggest social problem Australia faces. The government has done very little to bring about any solution to unemployment in this country. In 1983—the government is always very keen to go back to the past, it would appear in recent debates; it seems to be becoming a government of the past, not looking to the future very often—there were 624,900 unemployed. How many unemployed are there in 1993? There are 940,500. What about the long-term unemployed, the people who are out there doing it hard and tough? In 1983 there were 127,000 and in 1993 there are 336,000, a 300 per cent increase. Not only is the number of long-term unemployed much higher than under a previous coalition government but the time they spend unemployed is also much higher. The duration of unemployment in 1983 was only 15 weeks. It is now dragged out to just over 27 weeks.

This is the record of the Labor government. In the last 11 years this government has for the first time in certainly 60 or 70 years created a new underclass. As we heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), say in the MPI today, certainly we are not going to see—as the Prime Minister said—a class of working poor; they are unemployed poor, created by this government.

So we find now emerging in this great nation of ours an underclass of people who are unemployed for a long period without the capacity to get back in and have a slice of the action. The government cannot be trusted in financial matters. It cannot meet its objectives. It cannot be trusted in the training promises it has given to the Australian people. It cannot be trusted in its industrial relations promises. We see that here and now, this day, this week. It cannot be trusted to bring down unemployment with the promises which it has given. Not only that, it cannot be trusted in regard to its rhetoric on families. It talks about diversity in families but it is really encouraging the disintegration of families. That is the nature of this government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor Mr G.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) on producing a very good budget for Australia and a very good budget for the people of Geelong, whom I represent in this parliament today. Many people would appreciate that the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance have shouldered a very heavy burden in managing the white paper process and producing a budget in May instead of August. My congratulations go to them for a fine effort.

PARA.TAB: This budget is predicated on growth and will certainly produce a framework for job creation and a reduction in unemployment. As the Treasurer so succinctly pointed out on the first page of his budget speech, this budget will maximise growth, reduce unemployment, promote social justice and reduce the budget deficit without increasing taxes.

I might just comment on the social justice agenda of this government which has been addressed in the budget. I pay tribute to those ministers in the social portfolios that have given expression and effect to the strong social justice agenda that is pursued by this Labor government.

There are some in the community, particularly those on the opposition side, who doubt the economic basis on which the growth and investment projections have been made in the budget. We ought to compare the economic base that we have today with that which existed in 1982-83. We should recall that after that period we had six years of growth and sustained job creation.

With our current economic position, we are really poised for growth. Unemployment has fallen from its peak. It is now 10.3 per cent. More than 230,000 jobs have been created since April last year. Interest rates on bank lending are the lowest since the 1970s. Inflation is at its lowest level for three decades and, of course, inflationary expectations are quite low. Business confidence is high. Consumer confidence is the highest it has been for 10 years. We have had dramatic increases in productivity within the Australian economy. Our international competitiveness has improved by some 30 per cent. The time lost in industrial disputation in 1993 was the lowest for 30 years. The economic growth rate on which the job creation intentions of this government are based has in 1993 been some four per cent.

If we look at some of those economic variables in 1982-83, we will see a very different picture. But, despite the adverse economic variables at that particular point in our economic history, we still managed to grow on average by around four per cent and the Australian economy engaged itself in substantial job creation. The government has simply said, `We did it from 1982-83; for the six years after that. We can certainly do it again.' At that time unemployment stood at 10 per cent, inflation was double digit, interest rates were very high—in double figures—business confidence and consumer confidence were low, the Australian economy was racked with industrial disputation and jobs were being shed at a rate that had not occurred for decades. That was the legacy of the opposition. The opposition, as we well know, rewards those who held economic portfolios in the past and who failed. I will speak a little bit about that later.

The Australian economy is positioned on a platform which will certainly encourage economic growth. There has been debate in this chamber about the investment projections that are contained in the budget. But, of course, that is not the general community. If we look at the business community, it certainly supports the projections that the government has enunciated in this budget. Just two days ago the Age newspaper business council said that the government's forecasts were not an impossibility. The managing director of AMP said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the 14.5 per cent level of business investment is well within reach.

The National Australia Bank's projection for business investment is marginally higher than the government's. BHP's forecasts of business investment show growth of up to 15 per cent. These are people out in the economy, out in the marketplace. If they can provide projections that are roughly in line with that which the government has determined in the budget, then that is okay by me. Investment expenditure really is the key to sustained economic growth to the end of the decade. In recent times it has certainly been subdued.

PARA.TAB: I refer members of the opposition to the submission made by the MTIA to the recently completed government purchasing inquiry on which I sat. In its evidence it gave a very good analysis of why that investment had been slow and uneven. As we all know, the Australian economy has the capacity to accommodate higher production without a rise in investment. Productivity increases can be accommodated within the Australian economy without additional investments at this time.

Many people are saying that the recovery in profit levels should be driving higher levels of business investment. That may be so for some companies, but it is important to appreciate that the improved profitability levels for some enterprises are driven by debt and cost reductions. But, once the balance sheets are repaired in these enterprises and profitability levels come from increased sales expenditures on the goods and services produced by those firms, we will certainly see an improvement in investment.

The most interesting analysis the MTIA provided related to the globalisation of world trade and the emergence of new producers and markets. It indicated that this had certainly complicated the investment environment. Overseas parent companies are demanding higher rates of return on investments in Australia and have expanded options to place their investment around the world. So it was not simply a case that the overseas parent would choose to invest in Australia and stimulate the investment recovery in Australia.

We certainly do have a good investment platform at the moment with low interest rates, high consumer confidence, the prospect of improved demand, overall returning company profitability and the incentives that government has provided. Through this budget and other measures, I think we can confidently say the 14.5 per cent investment projection is likely to be understated. I refer the House to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade publication Composition of Trade, Australia, which indicates that imports of capital equipment are surging. It suggests that substantial investments are already under way in the small and medium business sector which are not picked up in the national account figures.

I am more than pleased not only with the general thrust of the budget and the white paper but also with the specific initiatives that will support working families in the Corio electorate in this International Year of the Family. Certainly, job creation in the region will flow from improved growth, and this will open up new opportunities for unemployed families in my electorate. The expansion of labour market programs, especially the job compact, will provide unemployed workers with a better opportunity to enter the job market by improving their skills and to take advantage of these new opportunities. The parenting allowance for the unemployed and low income earners will provide families in the Geelong area with a much needed boost to their disposable income.

There is a raft of other budget measures that will impact on the people of Geelong in a most positive and advantageous way. I refer to the initiatives that we have taken in the area of breast cancer research. The women of Geelong will certainly benefit by that initiative. Some $209 million over four years will be provided for a national breast cancer program. Last year I had the pleasure of opening a breast screening facility in Geelong with the Prime Minister's wife. It was well attended by people from the health field and by women in Geelong who have an interest in this issue.

The budget also provides some $62.7 million over four years to assist the homeless. Geelong is no different from other large provincial cities around Australia. It has a problem with homelessness, especially among some youth. Those measures will enhance accommodation assistance and will improve community support services to the homeless.

I am very pleased to say that in this budget there are special initiatives for veterans. My electorate consists of a large population of World War II veterans and Vietnam veterans. I have had quite close contact with the Vietnam veterans during my first year as a member of this parliament. I am hopeful that we can tap into the $20 million plus that has been provided in this budget to assist with rehabilitation, early intervention and provide for those with psychiatric disabilities among the Vietnam population.

The government has already provided funds to the national mental health strategy for mental illness. The budget allocates an extra $169 million over four years to accelerate the process of mental health reform. We have an excellent mental health facility in Geelong called Dax House. I am sure that with these budget initiatives we will be able to access extra funds and expand those services to people in the Geelong region.

Another important initiative in the budget is the child immunisation program which will provide vaccines for preventable diseases. An extra $9 1/2 million has been provided to promote childhood immunisation. I am sure children in Geelong will benefit greatly from this initiative. One interesting feature of the budget is the $48 million which will be provided over four years for the national Asian languages and studies program. Many Geelong schools are already heavily involved in such programs, but my task and the task of the educational community in Geelong will be to access those particular funds over the next four years and expand those initiatives in Geelong. More importantly, the initiatives in the white paper and in the budget will assist small and medium business and will really get the small business sector in Geelong humming.

As an overall situation, yesterday in question time the Treasurer described the sorts of measures taken by the government. He referred to the improved availability of finance—some $140 million—that had been provided by the Reserve Bank to the small and medium business sector. He referred to the expansion of the EFIC working capital facility, the introduction of the business angels concept and the assistance that will be provided to small and medium firms to access equity finance. He talked about tax initiatives, pooled development funds, initiatives taken by the government to improve awareness by entrepreneurs of Commonwealth Development Bank facilities and to improve their access to those funds. He mentioned the $100 million which will be provided over four years to NIES, the $70 million which will enhance trade networks and the increased access to government purchasing.

I met last week with representatives of the Geelong economic development board and held productive discussions with them. We discussed concrete initiatives that the community might pursue under the framework of the white paper and the budget. There are some very interesting initiatives that I think we can take on the ground in Geelong to give assistance to the small and medium business sector and, hopefully, through that generate some job creation. I think there is great scope for the establishment of a one-stop shop in Geelong where businesses can access government programs both at the state and federal level with greater ease. That particular suggestion was taken up with a degree of enthusiasm by members of the board. We will have discussions within the next month to firm up possibilities in that area.

Last year I negotiated with the industrial supplies office for the location of an officer in Geelong. Once again, this particular suggestion was taken up with some enthusiasm by the board, and we are hopeful of making progress on that within the next four to six weeks. We discussed ways of improving the access of Geelong firms to government purchasing. We talked about the move to establish a regional pooled development fund to expand the capital base and open up access to venture capital for new innovative firms in the Geelong region.

We talked about developing a better export culture in the Geelong region and strengthening the networks between firms that are already in the export field and firms that might like to enter that arena. I suggested that we ought to undertake more intensive discussions with regional banking personnel and members of the business community to iron out some of the concerns and difficulties that the business community has in that area.

There are opportunities for establishing a local business angels network, which will provide equity capital and business expertise. There are also opportunities for the further development of the services sector and its movement into the export arena and into Asia. In a general sense, there is a great opportunity for those who are unemployed to access the expanded labour market programs. So, all in all, I think the white paper is a great package that can be accessed by regions such as Geelong. We will work very hard in cooperation with local and state agencies in the area to make sure that Geelong firms and unemployed people in Geelong certainly get access to the funds that have been so generously provided by the federal government.

It is very important at this point to reflect a little on the economic scenario if the coalition had won the last election and Fightback had been implemented. We have heard a lot from the coalition on this budget, but let us play `what ifs'. Let us have a look at what would have happened if the Australian economy were driven by the coalition and if it had produced the last two budgets. One thing is certain: we would have had a massive increase in industrial conflict in this country; we would have seen a consequent loss of national production, which would have harmed investor perceptions; our reputation as a reliable exporter would have been damaged; and we would have seen lower levels of consumer confidence. What about fiscal policy two budgets later? We would have had a massive slashing of the community sector and we would have seen increased unemployment from those actions and reduced consumer confidence would have flowed from these public sector spending cuts. A lowering of demand would have accompanied that as well.

We have had a lot of talk in the last couple of days about interest rates. There is no doubt that the opposition has certainly attempted to talk up interest rates. For the last week it has done nothing else but attempt to exert through this parliament upward pressure on interest rates. Let us look at what would have happened to business investment and the level of interest rates if Fightback had been implemented. A massive increase in inflation and inflationary expectations would have been factored in by the financial markets of this country, which would be flowing in the long-term interest rates by the implementation of Fightback. Accompanying that would have been a dampening of business investment, certainly in key sectors such as motor vehicles.

Does anybody really believe that multinationals from overseas would have invested in Australia with a zero tariff policy that would have been pursued by the coalition under Fightback? Economic growth would have been stifled by uncertainty, and economic dislocation and uncertainty would have been the lot of the Australian people under the coalition.

In the key economic portfolios, nothing has changed. The leadership might have changed, but nothing else has. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is still there—one of the loyal advocates of Fightback until the Fightback funnel slipped below the sea line. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) still meanders around Fightback's graveyard as one of the coalition's undead. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking the budget papers at face value, many may conclude that the government has produced a harmless, do next to nothing budget with some gains but certainly no pain. Time has permitted the budget papers to be inspected more closely, and it is now patently clear that this `do nothing' aura surrounding the budget is masking a far more sinister reality—a reality in which the gains are illusory and only the pain remains.

PARA.TAB: The budget papers are full of sleights of hand. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the area of health. I am sorry that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), has left because he obviously took the word of the Treasurer (Mr Willis). He has not researched the detail himself. Being unashamedly political, the government has made grand announcements, claiming significant new money for Aboriginal health, breast cancer initiatives and mental health. But there are some cruel tricks; things are just not as they seem.

I do not doubt the sincerity of the new Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). But one has to ask: why can she not deliver the health funding increases planned by her male predecessor? Does she have the political clout of Graham Richardson, or does she suffer from being female? Does the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) perhaps treat women members of parliament in the same way that he treats women journalists? I know that Laurie Oakes, writing in this week's Bulletin, quotes the Prime Minister as calling one woman journalist `the Tory bitch' and another `that fat-arsed bitch'.

The Prime Minister is also guilty of promoting the theory that married women cannot have views of their own and merely express those of their husband. This is an insult to all women, and they would be justified in feeling outraged.

Let us look at the budget and Aboriginal health. Prior to the May budget, the Aboriginal community had been led to believe by the former health minister that $800 million would be made available for Aboriginal health. In the Senate on 24 March, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am utterly confident, on the word of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, that that plan will be put in place.

Contrary to this pledge, the eventual budget commitment was only $500 million. What is most cruel is that even this commitment is a hoax. To make my point, I will quote directly from an Access Economics report commissioned by the Australian Medical Association:
The current fad in government public relations is to re-announce old programs as if they were new ones, and to claim substantial new money spending when the real increase is rather modest.

This is nowhere more evident than in the area of Aboriginal health. The Government has announced a "new" phase of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy involving $499.4 million over 5 years, claiming that nearly all is new. Our analysis suggests that the increase in funding, compared with the level of spending during 1993-94, is only about $85 million over the life of the program or an average of $17 million a year.

Aboriginal Australians did not deserve to be tricked in this cruel way. Yet they are not the only group to be deceived. The women of Australia who face a 1 in 11 chance of contracting breast cancer have been treated with similar contempt. It seems that the government has committed $236.6 million over five years for breast cancer screening, yet this figure also proves to be an illusion. I return again to the Access Economics document which states:

Assuming instead that 1993/94 levels of funding were to be maintained in real levels, indicative spending in the five years would be some $176 million. Therefore the effective increase in funding for the program is some $60 million or $12 million per annum.
The government has saved its biggest tricks for medical research and, in particular, point scoring for breast cancer research.

PARA.TAB: Along with many others, I have been part of a concerted community campaign to have the funding for breast cancer research increased. On budget night, I thought we would have a real win. The Treasurer claimed that an extra $93 million was available over four years for the National Health and Medical Research Council and that `this was expected to result' in increased funding for breast cancer research projects. This was just playing politics. Again, the women of Australia and the medical researchers who could so well make this a clever country have been let down. I again quote from the Access Economics analysis:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also announced $92.8 million for Health and Medical Research, variously described as a "further" or "additional" amount. The budget facts sheets issued by the Department of Human Services and Health disclose that this "new money" has been achieved by re-announcing funding for on-going programs. Thus the $92.8 million includes funds to ". . . restore funding to the NHMRC base which was due to lapse at the end of 1994 and for additional research through the NHMRC". As in the case of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy, the suggestion that the funds were due to lapse at the end of 1994 is technically correct (in terms of forward budget commitments) but also totally meaningless. For the years commencing 1994-95, if spending on health and medical research were sustained as a proportion of total health spending at the 1993-94 rate, then the total would be some $716.5 million. The Government has committed $667.4 million. Therefore, the effective change in spending on health and medical research in the four years is a reduction of almost $50 million or $12 million per annum. On the face of it, the Government does not presently have a strong commitment to health and medical research. The steps taken to weaken NHMRC's say in the allocation of research funds has attracted wide criticism.

The government, in attempting to grab votes, announced in the budget the establishment of a national breast cancer centre at a cost of $16.4 million over four years. Again, the illusion was created that the government was doing something about the underfunded state of breast cancer research. Again, the reality falls far short of this illusion.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Human Services and Health has given evidence to the House of Representatives community affairs subcommittee that is inquiring into the management and treatment of breast cancer, of which I am a member. From this evidence, it is apparent that the centre will have no patients, undertake no research and will not be attached to a hospital. This expenditure can only be described as putting the cart before the horse and is a grossly irresponsible move when only $1.4 million is spent annually on breast cancer research. Time and again, public evidence has been given that research needs to be seen as an integral part of health care. Good research measures outcomes.

As a nation, we spend $33 billion each year trying to cure people once they become ill. We do that very well. In particular, we manage acute ill health well. We do not do so with chronic ill health. There are strong and convincing arguments to support the theory that wise investment in medical research could well save a lot of money in health care.

Professor John Forbes, the director and coordinator of the Australian-New Zealand Breast Cancer Trials Group, gave evidence to the public inquiry only last Monday night. On that occasion, he made the point that, if the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) can back down, the Minister for Human Services and Health should be able to do the same. If the minister cannot await the committee findings—which to me only makes good sense and would be credible—she should change the terms of reference of the national breast cancer centre and ensure that research becomes one of the functions of the centre.

There is the illusion of a significant increase in funding for mental health. The government announced a total mental health package of $168.7 million, but Access Economics found otherwise. I again quote its report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the effective increase in funding for the three mental health programs is some $31 million or $8 million per annum. To mask this rather modest contribution, the Government has issued a veritable torrent of information on other spending programs which may assist, in one way or another, people with mental illness.

Yet the conjuring tricks do not end with the health portfolio.Nothing is ever what it seems throughout the budget papers. If one listens only to the rhetoric of the Prime Minister and the magician's apprentice, the Treasurer, one would think the government had somehow created the ultimate in magic pudding budgets. We are asked to believe that over the coming financial year the government will increase spending by $6.1 billion without wavering from its mission to reduce the deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 and without increasing taxes.

PARA.TAB: So where will the government get the money to not only pay for the increased outlays but also to reduce the deficit? Out of thin air? It will be getting it out of the people in my electorate and others around the country. For a start, it will hit the students who study at the two universities in my electorate.

In its desperation to milk more out of its revenue sources, the Labor government has yet again turned to those with HECS debts. However, as announced in the May budget, come January 1995, any lingering commitment that Labor may have had to accessible university education will be ditched. The Labor government needs HECS revenue now rather than later. So, come January 1995, HECS debtors will be assessed according to their weekly earnings and not, as previously, according to their annual earnings.

Under the present method of assessment, former students who earn $26,403 over the space of a financial year are required to repay their HECS debt at a rate of three per cent of their wage. However, come January 1995, any HECS debtors who earn $509 gross in the space of a week will be required to hand over three per cent of this weekly wage as a repayment of their HECS debt.

For those who earn $509 a week for each of the 52 weeks of the year, this is not unreasonable. However, what about the graduates who can only find casual or temporary employment after completing their degrees? Thanks to this recession, this is the case for far too many students. They may earn $509 one week but nothing the next week, yet these people, regardless of the fact that they may have a low annual income, will have HECS repayments deducted from their wages every time they dare to earn $509 a week.

For these people, the HECS debt they incur to get an education will be particularly onerous. Maybe in the future those who know that they will always be engaged in casual and temporary types of employment—I am thinking particularly of women—may calculate that it is not in their best interests to pursue a university education. In this way, Labor will secure yet another nail in the coffin of accessible university education.

The Prime Minister and his helpers have not stopped at the students in my electorate; then there are the small business people. Casting its eye around for a quick buck, Labor in its wisdom has decided that $1 billion can be raised by improving compliance. In other words, there will be a massive redirection of resources within the Australian Taxation Office towards auditing tax returns. Apparently the 130.7 per cent increase in fringe benefits tax in 1994-95, which amounts to $1,830 million, just was not considered enough.

At the same time as business is being milked for more funds through the taxation system, it is commanded to increase its spending on business investment by 14.5 per cent—a rather hollow command when absolutely no effort has been made to create a climate conducive to business investment. Even if businesses find the confidence to invest, in spite of the tax and industrial relations regimes they are pitted against, they will still have to find the actual funds to invest. These funds will be increasingly scarce in a borrowing climate in which the government's borrowing will effectively crowd out private sector borrowing. The Australian Financial Review quite eloquently captured the irresponsibility of pump-priming a growing economy when it observed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government still has its foot on the fiscal accelerator as the economy approaches a fairly brisk cruising speed.

This is what happens when we let madmen drive! Having dealt with the business sector, the government has not forgotten the wage earners in my electorate. In 1994-95, the money flowing into the Commonwealth coffers through personal income tax will increase by 8.1 per cent. Sure, the government has not increased rates of personal tax. It does not have to. It simply waits for people to be pushed into higher tax brackets as their wages are increased in line with inflation. This is the way in which the government has managed to up its personal income tax take by 8.1 per cent.

PARA.TAB: If this government were true to its word, it would have put in place the second round of personal tax cuts that it promised before the last election. By not handing over the $5.2 billion in tax cuts—that is l-a-w law tax cuts—that it promised the Australian people, the government is effectively pocketing the benefits of the recovery, benefits which rightfully belong to those who bore the brunt of the recession: the Australian people.

Why stop at allowing the direct tax burden on the average wage earner to increase when you can also hit them indirectly? No tax increase is in the 1994-95 financial year? That is rubbish. In July 1994 sales tax on wine is to increase from 22 to 24 per cent. On 1 August 1994 the tax on unleaded fuel will rise by 1c a litre. On 1 August 1994 the tax on leaded fuel will rise by 2c a litre. On 1 August 1994 the excise on tobacco will rise by five per cent. On 1 February 1995 there will be a further five per cent increase in tobacco excise. Finally, the government will celebrate the close of the 1994-95 financial year with a one per cent across the board sales tax increase. In all, the government will raise an additional $2 billion in the 1994-95 financial year from indirect tax increases legislated for in last year's budget.

Lesson No. 1 in the conjurers' manual is how to increase taxes in a financial year without mentioning these increases in the budget for that financial year. Just legislate these increases in the previous year's budget. Courtesy of retired magician's assistant, John Dawkins, the average people in my electorate will be slugged again and again this coming financial year with increases in indirect taxes. Indirect taxes should not be confused with insignificant taxes.

Each and every sales tax increase the government is putting in place will make it just that bit more difficult for my constituents. Take the tax increase on fuel as an example. More than 50 per cent of the households in my electorate have incomes below $30,000 a year. While this may not be obvious to the Prime Minister, ensconced in the cotton wool lifestyle of the nouveau riche, people from such households rarely have the ability to purchase new cars. They are compelled to drive older cars. From 1 August they will be punished for this impertinence with a 2c per litre increase on the leaded petrol they are obliged to use. The impact of this tax on the battlers in my electorate will be profound. For instance, every time average 1983 Falcon drivers fill up after 1 August, they will pay $1.30 extra for a tank of petrol. When people are struggling to make ends meet, this tax is just one more burden which they do not need.

No matter how hard the chief conjurer and his helpers try, they cannot obscure the fact that the extra $6.1 billion they will be spending in this coming financial year has to come from somewhere. It will not be produced out of thin air. It will be acquired by more conventional means—the taxation system. No amount of fancy gesturing can obscure the fact that in 1994-95 overall tax revenue to the Commonwealth will increase by 9.7 per cent. It should be remembered that this is the largest increase for more than a decade.

So the May budget was not so magical after all. The Prime Minister and his helpers have simply paid for the extra $6.1 billion worth of spending with an $8 billion increase in revenue. Nothing—at least under a Labor government—is ever what it seems. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the government's response to the country's ongoing unemployment tragedy. In parts of my electorate the unemployment rate has been over 16 per cent since the beginning of this year. The government's response to this tragedy has been to throw $6.5 billion at the problem and hope desperately that this gesture will disguise the fact that it has no answers to unemployment. We can train the unemployed until the cows come home. This will not create one real job, which is what they so desperately need. Jobs can only come from a vital and confident business sector. Herein lies the grand illusion of this budget. The 1994 budget is a great shaking edifice built on a fantasy—the Treasurer's fantasy that business investment will rise by 14.5 per cent over the coming financial year. Will the Treasurer's fantasy materialise? Recent figures suggest it will not. Only days after the May budget, statistics were released which showed that private capital expenditure had slumped by five per cent during the March quarter.

And the consequences if the Treasurer's fantasy does not materialise? There will not be four per cent plus economic growth. In turn, the growth dividend this government has so irresponsibly relied on to fund its spending habit will not be forthcoming. The end result will be a further increase in the foreign debt that is hanging over this country's future. This is the legacy that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer will leave for Australians of tomorrow. With the May budget, the Labor government has failed the Australian people yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak tonight in support of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1994-95.
