As the Treasurer (Mr Willis) said in his budget speech on 10 May, this is a budget that will maximise economic growth, reduce unemployment, promote social justice and reduce the budget deficit, without increasing taxes—despite the comments of the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth). I feel a bit sorry for the honourable member for Adelaide because, unlike a lot of her wealthy constituents and most of her male colleagues, the honourable member cannot join the Adelaide Club. I suppose she is a bit disappointed about that. I would not be.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Adelaide continues this nonsense from the opposition benches that somehow this government is a high taxing government and that the budget is a high taxing budget. Of course, that is absolute nonsense, as I will illustrate. It is quite an achievement in anyone's language to deliver a budget that will maximise economic growth, reduce unemployment, promote social justice and reduce the budget deficit to $11.7 billion without increasing taxes. It is an achievement that only a Labor government is capable of.

Let me deal with the point that there are no increases in taxes in this budget. The opposition is trying to dispute this by claiming that because total government revenue is expected to rise there must be increased taxes. This cynical falsehood was promoted by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) when he was the Leader of the Opposition and carried on by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) when he was shadow Treasurer, and it is still being carried on by the honourable member for Mayo now in his capacity as the Leader of the Opposition.

I notice that the failed Liberal candidate for the seat of Werriwa has twice been in the local papers making the same assertion and false claim. We know of his credibility after his abortive attempt to win the Werriwa by-election. This is the same bloke that believes that the local chamber of commerce in Campbelltown is a Labor Party front. I will say more about that some other time.

There are no tax increases in this budget. In fact, Australians are now benefiting from the income tax cuts that were introduced last November. Anyone with any intelligence or honesty would understand that the reason that the budget papers are forecasting an increase in revenue is due to the benefits of the economic recovery and increased employment. Because there will be more people in jobs earning enough to be able to pay tax and because profits will increase, thereby attracting more tax revenue, the total revenue receivable will naturally increase. It is not that tax levels have increased but simply that there will be more people and more businesses actually paying tax.

The opposition thinks this is bad. Obviously, it thinks that the economic recovery, increased business profits and increased job opportunities are bad news for Australia. It thinks it is bad news that government income will increase, and it tries to distort the truth with these false and cynical assertions that increased revenue means increased taxes. The only bad news in the budget is the bad news for the Liberal Party. This budget, together with the white paper and the community's reaction to both documents, is very bad news for the Liberal and National parties. It adds a further nail in the coffin of its electoral prospects. It might be bad news for the opposition, but that means it is good news for Australia.

Despite the rhetoric and lies of the opposition, Australia remains the lowest taxed country in the OECD. This is what really hurts the opposition and its political supporters. As much as these conservatives like to perpetuate the myth that, under Labor, Australia is a high taxing country in order to set up the usual straw people and so that its wealthy supporters have something to whinge about, the facts do not support its arguments at all. We are the lowest taxed country in the OECD.

There are some of us on this side of the House who do not necessarily think that being the lowest taxed country in the OECD is necessarily something to boast about. A fair and equitable taxation system is necessary to provide the revenue to enable governments to provide the services and programs that people expect, to provide the economic and social infrastructure and the social justice programs that people are entitled to expect and to provide access and equity for all Australians regardless of their socioeconomic backgrounds. It is appropriate that services and programs for disadvantaged members of our society be funded via taxation revenue from the better off. I believe a strong case could be made for saying that there are many people out there who could and should be paying more tax.

However, it is clear that, because of the outstanding economic management of this government, we are able to provide a comprehensive range of social justice programs and community services despite being the lowest taxed country in the OECD. There is no better evidence than the enormous range of measures contained in the white paper on employment, industry and regional development and in this budget. As I said before, only a Labor government could ever hope to deliver such a package to the Australian people.

Let me examine some of the measures contained in the budget. The measures contained in the white paper will cost $6 1/2 billion over four years. This is a huge commitment by the government to assist long-term unemployed people and to create jobs. I have said publicly many times that the government created high expectations in the community for many months prior to the white paper. The white paper was to be the government's response to unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment, which was rightly identified as the biggest political issue facing Australia as well as being a human tragedy.

Following nearly 12 months of wide consultation and debate around the country on unemployment, the white paper provides a comprehensive response that meets most of the reasonable expectations raised. Although I am sure we could all sit down and find an area or program which could have been given more money, the fact is that overall this is a magnificent package which will have a significant impact throughout Australia. The overwhelmingly positive response from the community to the white paper speaks for itself.

Of particular note in the white paper are the initiatives on regional development. Some $151 million over four years has been allocated towards the national regional development strategy. This includes $70 million for a regional infrastructure fund and $81 million for the regional best practice program.

This government will work with states, local government, business, unions and communities to maximise opportunities for economic growth and job creation at the regional level. This government will facilitate the establishment of regional economic development forums involving representatives of those groups that I have just mentioned. In some cases the existing regional organisations will meet the government's criteria.

I am pleased to say that this process has already commenced in my electorate. Last week I was pleased to welcome the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) to the Macarthur region. The Deputy Prime Minister attended a meeting of the Macarthur regional task force, which is a subcommittee of the Macarthur Regional Organisation of Councils, MACROC. Following the meeting, he was a special guest at a cocktail party jointly hosted by the chair of MACROC, Councillor Sam Mir, and me.

At these two functions the minister and the government's white paper initiatives on regional development were well received by the business and local government representatives present. Macarthur is one of the fastest growing regions in Australia with one of the youngest populations. There is universal recognition in the area of the importance of well managed and well resourced regional development and regional planning.

The white paper also provides for the establishment of area consultative committees by the Department of Employment, Education and Training to generate community support for the job compact and other labour market programs and to facilitate the linking of these programs with regional development initiatives. These area consultative committees will also involve local businesses, unions, training providers and government representatives.

I look forward to working with my colleagues the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) and the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) in the next few weeks in order to facilitate the effective establishment of these important regional bodies in south-west Sydney. The most significant announcement in the white paper for my electorate—indeed, for south-west Sydney and the greater western Sydney region—was the decision to fast-track the construction of a 2,900-metre runway at Badgerys Creek airport.

Apart from the obvious benefits for the national transport system of this decision, the development of Badgerys Creek airport, particularly with the construction of the associated road and rail links, will be an enormous boost to the development of western and south-western Sydney. Badgerys Creek, which is to be known as the Sydney West International Airport, will attract industries and many thousands of jobs to the area. The decision represents a major victory for all of the federal Labor MPs and local councils both in the inner city area near Kingsford Smith airport and in the western and south-western areas of Sydney who have campaigned long and hard for this decision.

I would like to mention some other significant budget measures. I was particularly pleased to see an additional $169 million over four years allocated for mental health programs. This includes $133 million in additional funds which will more than double the federal government's financial commitment to the national mental health strategy. Much of this money will be provided to state governments and will be used to address the areas of concern identified by the Burdekin report on human rights and mental illness which was released in 1993. As the convener of the Labor caucus working group on mental health, I look forward to working with the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), caucus members and the community in order to make sure that this additional funding delivers positive outcomes for people with mental illness or psychiatric disability.

There are other important initiatives in the human services and health area. These include an additional $500 million over five years for Aboriginal health programs and $209 million over four years for a national breast cancer program. In the housing portfolio, the budget also provides $63 million over four years for a range of initiatives to assist homeless people. These are just a few of the typical social justice policies of this government which have been delivered in this budget.

It has been very interesting over the last two or three days to listen to the various contributions to this debate and to reflect on some of the comments, particularly those from the opposition benches. Despite the media fanfare surrounding the leadership change in the Liberal Party, it is clear from this debate that nothing much has changed. The opposition is still the same tired old bunch of born to rule Tories with no policies and nothing to contribute but empty rhetoric attacking the Labor government.

Even today, in the wake of the incredibly positive economic news of five per cent growth and continuing low inflation, the opposition continues with this nonsense of preaching doom and gloom, not to mention the continued obsession with union bashing, as evidenced by the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) in this House today.

I took particular notice of some of the comments made by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) in her first speech. Unlike most of her colleagues, it could be said from the speech of the honourable member for Mackellar that at least she stands for something; at least she expresses a philosophy. She says that she believes in individualism and particularly asserts that individualism is preferable to collectivism. So at least she believes in something, even if the implication of her particular brand of individualism can be revealed as totally unfair, unjust and impractical.

The honourable member for Mackellar believes that collectivism is `where government is for groups and the individual can be sacrificed for the group'. I would have thought that such a description could easily apply to many quite normal and appropriate areas of society. As an ex-sportsman, it sounds to me like what it means to be a member of a team. The honourable member's comments are interesting when you consider the great lengths to which she has gone recently to describe herself as a team player on the opposition frontbench.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor old John Hewson got sacrificed for the greater good, didn't he?

—That is right. I think the comments speak for themselves. There are serious flaws in the concept of individualism expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar. The Liberal Party has always claimed to be a party which stands for the rights of the individual, particularly above the power of the state.

PARA.TAB: There are two points to make here. Firstly, this sort of philosophy is quite attractive to the wealthier and more advantaged individuals in our society; for example, the sorts of individuals who are wealthy and privileged enough to be members of the Melbourne Club or the Adelaide Club or to live in one of the million dollar mansions on Sydney Harbour or in the electorate of the honourable member for Mackellar. This description alone excludes most Australians. In the case of the Melbourne Club and the Adelaide Club, all women are excluded. The honourable member for Mackellar is not eligible to join the Adelaide Club. The honourable member for Adelaide is not even eligible to join the Adelaide Club.

The effects of these policies of so-called individualism on the less well off in our society would be disastrous. But, in any case, this so-called policy of individualism is hardly reflected in the policies, if you can call them policies, of the current opposition. We hear much more noise from the Liberal Party about states rights than we ever do about individual rights, as evidenced by the coalition's attitude towards the Tasmanian homosexual laws issue, where apparently the rights of the state to make repressive and draconian laws are much more important than the rights of many individual Tasmanians. You have only to look at the coalition's attitude towards the Native Title Act, where the states rights were much more important than the rights of individual Aboriginal people who had been dispossessed and disadvantaged for 206 years. There is a lot of contradiction and hypocrisy on the opposition side with respect to individual rights.

I would again like to return to the comments made today by the honourable member for Bennelong with respect to unionism. He asked a question which implied that union members were given preference in certain industrial agreements. He thought that was dreadful. It should be pointed out to the opposition, particularly the honourable member for Bennelong and his mate the honourable member for La Trobe, that there is nothing very unfair about union members being given preference in certain circumstances. After all, to be a member of a union you have to pay union dues. It is like being a member of a club. If you want to have the benefits of union membership, you have to pay your dues. If you do not pay your union dues, why should you attract the benefits of union membership?

It is just like being a member of the Adelaide Club, or any club for that matter. If you are a member of a club, you reasonably expect that the advantages and the privileges that come with being a member of that club are afforded only to members. So why is being a member of a union any different? If you are a member of a union, you are entitled to the benefits that the collectivism of being a member of a union brings to you. If you are not a member of a union, why should you get the benefits which have been hard won by the union movement over the years?

Once again, a double standard on the part of the opposition has been revealed. Those opposite set up straw people in the form of unions and union members. They attack unionists and workers. They think there is something wrong with union members having rights. They suggest that non-union members should have the same rights, even though they do not pay to be members of unions. But it is a bit different when it comes to the membership of clubs which people also have to pay for. If you are a member of a club, you are entitled to expect that the benefits of that membership fee that you pay will apply only to club members. But it is different when you talk about unions, according to the opposition.

We should not be surprised about this. The opposition, as evidenced by its recent changes to the frontbench, is very much a conservative party which is moving further away from the mainstream of Australian politics and political thought. Its window-dressing and shallow attempts to move to the middle ground will fail. As has been said many times recently, including by their own former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, those opposite are further away than ever from winning an election. If they continue with these negative and elitist policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —I reckon they should bring Malcolm back; he seems to be leading them.

—Those opposite could do a lot worse than bringing Malcolm back. I would not have said that in 1975, but these days Malcolm looks like a bit of a socialist compared with that lot opposite at the moment. He has some very decent views on issues such as South Africa. The coalition really has not changed much. Nobody is fooled by the movement on the opposition frontbench. There are different faces in different positions, but the philosophy of those opposite, if you can call it a philosophy, has not changed.

PARA.TAB: It is only a Labor government that can lead Australia into the 21st century. This budget and in particular the white paper provide an excellent basis to lead us through the rest of the 1990s and into the 21st century. As I said, it is only a Labor government that can provide that. Certainly, the opposition is further away than ever from providing realistic mainstream alternative policies for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), it is no wonder the country is in the state it is. His contribution to this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) clearly demonstrates just how out of touch he is. I guess through blind loyalty he has tried to tell us that what is contained in the budget and the white paper is meant to be good for Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is just over three weeks since we were gathered in this place to hear the Treasurer (Mr Willis) present the government's revenue and spending strategy for 1994-95 and the ensuing years. It is not an occasion which I look forward to each year. In fact, each budget which this Labor government has presented has been unique in its own special way. By the end of each budget night, the government has produced the same result. Without exception, every budget has ignored the ever-worsening plight of middle Australia and has foisted new taxes and charges, just like this budget did three weeks ago, on businesses, families and, in particular, my area of responsibility of regional and rural Australia.

The best that can be said for this year's budget is that it is not as bad as last year's—that is, in the short term at least. From the long-term perspective, this budget has the potential to be even more damaging. If, as many of us suspect, the investment predictions which underpin the spending initiatives contained in the budget do not eventuate, the people of Australia will have to foot a very large bill.

We do not doubt the government's prediction of private sector investment growth simply for the sake of being pessimistic. I, for one, would love the government to prove me wrong and come up with the 14.5 per cent growth in investment which this budget relies on. However, the reality of the matter is that there are few, if any, indications to suggest that this goal can be reached.

For a start, it would be quite a dramatic turnaround for a 14.5 per cent surge in investment to follow a year in which investment has increased by only one per cent. It becomes even more ridiculous when one considers that that modest increase was assisted by the investment allowance, which is due to end in 30 days time. Independent forecasters Access Economics also cast doubt on the government's predictions of a growth surge by calculating their own estimate, which was a much more modest increase of 7.75 per cent—almost half of what the government predicted. In fact, the government's own adviser, Treasury, clearly doubts the accuracy of the prediction. It warns against high expectation in the investment led recovery at least three times throughout the budget papers, with comments such as:

SPEECH.PARA: An upturn in business investment is expected to occur during 1993-94. Although growth in plant and equipment and in non-residential construction is expected to fall back towards more sustainable levels during the year, the pick up will still be moderate by past standards.

We can refer to last year's standard of one per cent growth. Perhaps that is what Treasury was referring to. This note of caution is reinforced by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which said in its budget response:

This is a forecast built on hope rather than any kind of solid evidence. And if private investment does not reach the level forecast, most of the other figures in the Budget, including the future size of the deficit are open to serious question.

The federal government would do well to heed the advice of the ACCI which does, after all, represent the employers and business people of Australia who will actually be making the decision to invest or not to invest over the coming years. They are the people who will take the risks and put their money and lifetime savings on the line.

PARA.TAB: Despite advice and opinion to the contrary, the government expects us to believe that it knows businesses better than anyone else and that its flimsy predictions should be believed. Why should we believe the government? It has been wrong so many times that it does not deserve our trust. It certainly has not earned it. On the eve of the worst recession this country has seen in 60 years, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), at that time the Treasurer, was telling us `economic policy has worked and is working'. If the recessionary years that followed were an example of the result of a working economics policy, I shudder to think what would have happened had Mr Keating's policies not worked.

I turn to what the budget did or, should I say, did not offer the people in my electorate of Maranoa and, indeed, many rural and regional Australians. Of most concern to my constituency is the way this government approaches the issue of road funding. It may have escaped the notice of the Keating cabinet, ensconced, as it generally is, in capital city offices and meeting rooms, that Australia is a very large country. This means it is often a challenge to get from one part of it to another. Fortunately, movement around and across the continent is greatly enhanced by the provision of roads. However, it is not good enough to simply build roads. They have to be maintained, extended if necessary and, at the end of their natural life, replaced. Given this government's track record of consistently reducing road funding, it appears to be under the impression that roads are maintenance free, self-renewing and expandable. Unfortunately, that is not the case.

The reality of the matter is that much more of our regional road network is nearing the end of its natural life. The state of disrepair has reached the point at which some sections of the network are beginning to hurt businesses in terms of freight time and costs. Worse still, the state of many of our neglected roads has become so hazardous that, inevitably, lives will be lost. Anybody who spends any amount of time travelling on regional roads—obviously, the Prime Minister and his cabinet chums do not—would be absolutely certain of their poor and potentially dangerous condition. Apparently, that is not a concern of this Labor government.

In the regional and rural parts of Australia that I travel in, the truckies in particular often say that it is not the damage their trucks do to the roads that concerns them, it is the damage that the roads do to their trucks. This financial year the government will spend $820 million on roads. That represents a savage cut of $200 million over last year's allocation and around $800 million less than we saw in 1992-93. The government has taken the butcher's knife to the funding of our roads. The tragic irony of this situation is that it should not happen. There is absolutely no excuse, no reason, no justification, for putting people's lives at risk as this government has done.

Roads are not free. They are not things that the government generously provides out of its own pocket. Road users pay for roads every time they put petrol or diesel in their motor vehicles or trucks. In fact, this financial year road users will pay the government $9.7 billion in fuel tax. Imagine how safe, how efficient and how extensive our road network would be if a sizeable proportion of that money were spent where it should be—on roads. As little as 8.5 per cent of fuel tax collections will be spent on roads. That proportion will continue to decline, reaching a mere 7.5 per cent in 1997-98. That is the real tragedy. The money is there. The transport industries are paying for roads, but those roads are not being delivered by this government.

This government will continue to let our roads deteriorate and to let them claim nearly 2,000 lives annually. In the last financial year, 1,946 lives were lost on Australian roads. The government will not heed the advice of Coroner Kevin Waller who, when recalling the bus disasters of 1989, described the Commonwealth's lack of interest in creating a safe highway from Newcastle to Tweed Heads as a scandal, and went on to call the government's road funding strategy a `sham'.

This government is apparently impervious to advice of any kind, if its refusal to deal with the findings of the McKinsey report on business investment in regional Australia is anything to go by. For a number of reasons, the findings should not be ignored. Firstly, they came at a price—$1.25 million—to the taxpayers of this country. Secondly, the McKinsey report is not a purely academic study but rather a report based on discussions with actual business people—the people who drive regional economies. Thirdly, the report should not be ignored because it provides some very sound advice to the government.

The McKinsey report correctly identified the recession, employment on-costs, such as the training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee levy, payroll tax and labour market inflexibility as the main impediments to regional investment. It is clear that these findings have gone right over the government's head. The government's budget and its twin, Working Nation, offer little in the way of reduced costs besides the welcome suspension of the training guarantee levy. It is worth noting the comments of some regional business people, which are recorded in the McKinsey report:

SPEECH.PARA: Is Government working as hard as I am to increase productivity and reduce costs? I'm doing what I can, but I can't control what they do—
`they' being the government—
They've got to reduce costs too.

One of the most telling findings of the McKinsey report was that 29 per cent of surveyed regional businesses indicated that they would hire another person if on-costs were lower. I urge the government to take that particular finding very seriously, as it quite clearly identifies an area in which a small amount of reform could have a huge effect on the problem of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: In plotting its role in the future of regional Australia, the government also had benefit and guidance from the Industry Commission and the Bureau of Industry Economics. The Industry Commission released its final report on the impediments to regional industry adjustment in April this year. Its most significant recommendation was a call for greater flexibility in workplace bargaining in order to recognise the particular conditions faced by workplaces in different regions. Naturally, this was completely ignored by the government in favour of the restrictive provisions of the Industrial Relations Reform Act which, as the Industry Commission politely points out, is highly unlikely to deliver to regional workplaces. Not surprisingly, the ACTU and the Department of Industrial Relations were highly critical of the Industry Commission's recommendation in relation to workplace flexibility. However, the private sector, local and state governments were supportive.
One of the most supportive organisations, of course, apart from the National Farmers Federation and the Geelong City Council, was the government of Tasmania. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The comments made by the Commission in relation to the need for institutional impediments to greater flexibility in work practices and conditions to be removed are strongly supported.

Given the widespread support for the freeing-up of the industrial relations system, it is particularly disappointing that the government did not seize the opportunity presented by the release of Working Nation to announce a new era of workplace bargaining. There is now ample evidence to suggest that the work force of regional Australia would have been among the first to benefit, had it done so.

PARA.TAB: The Bureau of Industry Economics also released a report in April, entitled Regional development: pattern and policy implications. This report emphasised the importance of government getting the fundamentals right and then keeping out of the way. Such fundamentals include sound management of the public sector, the provision of infrastructure and amenities, the operation of markets for capital, labour and technology, the regulatory and competitive framework and the stability of policy settings.

I trust that this very prudent advice has not fallen on deaf government ears, although the decimation of the road funding budget, which I addressed earlier, would suggest it has. It is unfortunate that the great proliferation of advice and opinion which has surfaced from these reports and others, including the Kelty task force and state governments, has not been utilised to prepare a detailed and targeted strategy for development of regional and rural Australia. The cynics amongst us would probably suspect that the millions the federal government has spent sending consultants around the country were merely to create a facade of genuine government concern for the distinct problems of regional Australia.

No matter what the government's motivation, the fact remains that we are left with a humble $263 million commitment over four years to assist the development of regional Australia. Although I am thankful that the government has finally pieced together some commitment, I am particularly concerned by the lack of focus and vision of the government's strategy. It is not clear from chapter 7 of Working Nation, which contains the government's regional development strategy, exactly what it is attempting to achieve nor indeed how it will intend to monitor the success or otherwise of these new initiatives. There are vague allusions to the need for all Australians to participate in national recovery and growth but no clear aims or objectives.

Of equal concern is the complete lack of detail about the initiatives—and for this there is absolutely no excuse. With 14 months preparation and an array of reports and papers, there can be no reason for the lack of a comprehensive guide to the way the government's initiatives will work. The regional best practice program, for example, provides for assistance to regions to establish a representative region-wide development organisation. The paper adds:

SPEECH.PARA: In many cases, existing regional organisations will meet the criteria.
What criteria, one might ask? What form will the assistance take? Will it be financial assistance in the form of grants, will it be personnel or simply guidance and advice?

PARA.TAB: Also, part of the regional best practice program is a promise of assistance to regional organisations to focus on the strengths and opportunities of the region. Again, what exactly is meant by assistance? What does the government intend by this focussing concept? Is it for promotional purposes or resource allocation reasons? What of the regional demonstration projects? Where are the guidelines for these projects to ensure the funds which are available are distributed prudentially and not according to the political persuasion of the region's federal member with a great big whiteboard? Similarly, I would urge the government to ensure that the regional strategic infrastructure fund is managed with a clear focus on the needs of the region and not on the needs of the government.

At the end of the day, the government's regional development strategy will be judged by its growth or further decline of regional Australia. The McKinsey report contains some chilling findings to which the federal government must be held accountable. It found that 41 per cent of Australia's regions were in decline; most of these are small country towns which provide essential services to the agriculture resource industries which continue to underpin our export trade. The problem is that the declining population is bringing about a commensurate decline in services and facilities. If the government's strategy does not have a positive impact on these regions, there can be no doubt that the decline will continue and those few who defiantly remain in those regions to produce world class wool, beef and crops will become a permanent underclass. I am not convinced that the government's regional development strategy provides the assistance those 41 per cent of regional areas need, but I would love nothing more than for this government to prove me wrong.

Motion (by Mr Kerr) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House the final report of the commission of inquiry into the future of the Commonwealth lands at Shoalwater Bay, Queensland, which was submitted to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) today. Shoalwater Bay is a superb area of pristine wilderness, 60 kilometres north-east of Rockhampton. By good fortune, 520,000 hectares of wilderness has been largely protected through acquisition by the army in 1965. The Shoalwater Bay military training area, together with the Byfield National Park, is the largest area of undeveloped land on the east coast of Australia except for the Cape York Peninsula.

PARA.TAB: In 1980, the area was listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its size, its almost pristine condition and the great diversity of landforms and habitats. The federal government announced an inquiry in December 1992 in response to pressure from local conservationists against proposals to mine the 70 kilometres of coastline from Corio Bay to Island Head. The inquiry and a recent report by Scott Johnston and Keith Jaffray, published in Wilderness the Future by the Total Environment Centre, clearly identify the factors that make this area so worth protecting as a wilderness area.

The area contains giant parabolic dune systems, which are up to 200 metres high and stretch up to 12 kilometres inland. They are one of the most diverse and least disturbed examples of this landform in Australia. The Shoalwater-Byfield wilderness contains 51 per cent of Australia's bird species, 27 per cent of mammal species, 13 per cent of frog species, and 12 per cent of reptile species. It ranks higher in biodiversity than such places as Fraser Island and Cape Tribulation. Even limited studies show the area supports 355 native animal species. It also contains at least 19 rare and threatened flora and fauna species.

Shoalwater Bay borders on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Its marine estuarine systems are the last large, undisturbed and fully functioning systems south of Princess Charlotte Bay on Cape York. It contains 150 square kilometres of undisturbed mangroves. Shoalwater Bay is therefore pollution free, thus ensuring a healthy Barrier Reef and the maintenance of the local fishing industry worth $22 million per year.

The CSIRO has recently advised that this area is an `ecological laboratory, a living inventory for biodiversity and an ideal centre for the study of biodiversity'. It says that `much of the woodland vegetation is well represented and is becoming endangered elsewhere'. The area represents the largest remaining area of old growth eucalypt forest in Central and Southern Queensland outside of the Clarke and Carnarvon Range areas. A survey prepared by the commission of inquiry showed that the residents of the Rockhampton area were vitally concerned with the protection of their water supply and the protection of the environment.

The final report clearly recognises that mining would jeopardise the huge sand dunes which act as a natural filter and storage facility. The dunes help to provide clean, fresh water to Yeppoon and Byfield at a time when surrounding water supplies are plagued with blue-green algae. The report also recognised the claims to the area of the local Darambal Aboriginal people and identified significant archaeological sites. These sites meet the criteria for national estate significance and are located mainly in the eastern dune fields and the coastal zone.

The interim report indicated that sandmining Shoalwater may contribute $260 million to the Australian economy—a pitiful figure in comparison with the value of a unique ecosystem, the quality and reliability of Livingstone shire's water supply, the local fishing industry, ecotourism, aboriginal rights and future scientific research. I am informed that sandmining was rejected by the Bjelke-Petersen government. If it rejected sandmining, it must be worth keeping.

The final report makes a clear and overwhelming case that no mining of any type should be permitted. It also recommends that both tourism and defence uses should be clearly defined and restricted. These conclusions are undeniable and I am confident that they will be accepted by the minister and the government. While I certainly applaud the commissioners on the depth, clarity and recommendations of their report, they have been timid in respect to the use of the area for defence purposes.

There is no question that the army has been highly responsible in its management of the area. Nevertheless, for all the reasons set out in the report defence uses must be phased out. Only the declaration of a wilderness national park for the whole 520,000 hectares can achieve proper safeguards for the local water supplies, fishing industry, archaeological sites and the World Heritage values of this unique environment. The Shoalwater Bay area is unique and deserves to be ranked with the Tasmanian wilderness and the Great Barrier Reef.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Member for Gilmore: Alleged Threats to Councillors

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in regard to an article in the Kiama Independent under the heading `Knott threatens councillors'. I apologise to all concerned for allowing myself to get emotionally upset in relation to the safety of my two sons. I was upset at comments that I interpreted as a callous disregard for the safety of my sons and the other children in my street. None of the people who were present believed a physical threat was intended. I have spoken to David Hall and he indicated that he did not feel that Neville Fredericks was in danger. Councillor Neville Fredericks has stated to me that he did not feel he was in any danger. Councillor Ruth Devenney did not believe that anyone was in danger.

PARA.TAB: There was no mention of guns or shooting at any point. This was a figment of Kiama Independent's imagination. In the full context of the conversation no threat was made. It was true that Kiama Independent asked me to comment, but I believe that everyone in the Kiama municipality knows how Kiama Independent has treated me and my family over the years. I believed the questions were provocative. The whole thing has been sensationalised and distorted.

As soon as Kiama Independent contacted me last Friday I phoned Councillor Neville Fredericks, astounded that he felt physically threatened. Neville Fredericks told me that he had not taken the matter to the press. I apologised to Neville Fredericks for any embarrassment or inconvenience he may have experienced as a result of the publication of this encounter. He indicated that as far as he was concerned the matter was finished.

I apologise to my supporters for allowing myself to be so used by Kiama Independent. In my own defence, many know how I have fought for over seven years with the RTA and the Kiama Council over the Princess Highway and local access to the highway, which now involves my street. People also know that I have been constantly urging for a pedestrian overpass bridge from Gainsborough so that no-one is killed on the highway. The pedestrian refuge has been demolished in accidents on a number of occasions. I have received no support from the council on this matter.

While I have no excuse for getting so upset, the memory of a father's letter to me about the death of his three-year-old son at the intersection of North Kiama Drive and the highway still haunts me. I received that letter in council while we were waiting on the report. All the people involved know what that letter was about and at that time I vowed to do everything that I possibly could to stop the carnage on our roads, particularly this stretch of road.

The people of my community are sick and tired of having to give the lives of their families to get improvements to the roads. While it may be an afterthought—a headstone for those people who have died—the road improvements that we have asked and urged for are precious little to the families who have lost people. I admit that I probably went over the top in what I said. But, if anyone thinks that I am going to stop fighting for what I believe is the correct and proper thing for the people of Gainsborough in north Kiama, they are sadly mistaken.

Mr Speaker, I say to you here today that there will come a day when, unless action is taken, in a future speech on the adjournment I will have to report to this House further deaths along that highway. The RTA knows about the situation. When I went out and asked about an overpass bridge, the RTA laughed. I sent the RTA a letter 12 months ago. I still have no reply. On 8 March 1994, I circulated to the people of Gainsborough a request for their assistance to get something done and I have been inundated with replies.

I have done the wrong thing. I let my emotions carry me away. I apologise to all those involved, but I do not apologise for fighting for the rights, the life and the safety of my kids and the other kids in my area. I am sure that the parents of the kids in Gainsborough and the parents in Cathedral Rocks Avenue will understand completely why I became emotionally involved and why I was so upset. I apologise to anyone here who takes offence at what I said. But in light of the death of that three-year-old boy, I find it very difficult not to keep fighting in regard to this issue. I intend to keep putting it to the RTA to do something about that road so I will not have to come into here again and report names of people who have been killed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to the matters about which I was speaking earlier today. I quote from a Queensland special task force report to which we have had access. This report reveals:

SPEECH.PARA: a.The Queensland Police—in conjunction with the C.J.C., the N.C.A. and the F.B.I.—have been undertaking a covert operation on the Gold Coast under the code name "Wallah". This is a follow-on to a previous operation codenamed "Hacker 6" which terminated on 27/1/93.
b.The purpose of Operation Wallah has been to investigate the involvement of well-known Australian criminals in prostitution, money laundering, stand over tactics and SP bookmaking on the Gold Coast.

c.One of the outcomes of Operation Wallah—and as a continuation of information gleaned during Operation Hacker VI—two prostitution operators on the Gold Coast were discovered with links to two of the targets of Operation Wallah. —Approximately 3 1/2 weeks ago a column that I wrote was published in the Melbourne Herald-Sun. The column related to an organisation called the Australian Family Association. At the very conclusion of that column I referred to another organisation called the Australian Defence Association, which I described as being associated with the extreme Right in Australian politics. Mr Michael O'Connor—I think his correct title is executive director—then wrote a letter to the Herald-Sun stating that, contrary to my suggestion, the organisation had no connection with the extreme Right in Australian politics and was not a front for the National Civic Council, which clearly is an organisation of the extreme Right in Australian politics.

PARA.TAB: I rise today to point out that I did not make that accusation, namely that the Australian Defence Association is a front of the National Civic Council, for a very specific reason. That reason is that the Australian Defence Association was established as, and was for a period of time, a front of the National Civic Council until late 1982, when there was a split in the National Civic Council. A significant proportion of the supporters and members of that organisation left the organisation, mainly consisting of the then leaderships of the Federated Clerks Union and the shop assistants union and formed another organisation of a similar nature which initially commenced under the title of the Industrial Action Fund.

Mr O'Connor, the leader of the Australian Defence Association, was an integral part of the group that split from the National Civic Council at that time. That group was headed by Mr John Maynes, the national vice-president of the National Civic Council prior to the split, and also at that stage the national president of the Federated Clerks Union.

At this point and subsequently, Mr O'Connor was employed by an organisation called FEDSDA Credit Cooperative, a small credit union established by the Federated Clerks Union and the shop assistants union to provide credit union facilities to the members of those unions. When I took office as secretary of the Federated Clerks Union, Victorian Branch in 1988, I discovered that the Victorian branch of the union was subsidising Mr O'Connor's wages in that position by roughly $13,000 per annum with very little genuine return to the union membership. I speculated at the time on precisely how much work he was doing for the credit union and how much he was doing for the Australian Defence Association.

Mr O'Connor has remained active in the breakaway group from the National Civic Council since that split. Although he is technically correct in denying that the Australian Defence Association and he have any connection with the National Civic Council, there is still a very clear connection with that particular strand of politics in this country.

The Australian Defence Association is a classic example of a front organisation established by the National Civic Council. It has a number of fairly prominent, mostly retired, military figures to add respectability but it is run by people who, under any test, would be considered to be extreme right wing fanatics.

It is interesting to note that in recent times Mr O'Connor and the association have endeavoured to at least moderate their public image, even if their true position on certain matters has not altered. For example, in 1986 the Dibb report was fairly savagely criticised by the Australian Defence Association, as seen in a Canberra Times article of 24 June 1986. According to the Australian of 21 March of this year, the Dibb report is now referred to by Mr O'Connor as a `landmark' report. Mr O'Connor's deputy and associate editor of the Australian Defence Association's journal, Mr Brian Ridge, is also a longstanding activist with a National Civic Council background.

I place these things on record to indicate that, although it is correct to say that the Australian Defence Association is no longer a National Civic Council front, it is certainly still very squarely in that part of the political spectrum in this country. It therefore disturbs me that it is seen by sections of the media as a mainstream source of credible opinion on defence issues when, I would submit, it clearly is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I would like to put on record the concerns of two of my constituents—Mr and Mrs Barnes—who are trying to get their mother out to Australia. Recognising the limited amount of time that I have, I will go directly to the issues.

PARA.TAB: On 24 January 1992, Mrs Barnes's mother applied to come to Australia. She filled in a form 47 while a form 40, the form for sponsorship, was filled in by Mr and Mrs Barnes. In the process of having her medical, the radiologists detected, or thought they detected, old TB scars on both upper lobes, although, as they said, they could not detect signs of active disease.

The radiologists wrote to the applicant's doctor and asked for further tests to be carried out. In fact, a series of tests was carried out at the hospital at that time because there were a couple of other factors to be examined. One factor was mobility, which was answered satisfactorily by her doctor.

The hospital doctor involved wrote and said that the later set of chest X-rays were, if anything, a little better than the earlier ones, with moderate resolution of the upper left zone shadowing. The doctor said that she was not being treated for tuberculosis but could see why a radiologist may have queried this possibility. That was followed up by a series of other tests carried out for this applicant. The letter that followed through from Aintree Hospitals said:

SPEECH.PARA: The chest x-ray shadowing which this lady has is longstanding. Broncheolar lavage has been performed of the area of suspicion on the chest x-ray and this shows no evidence of tuberculosis.

This letter was actually written on 24 September 1992 and forwarded to the Australian office in Manchester. The application was knocked back by the department, and the date of that letter was 24 February 1993—some considerable time later. It was knocked back on the basis of item 9 of schedule 1 of the regulation. In fact, item 9 states:
the applicant is free from:

(a)tuberculosis or any other communicable disease of a fatal or serious nature which, in the opinion of a Commonwealth medical officer, is a threat to public health in Australia; and is not suspected of having contracted such a disease. . .
This application eventually went through the tribunal process, and the tribunal, in its conclusion, said:

The Tribunal has previously held on a number of occasions that, whilst items 9(a) and 9(b) require the Tribunal to be an arbiter of fact with respect to the existence of the disease in question, an opinion formed by a CMO under item 9(c) above is not reviewable by the Tribunal.

As a result of his assessment the chief medical officer indicated, without taking into account the further tests that were carried out, that this particular woman had tuberculosis. The real problem that exists, as far as I am concerned, is the follow-up, where the tribunal says:
The Tribunal has also stated that this situation is unfortunate—
and certainly it is—

as the CMO's in the Migrant Medical Clearances unit, who make thousands of assessments per year, are not resourced to provide reviews of their own opinions at the level demanded by the public of bodies such as this Tribunal.

Here we have a case of a lady who, clearly, as has been shown by the evidence provided by doctors, has not got tuberculosis or has not had tuberculosis. Because the decision of the chief medical officer is not reviewable, the only way the tribunal can act on this is for the chief medical officer to take action to look at this case. I find it disgraceful that, although, clearly, evidence is available, funds cannot be provided for the chief medical officer to reassess his original position based on the information of the additional medical assessments that have been done by specialists.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the mess that the government has created with occupational superannuation. I want to give the House an example. I had a letter from a constituent referring to a visit he made to Mildura to pick grapes. He was anxious to work and he went to assist a friend in picking his crop. On 14 April 1993 his employer paid an amount of $43.38 into the Australian Farm Superannuation Fund for his benefit. He telephoned the administrator of Australian Eagle Life Ltd on 21 January 1994 to find out the balance in the account. To his disgust he found that the balance in the account was zero. When he questioned the company why this was so, it was indicated to him that a weekly fee of 85c was charged, even though, except for an insurance cover cost, there were no other transactions.

PARA.TAB: It is a terrible indictment of the government's occupational superannuation that someone who is prepared to work and has paid into a superannuation fund finds that there is no benefit to him whatsoever. There are ways around this problem. One of the ways—and I declare my interest—is a building society superannuation savings account. The government is resisting allowing building societies to participate in superannuation savings accounts. The accounts would be subject to preservation and other requirements applying to superannuation savings generally and to preferential taxation treatment.

The accounts would not require a trust deed or be subject to expensive prospectus requirements. Contributions would be deposits made with the society. They would be transacted in simple, plain English terms and conditions to comply with ISC standards. They would be contained in the records of account which would either be a simple passbook or a regular statement account style. The distinction between superannuation savings accounts and normal savings accounts would be emphasised and drawn to the attention of members. Ease and simplicity of deposit making would be features, using the branch network, direct crediting systems and automatic teller machines. There would be no special or extra fees.

This is what my constituent, Mr Adrian Johnson, objected to in his letter to me. He objected to the fees that were charged on this account. The fees built up and totally wiped out the amount of $43.38. There was absolutely no benefit to a person who was working and paying into an occupational superannuation fund which the government insisted that his employer must provide for.

I make a suggestion to the government. I would be pleased if the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the Special Minister of State (Mr Johns), who are at the table, would take this on board, because I know they are listening quite intently. The government is looking for answers to the mess that it has created with occupational superannuation in this country. I ask the two ministers at the table to have a look at this suggestion and bring it to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Willis).

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I visited Hay in the west of my electorate and met a lady who owns a transport business with her husband. They have been in business for 25 years, and the lady tells me that she has been helping her husband, except for the last couple of months of her pregnancy, drive the vehicles. As we could imagine, they have never had it easy in their business, but their current situation is the most difficult that they have encountered.

PARA.TAB: Bureaucratic paperwork, union influence on their business and government taxes have put enormous pressure on their business. They used to have 10 trucks, but now they are down to six. They have found that it is just not worth employing people because of the union problem. They found out that it is easier to drive the trucks themselves. This is what they are trying to do, but it is having an effect on their family, and in the long run it will have an effect on their health.

This is the longest they have ever gone without buying any equipment because, if one wants to buy a prime mover, as the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), who is at the table, would know, it costs about $200,000 without the trailer. Of course, $60,000 is paid in sales tax. We can imagine the problems that they are having in trying to find the money to purchase new trucks.

It is interesting to note that not so long ago in the Hay district there used to be about 40 trucks carting stock, but now the numbers are down to about 10. Many of the people who were driving those trucks have left the district because there is no longer a market for their skills. That is another reason why there are not many people remaining in rural Australia. Some of those people have gone on to unemployment benefits.

The biggest single burden on this business is fuel tax. In the last 12 months, for example, they paid $148,672 in diesel tax. Under the government's tax hikes in the 1993-94 budget it is estimated that the average rig will cost an extra $6,400 a year to run. That includes sales tax increases on spare parts and fuel excise increases. However, the coalition promised that we would abolish the excise because we believe in genuine regional development and we believe in doing something positive for rural areas.

This financial year the government will collect $9,706,000,000 in fuel excise and will spend only $820 million on roads. People in the west know exactly what bad roads mean. The honourable shadow minister at the table recently spent some time in a truck driving up the Kidman Way, part of which is located in my electorate, to see the standard of the roads and see what can be done to try to overcome the problem. The enormous discrepancy between the amount of fuel tax collected and the amount spent on roads is a scandal. Until we do something about spending more money on roads we are not going to get anywhere.

The federal government can never be expected to be taken seriously in regard to regional development unless it cuts the price of transport in regional and rural areas and increases road funding to provide a safe and comprehensive road network throughout the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the unauthorised use of an armoured personnel carrier (APC) in Perth during which a civilian used the APC to ram buildings in the Perth central business district occur because budget cutbacks have reduced defence security.
(2) What armaments are left inside APCs.
(3) What training or experience would a civilian require to operate an APC.
(4) What security procedures and restrictions apply to ammunition for military weapons.
(5) Can a civilian obtain ammunition commercially to suit weapons used by the Australian Defence Force.
(6) How much fuel is left in APCs not in use.
(7) What surveillance is made of defence premises after military contact hours.
(8) Have there been any instances where matters relating to security have been raised with the Department of Defence as an issue of concern; if so, (a) when and (b) by whom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Normal security precautions, which have been in effect virtually unchanged since the introduction of the M113 APC in 1964, were in force at the time of the incident.
(2) M113 APCs are normally secured with the .50 calibre and .30 calibre machine guns fitted, but with breech blocks and barrels removed and stored in the armoury.
(3) A civilian with reasonable mechanical aptitude would probably be able to start and drive an APC after 10-15 minutes of trial and error.

(4) There are detailed instructions on the issue of security of arms and ammunition. Ammunition may only be stored in an approved magazine. Small amounts of small-arms ammunition, including 12.7mm and .30 calibre can be stored in an approved locked container (normally a safe or armoury) for up to 24 hours. Ammunition stored in other circumstances is physically picquetted 24 hours a day.

(5) All types of small arms ammunition, up to and including .50 calibre machine gun rounds, used by the Australian Defence Force is commercially available from Australian and overseas suppliers. Although civilian sporting ammunition may have slight design differences from military rounds, they could be fired from a military weapon.
(6) There is no formal policy on the amount of fuel to be left in an APC when not in use. However, it is normal practice to refuel any vehicle immediately after use.

(7) The level of out of hours surveillance of Defence premises depends on the relative importance of the facility for national security. For example, facilities which are deemed to be major assets are accorded a level of physical security which includes surveillance by guards, mobile or roving patrols or approved intrusion alarm systems. At the other end of the scale, facilities of lesser importance in terms of national security may not require out of hours surveillance but, where appropriate, duty personnel and Service police provide a degree of monitoring.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the RAAF conducted tests into the use of its Hercules aircraft for water bombing to combat fires by installing tanks into the aircraft's hold; if so, (a) how were the tests conducted and (b) what were the results.
(2) Has the Government decided not to proceed with the use of Hercules aircraft for water bombing; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) During the 1981/82 and 1982/83 Victorian summer fire seasons the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments conducted a cooperative trial to evaluate the use of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) C130 Hercules aircraft for bushfire suppression. The Hercules was fitted with a Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System (MAFFS) which was loaned to the Victorian Government by the United States (US) Forests Service. The MAFFS system, which carries 11,300 litres of fire retardant slurry, is able to be fitted to the Hercules without requiring modification to the aircraft.

The trials were conducted in an operational environment and were thoroughly evaluated by a project team from the Fire Research Section of the then Forests Commission of Victoria (FCV). The Hercules made a total of 193 drops on 29 fires over the two fire seasons, covering a wide range of vegetation and fire types, and intensities.

The FCV provided fire retardant mixing and loading facilities and provided experienced fire service personnel to supervise airborne operations, ensuring that fire-bombing from the Hercules was integrated into the fire control strategy in the most effective manner. Prior to conducting the trials, the RAAF crews and FCV personnel involved received extensive training in the application and operation of the system from the US Forests Service and the US Air National Guard.
The evaluation demonstrated that, while the MAFFS-equipped Hercules could be successfully incorporated into fire-suppression operations, it did not significantly improve aerial attack capability.
This was due to the system not being effective on fires more intense than those successfully attacked by smaller, lower cost fire-bombing aircraft.

(2) At this time the Commonwealth has decided not to proceed with the use of Hercules aircraft for the purpose of fire-bombing. This approach reflects the results of the 1981/82 and 1982/83 trials and of additional research conducted by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisa

ANSWER.PARA: tion (CSIRO) into aerial fire fighting capability during 1984 and 1985. The CSIRO study found that larger fixed-wing aircraft, including RAAF Hercules, were not cost-effective for fire suppression under Australian conditions.

PARA.TAB: However, this issue is to be discussed at the 1994 meeting of the National Emergency Management Committee, which is the peak national body, consisting of state and territory authorities, for emergency management issues. Should a national view on this issue emerge at this meeting, it will be discussed further at a Ministerial meeting scheduled for later this year.
